PETITION.TITLE: Sporting, Cultural and Community Groups: Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned,
(i) are alarmed that many sporting, cultural and community groups have been made to feel that they can attract sponsorship only from promoters of unhealthy products;
(ii) call for a National Health Promotion Foundation to be established through an increase in tobacco excise of 10 cents per packet; and

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by WA Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bjelke-Petersen (from 27 citizens) and Jones (from 13 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated and Violent Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:

The Parliamentary Joint Select Committee on Video Material has concluded that ``Adverse effects upon people, and especially upon children, of exposure to material containing various degrees of violence, pornography or obscenity have been demonstrated''.
The majority of the Select Committee strongly opposed the proposition for a new NVE (non-violent erotica) category, which would have entrenched X-rated video pornography.
All six State Governments have, through their Attorneys-General, expressed unanimous opposition to the circulation of X-rated videos.
We consider the continuing distribution of X-rated videos from the A.C.T. to be reprehensible and to be contrary to the wellbeing of the Australian community in general.
We strongly request urgent Government action to prohibit the distribution of X-rated and excessively violent video material.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Elector-initiated Referendum

Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned showeth:
That Kingsford-Smith Airport is becoming increasingly congested and existing facilities are inadequate to handle the number of aircraft or their passengers.

2. upgrade existing radar and other traffic control facilities to enable Australia's high safety record to be maintained.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: Buddhist Leaders
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament;
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate,
That the Australian Parliament expresses its repugnance that the Socialist Republic of Vietnam has kept imprisoned, 47 Buddhist leaders since 1984.

And further, that the regime in Vietnam has recently tried and sentenced to death: Thich Tri Sieu and Thich Tue Sy, two distinguished scholars from amongst the 47. Both of these religious academics are intellectuals of the highest order, being scholars in Buddhist Scripture.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to denounce the intentions of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam and to call on the Vietnamese Government for clemency and a remission of the death sentence as being barbaric.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I ask: Has the attention of the Minister been drawn to an article on page 1 of today's edition of the Australian newspaper written by Paul Kelly outlining the essential differences between the Liberal and National parties in the Federal Opposition coalition over the issue of deregulation of the wheat industry? What effect will this impasse have on the Government's policy in regard to the wheat industry? What is the level of Federal Government concern about a possible loss of confidence amongst Australian growers, exporters and overseas consumers of our wheat?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read the article-few could have missed it-on the front page of today's Australian, headed `Wheat strikes at the heart of Coalition unity'. It would seem from all the reports that that is an accurate description of what is occurring in the Opposition ranks. I understand that the coalition has set up a wheat peace group and that Senator David Brownhill is a member of that committee. I have a high regard for Senator Brownhill's competence and ability, but I must say that even someone as competent and able as he may not be able to bring about a solution in a matter as fundamental to National Party politics in this country as this division in the Opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been asked by Senator Jones what effects the impasse in the coalition will have on Government policy in regard to the wheat industry. The Government has decided on a package of measures to apply to wheat marketing from 30 June this year. Legislation putting the Government's proposals into effect is currently being prepared for introduction and passage in the current parliamentary sittings. The Government is determined to proceed with its plans for the wheat industry. The fact that the coalition cannot make up its mind on a wheat marketing policy will have no effect on the Government's wheat marketing package.

TALK.START.PARA: —When will you make up your mind?

—I am interested that the bleats come loudly from members of the Opposition when they get pinned on this matter. The sooner the wheat legislation is in place, the sooner the industry and the Australian Wheat Board--
—Mr President, I take a point of order. I invite the Minister to table the Bill so that we can see what the Government actually intends to do.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I will deal with that interjection, which is not a point of order-and Senator Chaney knew it not to be a point of order when he rose to address you, Mr President-when I conclude my answer. The sooner the wheat legislation is in place, the sooner the industry and the Australian Wheat Board can get on with the important job of planning and establishing operations reflecting its wider responsibilities and powers under the new charter.

ANSWER.PARA: The press article today fails to point out that there is a substantial body of support within the wheat industry for deregulation of the domestic market, which after all accounts for only around 15 per cent of the crop. The Australian Wheat Board will continue to have control over the bulk of the crop, which goes to overseas customers. In this context it is an absolute nonsense to say, as the Grains Council of Australia does, that the Australian Wheat Board will no longer control price, and that prices will collapse. The fact is that some 80 per cent of our milling and industrial wheat is exported and, under the Government's plan, the Australian Wheat Board will be the sole exporter. As well, the Australian Wheat Board will be a strong operator in the domestic market and will have the necessary powers and government borrowing guarantees to compete for cash. The Government is concerned with the efficiency and effectiveness of the marketing process itself, and this is the key objective of the Government's package of measures for the wheat industry.

Senator Jones also asked me what were the levels of Federal Government concern about a possible loss of confidence amongst Australian growers, exporters and overseas consumers of wheat. Those engaged in marketing and purchasing Australian wheat need have no concerns. We will continue to supply wheat of a high and consistent quality.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stick to mining; you are good at that.

—Does the honourable senator dispute that? We will continue to supply wheat of a high and consistent quality and we will do this cheaply and efficiently through the Australian Wheat Board. The Government is concerned to maintain a strong and viable wheat industry in Australia. The package of measures agreed to by the Government recognises that, by world standards, Australia's wheat industry is efficient and responsive but that there is potential for further benefits to be achieved from increased competition within Australia. A major objective is to strengthen the effectiveness of the Australian Wheat Board as a marketer and trader and to move it progressively away from government control to full industry accountability and control.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government will continue to support the industry during its transitional period by the provision of borrowing guarantees for advance payments and the establishment of an industry fund. The Government has also undertaken to guarantee borrowings of up to $100m for the purposes of the industry fund. The new arrangements will provide more flexibility and choice to growers to achieve cost savings in marketing and the moving and handling of their wheat. Freeing the domestic market will bring competitive pressures to the storage, handling and transport sector where potential exists for significant savings. I believe that fully answers the questions by Senator Jones.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on. Fair is fair.

—Might I say in response to the interjection from Senator Chaney that this matter has been canvassed widely by my colleague and senior Minister, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, in terms of deregulation. If Senator Chaney does not know what the idea of deregulation is, I am terribly surprised.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is it a fact that, in a desire not to offend other governments, his Department gives security agencies only 28 days in which to gather and present evidence relevant to a visa application? What flexibility, if any, is there in the application of this deadline? Is the Minister satisfied that the present procedures enable proper assessment and scrutiny of foreign nationals seeking diplomatic status in Australia? When were the procedures established and are there any plans for a review in the near future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very difficult to please everyone in this business. It is the case that, from time to time, there are differences of view as between agencies and departments on whether particular visas should be issued for people coming in and differences of view about the time that is necessary to scrutinise the circumstances of the particular diplomatic applicant for a visa. The standard time, as I understand it, has been of the order of 28 or 30 days. I will need to check that point of detail and also the point of detail about the period for which this particular procedure, if it could be so described, has been in place.

ANSWER.PARA: One has to make a judgment; weigh and balance on the one hand the desire, no doubt, of security agencies to have an almost open- ended time in which to pursue investigations of this kind, compared with, on the other hand, the need for efficient and effective governmental relationships and not to delay unduly diplomatic visa applicants any more than anybody else's visa application. So it is a matter of judgment, of balance, with some variation of approach in particular circumstances as I said in answer to a question the other day. If I have anything else to add to the question I will be happy to do so with a follow-up answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister to answer the other part of the question which referred to whether he was satisfied that the present procedures enable proper assessment. Furthermore, if he is not satisfied, are there plans to review or change the procedures?

—There is no case that I have been involved in, in either my time as Attorney-General some years ago or more recently in my time as Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, that has led me to any personal dissatisfaction with the system as is presently operated. I have no personal agenda to review the system but it is something to which I will give further consideration in light of Senator Hill's question.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an environment article in today's Sydney Morning Herald by Greg Roberts? In the article it is suggested by a researcher, Dr Larkum, that large areas of coral in the Great Barrier Reef have been damaged by sewage, in particular an area near Heron Island? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the accuracy of these claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to the article which appeared this morning. Dr Larkum has been investigating for some time the effects of sewage in the Barrier Reef. However, the article is completely wrong when it suggests that an area near Heron Island has been badly damaged by sewage. I think Dr Larkum has been basing some of his experiments at Heron Island on controlled conditions. When contacted this morning by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority he was able to give it an assurance, which I can give to the Senate, that no area near Heron Island has been affected in the way claimed in the article.

ANSWER.PARA: As for the rest of the article and its tenor, I would have to concede that there has always been concern, and always will be concern, about sewage on the Great Barrier Reef and the effect of nutrients on coral. Obviously that is an area that will require much more research. I do not think that there is anyone in the world who can say definitely what all the effects are or what the effects of particular amounts of nutrient might be. The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority spends about a quarter of its research budget on researching the effects of nutrients on corals. Most of that research is conducted in areas where there is the largest amount of tourist traffic-that is, the strip between Townsville and Cairns, areas such as Magnetic Island. I think that most of the rest of the money would be spent in the Whitsundays. The concentration has been in those areas.

All tourist developments require a permit to discharge into the marine park. Applications are assessed very carefully. Just for once I will not be critical of the Queensland Government, because its Water Quality Council standards are high and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority ensures that they are met. Floating structures, such as the hotels which have had so much publicity in recent times and pontoons, are required to hold sewage in their tanks and to transport it away from the reefs before it is discharged into the ocean. Island resorts are required to meet a minimum of secondary processing standards and developers are required to fund the environmental monitoring of the effects of any discharge of effluent. Some island resorts are in the process of upgrading their sewage treatment plants and the Authority is looking at that carefully. Guidelines have been drafted by the Authority on the basis of the latest research, and standards for the discharge of effluent will be tightened even further if research, such as the kind being conducted by Dr Larkum, suggests that that is the appropriate way to go.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs stated at Question Time last Friday that the Government's $240 administration charge for migrant appeals against assigned status was subject to `uncertainty created by differing legal views', I ask the Minister whether the Commonwealth Ombudsman and the Attorney-General both take the view that a legislative basis is needed for the $240 fee. On whose advice did the Minister decide to continue to levy the fee without legislation? How many appellants have paid the fee since September 1987, and what total sum has been received from them? What plans does the Minister have to refund the fees collected to date? In respect of the test case brought in Victoria in March 1988 to challenge the legality of the $240 fee, I ask: Why was a decision made not to allow the case to run as a test case with both parties bearing their own costs: why was the issue of the costs of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs in that action not raised until the Commonwealth Ombudsman's investigations were all but completed; was the decision to pursue the Department's costs of $4,475 in November 1988 an attempt to discourage the complainant from seeking the Ombudsman's assistance; does the Minister intend to pursue the demand for $4,475 in costs in spite of his concession regarding the merit of the aborted test case; and on what basis was the decision made not to fight the second test cast brought in New South Wales and conceded by the Minister on 15 December 1988?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Early on the Department obtained the views of both senior and junior counsel in the case before the Federal Court challenge to the legality of the fee referred to by the honourable senator. The counsel were Mr Black, QC, and Mr Bell. It was this advice that was relied upon to continue to collect the fee administratively. Subsequently further advice was sought which introduced an element of doubt. I sought the advice of the Attorney-General on 24 October 1988 and received it on 12 December 1988. That advice had changed over the course of 12 months. The Attorney advised that the matter was now not entirely free from doubt and it was his view that it was the better course to put the matter beyond doubt by legislating for the fee. The Government is committed to this course as a result of the inquiry of the Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies, and the legislation implementing the Government's decision will be introduced in this session. As I said in the Senate on 3 March, the Ombudsman's report provided an impetus to act now to cease Independent Review Panel (IRP) arrangements, to introduce regulations as an interim measure and to provide a second application regime.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the second part of the honourable senator's question, between September 1987 and February 1989 inclusive approximately 11,400 appellants had paid around $2.7m. In answer to question No. 3, there are no plans to refund the money collected as fees for the review by the IRP. As I have previously said, I do not think the collection of the fee for administrative review has been unreasonable. In answer to question No. 4, which is a five-part question, regarding the litigation in Victoria in March 1988, referred to by Senator Jenkins, to challenge the legality of the fee, the reason that the case did not run its full course was that the applicant withdrew. It would be improper for the Commonwealth, if litigation were entered against a Commonwealth action, to agree that each party bear its own costs. Where litigants are successful in the court, it is usual for the cost to be awarded in their favour. Likewise, where someone commences litigation and withdraws, it is usual that they bear defending party costs. It is not the case that the issue of the Department's costs was not raised until the Ombudsman's investigations were all but completed. The Department, in March 1988, made its position on costs clear, namely, that the appellant would be responsible for the costs awarded against her. There has been no deviation from this position.

In answer to part (c) of the fourth question, the decision taken in November 1988 to maintain the earlier decision to pursue costs was made in light of the usual policy that Commonwealth revenues be protected. Nothing was done to discourage anybody seeking the Ombudsman's assistance-either a litigant or any other person. In answer to part (d) of the fourth question, regarding the matter of continuing to pursue costs, if the unsuccessful litigant wishes to raise a question of significant hardship or any other matter relating to paying costs, I will consider that submission. In answer to part (e) of the fourth question, in December 1988 litigation was commenced in an unrelated case in New South Wales. That case challenged the interpretation and application of change of status policy and also challenged the imposition of the $240 fee. On the basis of counsel's advice, my Department considered the primary decision defective on the basis of an interpretation and application of change of status policy and, accordingly, the decision was vacated and the litigation discontinued.

In conclusion, I personally believe that it is necessary to have some charge for review on a user-pays principle. Without that, especially in the immigration area, there will be many frivolous appeals. Certainly in the new proposed model, a fee will be included in the legislation. The people who have generally been stirring in this area have one common feature, that is, they are lawyers. Lawyers always believe that one should never charge a fee for anything except for their own services. They also seem to believe that the immigration area is the new growth area. Most lawyers have now been excluded from workers' compensation. They are now looking for a new area to leech onto, and the most vulnerable area they have found is the area of defenceless migrants.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not care what the interjection is. Opposition senators should see how many of their own constituents are being exploited by solicitors. It is an absolute shame and I think this Parliament should do what it can to stop it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BUFFALO ERADICATION PROGRAM: KAKADU NATIONAL PARK

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories inform the Senate of the extent to which the buffalo eradication program in Kakadu National Park utilises commercial operators to remove buffalo from the park, rather than carrying out wholesale shooting? Can the Minister advise the Senate as to the environmental impact of the buffalo control measures in Kakadu National Park?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Collins would be aware, the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service has been implementing a program of buffalo eradication in Kakadu since 1979. That program was required for two reasons: firstly, the bovine brucellosis and tuberculosis campaign and, secondly, the environmental damage that the buffalo were causing. I do not think anyone would dispute that the damage they were causing to Kakadu was extensive indeed. We have achieved considerable success on stages 1 and 2 of Kakadu. Already it is generally acknowledged that that has led to a spectacular recovery in vegetation in those areas. Soil erosion, which has been an enormous problem in respect of buffalo in Kakadu, is also now less of a problem than it was. Obviously, we have had a preference for not allowing the wholesale shooting of the animals. Consequently, they have been rounded up, herded and taken away, largely for domestication and meat supply purposes. That is a policy which we have preferred and which will continue.

ANSWER.PARA: In stage 3, which comprises the former pastoral leases of Gimbat and Goodparla, that has also been the basis for the removal of buffalo. These are areas for which Senator Evans has expressed particular affection in recent years. In 1988 some 6,000 animals were removed from Gimbat by the successful tenderer. Counts of the remaining buffalo by officers from the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service have indicated that sufficient numbers remain for a further commercial take and tenders will shortly be called for the coming season. On Goodparla the former leaseholders continued to remove stock under an agreement with the Commonwealth until 31 December 1988. More than 12,000 animals were taken to domestication programs or abattoirs. Arrangements for a further stock removal at Goodparla are currently being considered.

Again, in Gimbat and Goodparla there has been a remarkable recovery of the vegetation in what is a fairly dry area of the park. As with stages 1 and 2, priority has been given in stage 3 to the commercial utilisation of buffalo rather than shooting. Returns to the Commonwealth so far in the current financial year show that the buffalo contracts in Kakadu amount to $316,000 and that for the Northern Land Council buffalo control costs amount to a further $65,000. The management plan foreshadowed the establishment of a controlled population of buffalo within a specific area. Having in mind the need of the traditional owners to have some source of meat, to maintain within the park some illustration of its history and to maintain an obvious attraction to tourists, negotiations with the Kakadu Association are well under way and I hope that we will be able to stock a suitable area and fence it off very shortly.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: McLEAN CONSOLIDATED PTY LTD: ROYALTY PAYMENTS

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Resources. I refer to a previous question which I put to the Minister on 1 December last year regarding the financial instability of McLean Consolidated Pty Ltd, to which he proceeded to issue an export woodchip licence a few weeks later. First, is the Minister aware that the Western Australian Government seized the timber stock of McLean Consolidated on 14 February 1989 because the company is months behind in royalty payments, and that another company, Whittakers Ltd, has negotiated a purchase price of $1.5m for McLean's Denmark mill and the 60,000 tonne per year woodchip export licence? Secondly, does the Minister agree that the financial collapse of McLean Consolidated Pty Ltd and its subsequent takeover by Whittakers comprise a change in the terms of the proposal and are deserving of full public disclosure of economic and environmental implications? Thirdly, will the Minister stand by the commitment given at a meeting with conservation groups on 22 November 1988 and tabled by him in the Senate on 15 December in which he `indicated that if there were to be any change in the proposal it would be subject to the appropriate environmental analysis.'? Fourthly, in relation to the sale of McLean Consolidated, could the Minister clarify the position of Gersor Pty Limited, who are 50 per cent joint partners of the McLean export woodchip licence? Finally, if not, is the Minister aware that Gersor Pty Limited is a shelf company with an issue of two shares valued at one dollar each?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vallentine continues her ghoulish interest in the financial affairs of this particular company.
—Tell us what sort of interest you have.
—She will be a threat to capitalism next.

—Perhaps I should ignore the interjections and answer the question. Neither of the interjections is particularly helpful, nor do they illuminate the matter in any way. Senator Vallentine asks me whether I am aware that the Western Australian Government has seized the timber stock of McLeans. Yes, I am. The reason it has done so, I understand, is that McLeans was significantly behind in the payment of royalties to the Western Australian Government. The Western Australian Government then seized the timber stock to secure the payment of the royalties, but reached an arrangement with the company and timber has been released from that stock and the company is trading otherwise normally, the Western Australian Government having secured protection for royalty cover if the company were in some form later to default. So I am aware of that.

ANSWER.PARA: The next question was whether I agreed that the financial collapse of McLean and the takeover comprise a change in the proposal. I do not think that they change the proposal so far as I would define `proposal' in the normal sense of the usage of that word in the context of woodchip export licences. The proposal in a woodchip export licence context is a proposal to export a given amount of woodchips from a particular source for a specified price over a given period. The ownership change of a company does not alter where the source of the woodchips is, whether it is environmentally sound, what the price relationship of that export is, and over what period the new owner might export. Therefore, it seems to me that the proposal as used in this context is not being changed in a way in which it would require a further environmental assessment.

That goes to the next question Senator Vallentine asked, as to whether I would honour my undertaking. Of course I would honour my undertaking. I always honour my undertakings, but the undertaking as Senator Vallentine has expressed it is not consistent with the undertaking I gave at the time in the meeting with the environmentalists to which she referred. I also understand that on 27 February Whittakers made a takeover bid for McLeans but that bid is stalled at the moment as to whether or not it should be referred to the shareholders for decision. If it were to be stopped, there is then a hiatus and other bidders can come into the market. But there is the prospect or possibility of a management buy-out; there is the prospect or possibility of the Coalition for Denmark's Environment, an environmental group, buying the mill. There is a complication in that someone by the name of Mr Traher is claiming some ownership, which complicates the whole matter. At this stage I cannot be absolutely sure what the future ownership of that mill facility will be, but if the conditions that I have set for the export licence are adhered to there is no reason why the export licence should not be given. I make this point particularly strongly. The export licence is to export sawmill residue, that is, the material left over after sawmilling has been conducted. The alternative to reducing that residue to woodchips and exporting it would be simply to burn it. As there is always sawmill residue after a sawmilling operation, it would seem sensible for the mill facility to avail itself of a commercial woodchip market, if such is available, rather than burn it, thus adding to the carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. Finally, I was asked about the role of Gersor Pty Ltd. I am aware of the company's role in the McLean takeover.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to reports that the Australian Taxation Office has been issuing tax file numbers to dead persons? How many tax file numbers were mailed to dead persons and to wrong addresses? Can the Minister explain how such a bungle in the Taxation Office occurred? Has the Government or the Taxation Office ruled out the possibility that organised crime has been trying to subvert the tax file number system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I knew that the Liberal Party was trying to subvert the tax file number system, but I would not yet put it in the category of organised crime, although it is something to think about.
—Disorganised crime!

—I should put it that way, yes. I was asked whether the Taxation Office has mailed out tax file numbers to people who are dead. I do not know for sure, but I think it highly likely. When somebody dies, it is not the custom for the next of kin immediately to notify the Taxation Office of the death. Indeed, it might be sometime afterwards before the Taxation Office becomes aware of the death of a taxpayer who, because he was a taxpayer, had a tax file number. It also often takes considerable time for the Tax Office to discover whether a taxpayer has changed address. I am advised that it is correct that the Tax Office has mailed to taxpayers advice of their current tax file number. The purpose is to remind them that they can complete their new tax instalment declaration on 1 April, as is required and, indeed, is in their interests.

ANSWER.PARA: I am also told, as I suggested earlier, that in some cases, advices have been sent to wrong addresses in Western Australia, Queensland and the Northern Territory because taxpayers have changed addresses without advising the Tax Office. The Tax Office computers are not and never can be completely up to date. It is not realistic to expect that they would be. The Tax Office regrets any distress that such errors might have caused, and when it became aware of the problem it ceased mailing tax file number advices. It now advises that it intends to mail advices only to those taxpayers who lodged a tax return in 1988. However, that will not entirely rule out the possibility of correspondence being sent to people who have moved. Therefore, it may still be sent to obsolete addresses. Advices may also still be sent to those who have died. Inevitably, commonsense and logic would suggest that this is not the first time the Tax Office has sent correspondence to people who are deceased, because it is in correspondence with most taxpayers at least once a year, frequently more often. The statistical probability is such that there must have been previous occasions on which the Tax Office mailed assessment or advice of some sort to people who were deceased. This, however, is the first occasion on which I can remember anybody kicking up a fuss about it. The reason for that is that the Liberal Party is following Peter Sawyer, the League of Rights and the other ratbags in a campaign designed to undermine the efficiency of this tax enforcement mechanism.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. I leave aside the point that it sounds as though the Government has not thrown away the idea of the Australia Card, as the Prime Minister had promised. It looks as though it is still on the agenda. I ask the Minister-and he totally avoided giving me an answer: Is organised crime involved in picking up the tax file number documents which have been forwarded to dead persons?
—Certainly not to my knowledge. I do not know what information, if any, Senator Messner has and whether he has any more reliable source for that allegation than, say, Peter Sawyer.
—What about the newspapers this morning?

—Some of the newspapers are no more reliable than Peter Sawyer either. If Senator Messner has that information, he can provide it to me or give it direct to the Attorney-General or the Treasurer. If he gives it to me, I will certainly hand it on to them.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs. Has the Minister seen advertisements in national newspapers for various `Lotto schemes' guaranteeing wins by those who subscribe to those systems? Would the Minister advise honourable senators whether it is worth while investing in such schemes to supplement their incomes? If not, can it be assumed that action is being taken to protect consumers from losing their savings on such lottery systems? When can we expect an end to the advertising of such schemes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer to one part of Senator Maguire's question is that, even on his income, he should stay away from such schemes. The matter raised by the honourable senator has been the subject of numerous complaints over recent days, particularly in Queensland and New South Wales. The advertisements for `get rich quick' lotto schemes are non-scientific. They are certainly not a new approach to ripping off gullible consumers.

ANSWER.PARA: The scheme which Senator Maguire refers to purports to offer guaranteed winnings on the basis of scientifically-based and mathematically-assessed probabilities with the use of high technology computer equipment and techniques. The schemes are being promoted in full page advertisements in which people are being told that they can win and win consistently. After making contact with a return coupon, people are requested to provide further large amounts of money for a full system, in order to be in a position to make these massive winnings. Basically, the information which is provided in exchange for this money is also set out in booklets which can be bought very cheaply in many major retail outlets. The schemes in question are neither new nor scientific. They are merely a variation of existing pyramid schemes or games.

As a consequence of the fact that there has been a prevalence of these sorts of promotions, the Trade Practices Commission, together with State consumer protection agencies, has been pursuing this matter. The schemes in question probably contravene three or four provisions of the Trade Practices Act and also some State consumer legislation. Accordingly, a number of proceedings have been instituted by State agencies to chase up the promoters of such schemes. Major difficulties are involved in the successful location and prosecution of the promoters of these schemes. This is because of the large number and great variety of schemes involved. Also, promoters change both their business names and their locations as often as possible.

In order to be more successful in our approach in this area, we are also conducting, through the Trade Practices Commission, a publicity campaign which is very much geared towards protecting, advising and warning consumers about this sort of approach. The campaign being run by the Trade Practices Commission is very much in line with other campaigns that we have run, such as the campaign to warn small businesses against bogus telex directory advertising.

So the matter that Senator Maguire raises is of concern to us. In order that we can offer adequate and effective protection to consumers, we are pursuing this matter not only on a cooperative basis with the States but also on our level with a keenly tuned publicity campaign, as well as an intention on the part of the Trade Practices Commission to prosecute wherever we can.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and also concerns alleged abuse or maladministration of the tax file number system and unauthorised access to confidential information. I have referred the Minister to a report in Saturday's West Australian newspaper in which a former insurance investigator alleges that police and Australian Taxation Office officials illegally provided confidential information and that in some cases bribery is involved. The Minister would be aware that the newspaper reported that it tested the informant's credentials by asking him to obtain, and receiving from him, a journalist's tax file number, details of Department of Social Security transactions concerning another person and the silent telephone number and address of a person from a source in Telecom Australia. I ask the Minister: Have the Australian Federal Police (AFP) investigated these claims? What action is the Government taking to prevent these gross abuses of personal privacy and to punish those who would appear to have broken Federal laws?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article in the West Australian of 4 March headed `Major corruption in PS: Informer'. Indeed, it does make the sorts of claims which were outlined by Senator Chaney. I think this whole chamber would be extremely concerned to ensure that allegations of corruption of such seriousness are pursued with vigour and expertise. Indeed, as I will indicate in a moment, that is the case.

ANSWER.PARA: In general I think it is important to say on behalf of the Government, and no doubt on behalf of the chamber which, during the passage of the tax file number legislation undertook concurrent privacy legislation, that any action of such an illegal kind, if it is proved to have occurred, must be condemned by the whole community not only because of the particular instance concerned but also because of the impact it has on the general public's perception of fairness and honesty in the dealings of public servants with very confidential information.

It was only this morning that I received a brief from the Deputy Commissioner, Operations, of the Australian Federal Police on this particular matter. Without detailing all parts, it is to the effect that on 3 March 1989 an informant, whom I will not name-an ex-investigator in Perth-approached the West Australian newspaper with information concerning allegations of corruption in the Perth Taxation Office and the Western Australian Police Department. On the same day he detailed his allegations to an AFP officer in the western region and made a number of allegations, which I will not outline.

The head of the Western Australia Police anti-corruption squad was briefed on the allegations, a joint operation was established and search warrants were executed on the premises of the former employer of the informant. A large quantity of documents and computer equipment was seized and evidence obtained, including tax microfiche. It is said that further documentary evidence is being looked at and the informant is continuing to assist police in their inquiries. In the last couple of minutes only I have been informed that a serving police officer in the Western Australian force has been charged and further developments may be expected in the very near future. So the investigation under way-as I say, a joint operation between the AFP and the Western Australia Police anti-corruption squad-is being undertaken with full devotion of necessary resources.

As to the particular allegations, obviously we need to wait to see whether they prove to be substantiated. But I understand the concern of Senator Chaney and indeed of all honourable senators that tax file number information in particular be protected. That is why this Parliament not only inserted very severe penalties in the tax file number legislation to deal with the unlawful disclosure of tax file number information, but also set up machinery in order to ensure that as far as is possible administrative safeguards are in place and management can be alerted to those situations which might develop where an official could be tempted and corrupted in the way that is suggested by these allegations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. Because of the concern which has been expressed in the community following the passage of the tax file number legislation after extensive amendment to it and the privacy legislation following extensive discussions between the Opposition and the Government, I ask the Minister: Will he examine this case and advise the Senate what reliance can be placed on the secrecy provisions in both the tax file number legislation and the social security legislation in light of what this case apparently discloses?

—I do not know that I can give an undertaking to the Senate to advise it on this case. I have already drawn the general principles that are involved from these allegations and I think they would be shared by honourable senators on all sides of the chamber. Naturally, when the facts are unravelled somewhat further, clearly the Australian Taxation Office and, if it proves to be the case, Social Security and other Federal agencies will be in a position where, having learnt the lessons from this instance, they can more specifically erect safeguards and barriers against any repetition.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Devereux Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to a report in today's Hobart Mercury which has as its headline `Noranda threatens to quit'. I ask the Minister whether he can clarify for the Senate whether the original guidelines for the establishment of the Wesley Vale pulp mill have been changed, given that the Tasmanian Government is insisting that no changes have occurred while in the article I have referred to Mr Zimmerman, the Chief Executive Officer of Noranda Forest Inc., clearly states:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . changes to the guidelines negotiated by the companies-Noranda and North Broken Hill . . . provided a `workable formula' to allow the mill to go ahead.
This comes on top of a recent statement in parliament by Mr Peter Rae, a State Government Minister, that changes have occurred to the original guidelines.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think anyone really believes that changes to the original guidelines did not occur. The fact is that only one Tasmanian Minister has been honest enough to say that they did-Mr Peter Rae, a former senator. Perhaps that is why he had the courage and integrity to stand up and say in the Tasmanian Parliament the other day that there had been changes. The boss of Noranda is now saying thatchanges--
—He said changes for the better, didn't he? Why don't you quote him properly?

—Noranda certainly believes that, from its point of view, these are changes for the better. I think Mr Zimmerman ought to be congratulated for at least coming out and, to some extent, dampening down this sham that some representatives of the company in Tasmania and the Tasmanian Government have been perpetrating.

ANSWER.PARA: Obviously the Government, in examining its decision on the mill in the next couple of weeks, has a predisposition towards supporting downstream processing and, hence, pulp mills. Obviously it must assess what environmental price we have to pay. In doing that and in looking at the guidelines which have been changed it is not very difficult to list changes. I want to refer to an article by Andrew Fisher in the Sunday Tasmanian dated 26 February, which is not an Australian Labor Party rag. He went through just some of the changes. Remember that the Tasmanian Government said that there had been no changes. Whilst Senator Puplick has said that I had better tell everybody that Peter Rae said there had been changes for the better, he said that after he had been prodded by his leader. Nonetheless, Mr Hodgman said that there had been no changes at all, and repeated that many times in a debate we had on Saturday.

As soon as we pick up the original guidelines we see that they state that Bass Strait had to be protected at all times. That has now been changed to `or after 12 months'. So, for 12 months, the company has a free rein to do anything it likes. The company had originally to use what was called `the best available control technology'. That has now been changed to `commercially proven and widely accepted technology'-a second change. Under the original guidelines, the mill was not to affect the receiving waters of Bass Strait. That now reads `receiving waters outside the mixing zone'-a third change.

Instead of implementing chlorine dioxide substitution to at least 40 per cent, the company must now simply have the plant capacity to do that. The company is not even being made to do so as it was under the original guidelines-another change. Under the original guidelines, if there was a pollution leak the company had to take immediate action. That now reads `as soon as practicable'-another change. If the pollution controls broke down for more than 30 minutes, the plant had to close. Under the new guidelines, it can continue running for a full day. There was to be no accumulation-that is pretty definite-of effluent on the sea bed. That now reads that `there should be no build-up that would cause material detriment'. The big change is the one concerning dioxin because from there being no detectable changes in background levels it is now defined as `no material detriment to the environment'. Background levels one can only define, as the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation scientist, Dr Hallegraft, said last week, as the quality of the water before the mill starts. Material detriment according to the Oxford Dictionary is `significant or important harm or damage'.

So, yes, there have been changes, not just some but many. There has been change after change. For Mr Hodgman to try to maintain that there is no change should not be a surprise. He said he would resign if there were changes. Obviously the job is more important to Mr Hodgman than the principle. So, he will stay, change or no change. Fortunately because of the Gray Government's handling, whether the mill goes ahead, that Government cannot survive and it will not stay.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I ask the Minister to withdraw that inference about a Minister in the Tasmanian Government.
—Order! I must say that I did not hear any inference against a Minister in the Tasmanian Government.
—I refer to his inference that the Minister cared for his job more than he did for the guidelines.
—I do not think there is a point of order.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. I refer to a report in last Wednesday's Australian that the Minister's Department is proposing that universities will have to abandon the principle of appointment on merit but will need to prove that they have been unable to find a `suitable Australian candidate to fill the position before an overseas appointee will be granted residency'. I ask the Minister: What is the present status of any such proposal from his Department? Surely, he, as Minister, is not proposing to support such a restriction. Why is it that our universities should no longer be able to appoint the best applicant on the ground of excellence? Finally, I ask the Minister whether he will confirm that he was a signatory to the 1982 Senate Committee report entitled Tenure for Academics in which both he and I and other Senate Committee members said:

QUESTION.PARA: Overseas competition is healthy for Australian higher education institutions.

Does he still adhere to that view and, therefore, will he resist any proposal from his Department and from academic trade unions that is not based on excellence or which compromises the long established recognition that our higher education institutions are part of an international community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not particularly changed my views on the question of tenure for academics. As Senator Teague will know, I had some doubts about tenure but I had more doubts about the witch-hunt that may follow if it was done away with. Nevertheless, one must recognise that academia has passed Senator Teague and me by. For the most part, wherever possible, they are going for fixed appointments. Therefore, if academics are only going for fixed appointments, some of the past immigration practices in this regard may no longer be relevant.

ANSWER.PARA: The main objective of my Department's proposals is to extend the existing special provisions for senior academics to fixed term appointments of at least three years. This reflects the growing emphasis on non-permanent appointments to achieve staffing flexibility in the period of significant reallocation of resources. The current special provisions apply only to permanent appointees. Fixed term appointees are considered under temporary resident requirements. On the advice of the Department of Employment, Education and Training, lecturers would no longer be included in the special provisions but would be subject to the normal employer nomination provisions. That reflects the need to give Australian graduates the opportunity to compete for entry level positions-that is, tutors and lecturers-without excluding overseas appointees when no local applicant is suitable.

By focusing solely on the problems with definitions of senior academics, I think that our position has been slightly misrepresented. The Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and the Australian Committee of Directors and Principals have undertaken to provide data on the number of overseas appointments at lecturer level to enable further consideration at this point of contention. In other words, the position is not final; we have put forward the general proposition. I have not really changed my mind on tenure. It is one of the methods by which proper academic excellence is protected. Also we had to recognise back in 1982 that there were problems in terms of flexibility. These days those problems are more intense than they were seven years ago. On the advice of another department, we have to react more flexibly. I do not see this move as particularly disadvantaging people overseas. The employer nomination scheme is basically the way. People are targeted to specific jobs from any other occupation. I do not know that academics are so special as to require a special category.

—The question had six points in all. I will seek to obtain an early answer for Senator McLean on the various matters raised. I can say something as to the fourth point. The honourable senator asked why the Minister has put off indefinitely visiting the reactor and speaking directly to the engineers involved. DEBATE.TITLE: THE WORKING OF THE PROTECTION OF MOVABLE CULTURAL HERITAGE ACT 1986 AND THE ADMINISTRATION OF THE NATIONAL CULTURAL HERITAGE FUND

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This report is very brief and very welcome. It is welcome because it indicates that after much time and effort and much delay the protection of our movable cultural heritage has moved one step forward. I well remember that this legislation was rushed through this chamber-we were told we were not allowed to amend it because it was a matter of such enormous urgency that it had to be completed-then waited for the best part of two years for its proclamation. This paper now reports the further development and production of the National Cultural Heritage Control List. This is an important development in Australian cultural policy, because it marks the first attempt systematically to provide a clear indication of what parts or items of Australia's movable cultural heritage can be exported from the country and then reimported, and under what terms and conditions.

The Movable Cultural Heritage Act was enacted to provide the legislative framework for establishing a system whereby we could have some control on works of art, cultural material and artefacts which might be taken out of the country. The development of that regime rested primarily with Dr Battersby, whom I take this opportunity to congratulate for the extremely fine job that she has done over many years in this field. It was then the responsibility of the Government to promulgate regulations to establish a list of items or categories of items which could or could not be removed from the country. Regulations made in 1987 and statutory rules made in July 1988 have given effect to this.

In the arts, the new system provides that works of art which exceed a specified market value may require export permits when they are more than 30 years old or when the original artist is no longer living. For example, with photography, which is classified in the regulations as a fine art, a marketable value of $7,000 could make the photographs subject to restrictions, while Australian paintings with values of more than $150,000 could require ministerial permits for export. Major works of art held in Australia but created elsewhere may also be restricted if they have been in this country for 35 years. That is similar to legislation which the British use to protect their own significant private collections, mainly from the predations of American collectors-although these days, I suspect, it is the predations of collectors with pockets stuffed full of yen who are more likely to be a threat to the continuation of those art collections. We know that in places like the United Kingdom and Canada similar legislation has been very important for the control and retention of their cultural heritage.

This legislation also provides a basis on which we can move forward to a formal ratification of the 1970 United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation protocol which deals with this matter, and will allow us to be more closely integrated into international arrangements whereby works of art can be returned to their country of origin. I am not a total fanatic about that. I happen to think that if the Elgin marbles had not been housed in the British Museum they would by now be in the same crumbling state that the rest of the facade of the Parthenon is, and the statues from the Erechtheum, which are hidden away under the Parthenon because they have almost crumbled into nothingness, are some indication that occasionally display in foreign museums may be of some value. Nevertheless, we know that in the Aboriginal communities there is concern about return of cultural material. There are occasional claims that there are even items in our own National Gallery which may or may not have arrived from Peru or elsewhere and which need to be examined within the framework of this piece of legislation.

Nevertheless, I very much welcome the report. I congratulate those who have been responsible for drawing up the various categories of items to be included in the class A schedule, which cannot be exported except with a certificate, and class B objects, which require an export permit or certificate of exemption. I look forward in future years to seeing the way in which this develops. It is a new development in terms of promulgation of these regulations. I believe that this is an important piece of legislation. The Opposition is very happy to support the operations of the legislation, and we look forward to the continued development of this very important initiative.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate now has before it the Australian Sports Commission Bill 1988. This is a Bill for an Act to establish a new Commonwealth statutory authority, to be called the Australian Sports Commission. Essentially, the Bill will merge the functions and administrations of the Australian Institute of Sport and the Australian Sports Commission, as they are presently constituted. This merger is claimed to be an integral part of the process of streamlining Commonwealth sports administration, to which this Government has apparently dedicated itself.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission is going to be permitted to operate under the name of the Australian Institute of Sport when performing certain of its functions. Although occasionally the term Australian Institute of Sport will be used, the Institute will not be a separate body, as is the current situation. It will operate entirely as part of the one statutory authority.

The Bill sets out the objectives, functions and powers of the Commission. Those functions are to be performed, in whole or in part, by the Commission under the name of the Australian Institute of Sport. The Bill also covers a wide range of issues relating to the management and operation of the Commission in much the same way as other statutory authorities are dealt with. Finally, the Bill defines the relationship between the Commission on the one hand, and the Government on the other, within which the Commission will undertake its respective tasks.

I indicate at the outset that the Opposition does not oppose this piece of legislation. However, I wish to make a number of remarks about sports policy and sports funding in Australia. I will also wander, with some care and trepidation, onto the issue of drugs in sport, without in any way compromising the inquiry currently being conducted by the Senate Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts into at least one aspect of this area.

The Australian Institute of Sport had its genesis in the period of the Fraser Administration. Mr Ellicott, the then Minister for Home Affairs and a very keen supporter of the establishment of the Institute, stressed that an emphasis should be given to both the encouragement and promotion of particularly talented sportsmen and women, who are sometimes referred to as the elite. He also sought to establish a body which would eventually decentralise its operations, thereby providing a greater degree of access to its programs, particularly its coaching programs, throughout the whole of Australia. Indeed, the Institute's decentralisation program has been one of the most valuable attributes of the development of sports policy in recent times.

Nevertheless, a couple of things need to be said about sports policy, and particularly about sports funding. First, this Bill has been with us for what appears to be an inordinately long period. I think the Bill has now been in the Parliament for nearly 19 to 20 months since it was introduced into the House of Representatives. It has certainly been around for a long time. It is very disappointing that the advantages that are claimed to flow from this initiative have been delayed for so long. It is also fair to say that some claims made by the Government, in terms of its expenditure in sport, do not altogether bear the closest of examination.

I refer honourable senators to the fact that some time ago the then Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Mr Brown, gave a commitment, on behalf of the Australian Labor Party, that funding for sport would be maintained in real terms in the 1987-88 Budget and in the subsequent Budget of 1988-89. In real terms, however, funding for sport has been squeezed. It has been kept at unreasonably low levels in a number of areas. For example, if one looks at page 202 of the 1988-89 Budget Statements, under the heading `Assistance to Sport' one sees that $30.3m was provided for assistance to sport in 1986-87; in 1987-88 $29.6m was provided; and in 1988-89 $27.1m was provided. Compared with last year's Budget, this constitutes a decline in total assistance of $2.4m or 8.3 per cent.

Senator Richardson, the current Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, says that there really has not been a decline in the level of funding for sport. He argues that one has to rope into this calculation an extra $6.32m, which will be spent on programs which he describes in a press release as `programs promoting healthier lifestyles, a wider community participation in sport, water safety, and a recreation assistance scheme for people with disabilities'. Although the Opposition does not have the slightest objection to the provision of assistance for any of these programs, I think some of the programs aimed at `promoting healthier lifestyles' are not exactly returning value for the Commonwealth dollar. Nevertheless, the claim which I believe most people in the sporting community were led to believe, that there would be a maintenance of expenditure on sports activities, has not been honoured by the Government.

An article in the Sun-Herald of 4 September 1988-just after last year's Budget was brought down-describes the President of the Confederation of Australian Sport, Mr Jim Barry, as being `bitterly disappointed' with the outcome of the Federal Budget. He had reason to be bitterly disappointed, because the claim that the Government was going to maintain its expenditure on sport in real terms, as distinct from maintaining its expenditure within the sport and recreation portfolio area, has not been lived up to by this Government in the way in which people were encouraged to believe it would be.

Although this nation makes enormous claims about sport and undoubtedly we are supposed to feel honoured to have one of the world's great sporting heroes as our Prime Minister-one defines a sportsman these days by the simple definition that he is the person standing next to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the photograph-the actual level of per capita expenditure in this country in terms of money spent in support of sporting activities is not high by international standards. For example, the amount of money spent per head of population in the United States of America, even excluding college, sports and corporate sponsorship, is $7.43. In West Germany, the figure is $6.77; in Italy, $4.64; in France, $6.48; in the Netherlands, $4.84; and in Canada, $3.12. In Switzerland, perhaps not known as one of the world's greatest sporting nations other than in certain winter sports, the figure is $13.84. I have deliberately not included any of the unreal comparisons with Eastern Europe. But if we put those figures against the figure in Australia of $2 per head we can see a reasonably comparative figure. I believe that money spent in support of sport is money well spent because it is not only spent in terms of activities which I think make a contribution to the health and well being of the nation--

TALK.START.PARA: —Did your figures take into account the federal system and other factors?

—Oh yes; my figures always take into account other factors of that sort. They are perfectly accurate figures and perfectly valid comparisons of money spent. For example, the United States, West Germany, Canada and Switzerland-countries which I have mentioned-are all federal states and the comparison is perfectly accurate in that regard. I am most grateful to the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) for the opportunity to make that point with even greater force. The point I was going on to make was that the money spent on sport is well spent, not only in terms of its contribution to lifestyle and indeed to healthier living, but also in terms of the enjoyment of individuals, the building of a sense of community, and the support of and assistance to voluntary organisations, which I think is in itself important.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been a number of instances in which one could be very critical of some of the operations of sporting bodies in this country, but I do not want to carp about those on this occasion. There is only one to which I wish to draw attention-I am sure that Senator Tate will be particularly interested in this-and that is the scandalous mucking around with the establishment of cycling facilities in Australia. We have had a world class velodrome available for the promotion of cycling, training and the practice requirements for Australian cyclists located in Launceston. That world class velodrome should have been the primary focus for cycling activity in Australia. It has not been. The reason for that-Senator Crowley, who will follow me shortly in this debate, undoubtedly will be interested in a different aspect of this from Senator Tate's interest-is that prior to the last South Australian State election an electoral bait was drawn across the trail promising that a cycling facility was to be established in Adelaide. That promise was made some two years ago by the South Australian State Government. It has just been reannounced for the third, fourth and fifth time that money is going to be spent in South Australia to duplicate a facility which exists in Launceston and which has not been properly used in Launceston because of an electoral commitment given between the Commonwealth and the State Labor parties in South Australia to have a facility built in Adelaide. Frankly, this sort of political decision made within the sporting community and within sports policy I think is most unfortunate and not conducive to the proper development of sports facilities and sports planning in Australia.

In October 1988 the Liberal and National parties released their sports policy. It is important that I put on record exactly what our policy is in relation to the Australian Sports Commission and the Australian Institute of Sport so that people are aware of the incoming government's policy in this area. Under the heading `Australian Institute of Sport', the policy states:
A Liberal/National Party Government will support the amalgamation of the Australian Institute of Sport with the Australian Sports Commission.
That is the purpose of the Bill before us today. I continue:
The AIS will be required to allocate more of its resources to coaching courses both in Canberra and at other venues around Australia.
The provision of adequate domestic and international travel to expose AIS scholarship holders to higher levels of competition will be emphasised under a Coalition Government.
The policy of decentralisation of accepted AIS sports to centres around Australia will be continued.
The Australian Institute of Sport will be required to establish performance levels to assist it in setting goals, and to act as a measure of its successes and failures.

We indicate that we will continue to support and encourage the Australian Sports Aid Foundation and, indeed, we will be looking for a greater degree of private sector sponsorship within sport. The policy has a number of other significant initiatives which will take us very much back to a position of national leadership, but not government direction, of Australian sport and sports policy in this country.

I turn to the final question that I said I wished to address, the question of drugs in sport. The pressure which is placed upon young athletes to compromise themselves by using drugs is now at a most extraordinary level. It is to the overwhelming credit of most young Australians that they are not seduced into this form of behaviour. It is a tragedy that young athletes like Darren Clarke who a few years ago were only fractions of seconds off world record pace in particular events now find themselves something like five metres off the pace. One cannot help but remark that to a very large extent it would be not unfair to say that that is in part because they have resisted, whereas others have succumbed to, the lure of using performance enhancing drugs in sporting activities. People like Clarke and others have played a prominent role in indicating the degree to which they will resist pressure by those who want them to use performance enhancing drugs and that is greatly to their credit, but I do not know the extent to which that capacity to resist is being progressively undermined by the philosophy of `win at any price' and the pressures which, right from the senior levels of government down, we all tend to put on people in the sports arena to achieve for Australia-waving flags, running television commercials and all the rest of it-with the implication that somehow almost any price is a good enough price to pay for success on the sporting field.

I said earlier that I think it is enormously to the credit of the overwhelming majority of Australian athletes and young people in particular that they resist this pressure. I have been concerned-I put it at that level at this stage-to read some of the material which has flowed from the public hearings of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, which has been investigating this matter. I do not want in any way to reflect on what that Committee is doing or to in any sense judge or pre-empt what it will say in its final report, but I believe that the way in which the hearings of that Committee have been reported has started to engender in the minds of most people who are simply casual readers of the press or observers of the media that somehow Australian sport is awash with drugs and that every participant in sporting activity in Australia at a certain level must be under suspicion of having some contact or some involvement with drugs and with the drug culture in sport. I do not believe that that is correct. I believe that the media has caused the reports of the Senate Committee to be dealt with in such a way as to reflect very adversely upon sports men and women throughout Australia.

The President of the Australian Olympic Federation, Mr Kevan Gosper, in February of this year wrote to Senator Black, the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, the Committee which is undertaking the investigation to which I have referred. Mr Gosper says in his letter, in part:
Widescale assertions of drug-taking are being made in a manner that besmirches the reputations of the AOF and the IOC, the AIS and the controlling bodies of the Olympic sporting disciplines.
It is a patent misrepresentation to assert, as was the case last week, that the AOF `gave six week's notice' of impending drug tests in the hope that no Australian sports people would be detected.
To imply official corruption in this way belies overwhelming evidence to the contrary that the majority of young sports people are not associated with drug-taking.
The facts speak for themselves:
15,000 athletes at the Seoul Olympic Games
260 events
600 drug tests
20 positive
10 dismissed on appeal
10 upheld
Further research has shown that fewer than three percent of athletes within the programme of Olympic disciplines tested positive.

Mr Gosper goes on to make the point that the Australian Olympic Federation has been one of the pioneering organisations in attempting to eliminate the use of drugs in sport. He seeks public acknowledgment of the policy of the Australian Olympic Federation and the work that it has done in seeking to eliminate drugs in sport. On behalf of the Opposition I want to record our public acknowledgment of the effort that people such as Mr Gosper and the Federation and the various organisations particularly concerned with amateur sport in this country have undertaken, as far as is practicable, to get rid of the use of drugs in sport. I think it ought to be placed on the public record that the overwhelming majority of sports administrators in this country are concerned about this problem and have been undertaking such actions as are available to them to combat the problem. I do not think their efforts should be left without being remarked upon when so much of the reporting in the media gives an entirely false impression of the overall situation as far as this country is concerned.

I am concerned equally about the importance of re-establishing in Australia a testing centre for drugs in sport inquiries which will meet Australian Olympic Committee standards. Madam Acting Deputy President, you will recall that in April 1987 the International Olympic Committee's Medical Commission revoked the accreditation of the Royal Brisbane Hospital to test for drugs in samples supplied by athletes both from Australia and from overseas. We have still not fully re-established within Australia an International Olympic Committee accredited facility for these tests. If my memory serves me correctly, they are currently being sent mainly to Cologne in order to be tested and the test results are returned to Australia. I do not think that is satisfactory. I know that the Government has taken some steps in this regard and I hope that the accreditation of a suitable facility in Australia will not be long delayed.

I wish to make one final comment on this matter. Even when one has tests and testing facilities, sometimes those tests are open to query as to their reliability. I do not intend to go into enormous detail regarding the case of Mr Alex Watson. However, I believe that the submissions that Mr Watson has made, backed up by some extremely important data from people such as Dr Maslen, a Western Australian expert on questions regarding caffeine and testing for caffeine, are of some considerable relevance because there are doubts about the validity of particular tests applied in relation to certain substances which are still not well understood in terms of their physiological and pharmacological effects upon the body. I do not seek to pronounce one way or the other, at this stage on the question of Mr Watson's position, other than to say that I hope that all the evidence will be properly assessed by the relevant authorities, both in terms of the international associations with which he is concerned and with the Pentathlon Union in Australia and at an international level. The facts speak for themselves. I hope that, at the end of the day, Mr Watson gets true justice, whatever the outcome of all those inquiries. In order to get true justice we must also have thoroughly reliable tests. I hope that the tests, both at the international level and the domestic level, will always be understood to be of the highest possible standard.

I conclude by saying once again that the Opposition supports this legislation. It believes that some significant issues have arisen in terms of Australian sports policy, Australian sports administration, and Australian sports funding. However, those are capable of being debated within the Budget context and within the context of individual cases, such as that which I have raised regarding the placing of cycling facilities in Australia. I believe that the amalgamation of the various parts of sports administration in the Australian Sports Commission, being established in its new form under this Bill, is a step in the right direction. To that extent the Opposition is prepared to indicate its support for this legislation and to wish it speedy passage but, as it has been in the Parliament for almost two years, I simply say that I wish it a speedy passage today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Australian Sports Commission Bill 1988, which, as Senator Puplick has said, will establish a new statutory authority-the Australian Sports Commission-which is essentially an amalgamation or a merging of the functions of the Australian Institute of Sport and the current Australian Sports Commission. As well, this legislation defines the objectives, the functions and the powers of that new body and spells out how it relates to the Government and to the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. In particular, the legislation makes clear-and the Government in this legislation wants to make clear-the new Commission's relationship with the Government. It is clear that the Commission will operate within the framework of an overall government objective and policy and, ultimately, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) will be able to require or guide the Commission to put into practice and effect the policies of the government of the day-at least as I understand it. I presume that Senator Puplick, in spelling out the Opposition's policy, does not really take issue with that point. He may be able to explain to me later, as I understood him to say at the end of his speech, why there seemed to be some requirement for the Commission to be independent of government. This legislation makes it clear that the Minister will determine the overall guidelines for the Commission, as established. I suppose that I can presume that, as Senator Puplick is agreeing with this legislation, he is not taking too much objection to that point.
