SPEECH.PARA: I chide Senator Puplick for chiding us about cost constraints and the restriction of moneys or the allocation of funding to the sports arena over the last few years. I think the Australian Sports Commission, the Department and the relevant Ministers need to be congratulated on continuing to achieve all the things they are achieving under the sports vote and, at the same time, being very mindful of the need for expenditure restraint. In some ways this legislation is one very effective way in which the Government has addressed the problem of reducing administrative costs by merging the functions of the various subsets under the sports ministry, achieving savings that have enabled the continuation of all the things we want to see happening under sports, and at the same time being very mindful of the need for cost constraint.

I find it amusing that, as ever, the Opposition, which somehow believes in no government expenditure, comes into this chamber and criticises the restraint practised by this Government and, even worse, criticises the Government for not maintaining real funding. This Government is very aware of the importance of economic constraint. It has achieved a very effective ongoing program in the sports area and, at the same time, a very responsible management of sports expenditure. Even the changes to the administration which this legislation further enshrines add to the gains or the financial good management by reducing some of the expenditure. I ask Senator Puplick whether the Opposition's policy says that the Opposition will maintain government funding in real terms under the sports policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. We will only give commitments that we can honour.

—That will be a point for another debate. Senator Puplick seems to dispute Senator Richardson's claims that the Opposition has to take into account another $6.3m under the sports development program and has to take off the gains made by a reduction in expenditure. We are pleased to see that the Opposition has a policy that is very similar to the Government's policy in the sports area.

SPEECH.PARA: It was mischievous of Senator Puplick to suggest that Adelaidians do not cycle as well as Launcestonians. I do not believe that the decentralisation policy meant that there should be one national facility in the country, wherever it is put if it is to be taken out of Canberra. If one has a look one will find that there are international standard facilities in more than one place around this country. Cycling has been very extensively fought for and supported by the South Australian Government and by any number of people committed to the cycling sport in that State. I will not cite all of the heroes who have cycled with such success in South Australia but when this cycling facility is completed in South Australia I am sure we will see an extension of the benefits and the opportunities that are offered to Australians to develop their cycling skills.

The existence of the cricket academy in South Australia does not mean that this is the only place where one can learn cricket at that kind of level or that it is confined to that place. Nor does it mean that facilities are not to be developed in other places. What we have to support-and I strongly support it-is the intention to make these excellent international facilities available to Australians with the aim of decentralisation. While it is sometimes advantageous for people to come to the Institute of Sport and use its excellent facilities, clearly that is not possible for many Australians for much of the time. So some balance is achieved by taking some of the specialist facilities away from the capital. Sometimes we reverse that by bringing teams there, particularly prior to significant events, so they can use the facilities at the Australian Institute of Sport. No doubt there will always be continuing debate about the best balance between those two services. At the moment, the Government fairly clearly wants to make its sporting facilities available to as many people in the community as possible.

A couple of other achievements under this Government and the Australian Sports Commission are well worthy of recall. In particular I recall the emphasis of the Government to provide as much support as possible for broad community participation. I do not believe we should overlook Aussie Sports which, to this point, has been established for nearly three years. Well over 1,700 primary schools and over 500,000 children are now enjoying the benefits of that program. That is something that is sometimes overlooked but the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) deserves considerable congratulations for that achievement. Early participation in sport and recreation to the point where it may become the expectation of people that sport and recreation are a normal part of living, hopefully will establish that practice. Hopefully, that expectation will be carried on through secondary school and into adult life.

It is a matter of concern to me and to a number of others that so far that pattern has not been established to the point where girls maintain their participation in sport and recreation during secondary school years as much as do boys. Any number of research documents continues to show that that is the case. While I know that there are thousands of young women around Australia participating in sport and recreation, the numbers are not maintained as highly as they are at the primary school level. It is a matter that the Government continues to address. We take very seriously the point that Senator Puplick made earlier about the benefits of health and fitness to the community if its members participate in sport and recreation.

Not too long ago, when I launched at a function in South Australia a community video about women in sport, Senator Richardson said, on behalf of the Government, that there are about 1.5 million women registered in the various sports which have a registration component. The Government aims to see that number tripled to 4 1/2 million by the year 2000. That is a very good, simple goal. There are many more women whom we want to see actively registered as participants in sport and recreation in all its varieties around this country.

I would like to make some comments about the drugs in sport campaign. I spoke recently at a Sports Medicine of Australia Foundation dinner at the New South Wales branch. There are some points that we should make about the drugs in sport debate. In some ways there are two very diverse attitudes in the community about drugs in sports. One is an instinctive repugnance. People say, `They're cheating. It's not fair. How dare they', and so on. It was best captured, I suppose, by a splendid article in the Age the day after Ben Johnson lost his gold medal. That article commenced with the words, `Say it isn't true, Ben'. I suspect that that was an attitude many of us had. In other words, `Please, you, who seem to have been so absolutely splendid and great, do not tell us you have done it by cheating and using drugs'. It seems that that was the case. There was a sense of disappointment and repugnance at the use of drugs by sports people, particularly at the elite level. On the other hand, there is a broad community acceptance. People say, `So what? Everyone is doing it. If I don't, how can I compete? It's not fair. It's making a mockery of it. Everyone does it, so what's the harm?'. The challenge for the inquiry, and certainly for the Sport Commission in its national drug program, is to come to terms with those two very diverse opinions in the community.

One of the things we should do is practise some restraint. It would be better for us to hasten slowly in this area and wait until we have some substantial data on which to begin to form our opinions. For example, what is a drug in the expression `drugs in sport'. I do not believe we have a clear definition of what is called a drug for the purposes of this debate. In the past, I have spoken to people about this. One example that comes to mind is that of a man who used to ride 50- and 100-mile bike races in England. I suspect that anybody who rides in 50-mile races, let alone 100-mile races, is probably so remote from my experience that I would have nothing in common with him. But at one stage he was relating to me how taking a drink of water during a race was regarded as dishonourable, the behaviour of a cad; only a cheat did it. Until very recently, people who ran the marathon were regarded suspiciously if they took a sip of water in the course of that 26 mile-plus run. Even water was regarded as unacceptable. It was regarded almost in the nature of an aid to a person trying to compete in those events. The 50- and 100-mile cyclists also told me that when some sports people were discovered to have flasks of tea or coffee to sip along the way they were also frowned upon. They were not struck off, but it was considered not to be the proper way to behave.

What we have seen is the development over time of what is regarded as appropriate behaviour by sports people. For example, these days it is regarded as inappropriate for a person running a marathon to do so without taking adequate fluids throughout the course of the run. I met some heroes of the old order as they lay twitching and unconscious at the end of a marathon in the resuscitation tents of various cities-heroes who knew that a real man did not sip water. These people had to be hydrated with intravenous water or a saline drip when they got to the end of the race. Mostly they managed to make it to the end before they collapsed, which was very timely, I suppose. But that notion is now frowned on; it is very foolish. The attitude of the community would say that it would be foolish in the extreme not to take adequate fluid and sustenance and prepare properly if one is going into that kind of endurance race. We must realise that there has been an historical change. There has been an emerging understanding of what is an appropriate level of fitness and what is an appropriate level of proper, wholesome healthy body response to such strain and stress as athletes put on their bodies.

In the drug debate we need a clear definition of what a drug is. We must also ask whether it is ever possible or proper to use drugs. For example, is an athlete who has a headache unable to take pain killers if it is coming up to the time of a race? I do not think that anyone would say that that is the case. On the other hand, perhaps pain killers will help a person endure the stress or strain for which he might strive in achievement. Maybe that comes under the definition of drugs. Maybe it is about what one can use by way of medication or assistance within a certain number of hours of a performance. I think I read in a newspaper recently that Ben Johnson is supposed to have used drugs within 21 days of his run. So what is the appropriate time before an event, let alone after an event, in which a person may take medication?

Are these drugs medications? If they are medications, ought they to be prescribed only by a doctor? I take Senator Puplick's point that we urge a caution as to the validity of reports on this. I do not know whether they are true. However, I am concerned when I read about non-medical people passing out steroids by the handful saying, `Just knock a few of these down', because steroids are serious medications. We do not even know the concentration of the chemical or the significant active ingredient in the tablets. As a medical person, I am quite horrified at that casual practice in the allocation of medications and chemicals to people. It is very worrying. I do not want to be understood to be saying here that doctors only should prescribe drugs in sport. However, if after seriously addressing this question, it were judged that some medications were appropriate sometimes, we must look at who is the appropriate person to administer those drugs. I do not see why a drug for a fit athlete is too different from a drug for a sick person. We need to be responsible about the stringent requirements that go with the administration of medications to healthy people as well as to unwell people.

I think that the best thing to do in the drugs in sport area is to wait for the report from the Senate committee. Maybe the very best we can do is to wait until that considered response by a committee that is taking a large number of submissions provides us with, I hope, some of the data that I have alluded to as necessary and with information on many of the other questions that I have not had time to refer to today. It is time to be somewhat restrained; it is time to look for some hard facts, proper data and definitions. It is also important to look at how those two attitudes that I have mentioned-that is, on the one hand, a repugnance by people to those who use drugs in sport and, on the other, a broad acceptance-might be resolved. Through it all I think that we should have a considerable regard, if not respect, for the athletes, particularly those trying to reach international levels of excellence. They are under considerable strain and pressure to achieve and to win at all costs. From that we may conclude that we need to redefine what is at the base of our sporting philosophy.

Talking of winning at all costs leads me to another point that I want to raise briefly, and that is violence in sport. The report of the National Committee on Violence by Professor Chappell was released recently. I was interested to find that Professor Chappell not only covered domestic violence-violence against our children, and so on-but also mentioned violence on our sporting fields. I suppose, reading from page one, Professor Chappell probably did not tell me how to think about it, but I gathered that he was not in favour of violence in sport. If that is not what Professor Chappell said, I suggest that that is all I can conclude from page one.

However, being a good sportsperson, I also turned to the back pages and there I saw the hero who coaches the team in Queensland that has Warwick Capper playing for it. Capper had been clobbered, bitten or thumped three times in the one match by his own colleague. `Oh', said the man in charge of that team, `That's really nothing. It just shows the boys are really serious'. `Whoops', one could almost hear him thinking, `As long as they don't take this violence off the field it'll be all right'. I had a funny feeling that page one and the back page were contradicting each other in a very significant way and I also had a feeling that Warwick Capper might have had a slightly different view about violence on the football field too, let alone anybody else who has collected a very good elbow as he has run past.

I raised the question of violence in sport at the national sports medicine meeting. I was interested to find that many people at that meeting were at pains to tell me that sport would not be sport if it were not violent. I thought, `Oh, no, back to page one'. Very often sport is excellent, superb sport without violence. It is the development of the skill, the challenge, the balance and the finesse that is the excitement of sport. It is not just whether a person can drop three of the opposition and not get caught, or whatever else it is that our heroes get up to in the name of exciting body contact.

I was delighted to see that some of the football codes are introducing changes to their rules of practice so as to ensure that players do not suffer grievous injury. I would not mind at all-this is not a recommendation that I would insist anyone follow-if we had the rule that put people off the field for five minutes to cool down. That would be a jolly good thing. If a person got caught thumping someone, he would have to go over the back of the fence and wait for five minutes. Thus his team would play at a disadvantage. While that is not bad in practice, it does not seem to stop the ice hockey players who forever come back to the field just to enjoy another five minutes off the field. But I will not talk about ice hockey.

I find it very interesting to consider what it is about violence in sport that seems to get people agitated, although they have not quite become violent about it. It seems that some people push strongly for violence in sport as a good thing. Again, it may be that what we have to do is to make clearer what we mean by violence in sport. I think that the gratuitous whack, thump, kick, trip-anything of that sort-which is clearly outside the rules of the sport and is quite likely to injure the other contestant ought not be encouraged. I find the enormous following for golf quite interesting. One could hardly use violence in golf, a sport with an enormous following, although the golf ball might speak differently. Tennis, skiing and lots of sports enjoy huge participation and television audiences, or even live spectator audiences, and would not by any definition be called violent. I find it quite interesting that some people suggest the changes in our cricket from test matches to one-day matches have done little more than encourage, if not violence, at least some kind of Mexican wave and banana throwing among the crowd, and that that is a move towards violence. Perhaps I am straying a little too far from the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would have us playing water ballet instead of real sport.

—I would not have thought that Senator Tate would be the pro-violent sort! Let him go and play good cricket. Don Bradman probably never clobbered anybody. On the whole, cricketers do not resort to violence; it is skill, timing and balance-all those lovely things-that make for great sport. I do not think that we do have to do water ballet. Senator Tate's comment was quite a curious one and I disagree with it. However, I can say that he is in good company, or at least in large company. Going back to my comments on drugs in sport, it may be time to redefine the philosophy of sport: where is sport going? What is meant by sport in terms of a government's or a nation's commitment to it? What is our commitment to sport?

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that there are people who would actually encourage violence in sport. I am not urging that we do away with tough, rigorous playing, but I certainly would not want to encourage violence in sport any more than honourable senators would want to encourage the use of drugs in sport. We have to appreciate that violence and drugs have another thing in common, that is, the dollar. The investment of large amounts of dollars in sport means that sometimes the nature of the sport is determined by the persons paying, rather than by the persons playing.

All those involved in sport-the sports people, the sports administration and, in particular, the Australian Sports Commission-have a challenge to make clear some of these questions and the philosophical underpinning of sport in this country, which I think is changing considerably. Evidence of that is the establishment under the Australian Sports Commission of the Women's Sports Promotion Unit. When I conducted the inquiry on women and sport for the Government we had a considerable battle to persuade people that women's sport was worthy of the same kind of recognition by government and sponsors as men's sport receives. Since that report was tabled in 1985 the climate for women's sport in this country has considerably changed. If that reflects a changed community attitude that allows more diversity, and more tolerance, of a wider variety of women's sport, then I can only congratulate the people involved. Certainly, I believe that both Ministers for sport-in particular, the former Minister, Mr John Brown, who launched the Women's Sports Promotion Unit in December, 14 months or so ago-and the Sports Commission, in its support and commitment to the Women's Sports Promotion Unit, reflect the importance and acceptance of the participation of women in sport. I believe that we are getting excellent value for our sporting dollar from the Women's Sports Promotion Unit, chaired by Margaret Pewtress.

The debates I alluded to, in terms of the philosophical underpinning of sport, concern things that the women in sport are tackling. Certainly they were raised with us during the inquiry on women's sport. We were told that women's sport is Mickey Mouse and that nobody would want to watch it because it is all milksoppy stuff. Clearly those people have never watched a good netball match. While we had to address that question, the conclusion of our report was that, essentially, it is up to the participants in sport to determine the nature of their sport-not only the active players, but also the coaches, the trainers, the people in the administration and the infrastructure behind, or involved immediately with, the sport. With the formulation of the views on sport by the participants, the Sports Commission would have even further information to go on.

In 1986 the Australian Sports Commission published a strategic plan for 1986-87 to 1988-89 in which many of these questions were tackled, or at least were appreciated as being important to address. In our Australian Sports Commission we have a comprehensive organisation which is already tackling many of these issues. But, like everything in this world, new issues have emerged. The issue that I think is particularly high on the agenda at the moment is the question of drugs in sport, notwithstanding that there is a national policy to deal with drugs in sport under the Australian Sports Commission. Clearly that debate now has a new dimension. In the not too distant future we may have to address the question of violence in sport.

The economic issues associated with sport cannot be overlooked, not only the cost to government through the allocation of its public dollar but also the cost and/or the benefits to the corporate sector and sponsors in the area I am interested in-that is, women's sport. The considerable increase in the sponsorship dollar for women's sport and the increased media coverage are partly a recognition of the fact that many people in this country spend lots of money on sport and recreation, whether attending as spectators or participating and buying the necessary equipment. The Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has produced some excellent reports, not the least of which is entitled Technical Paper No. 1-The Economic Impact of Sport and Recreation, Household Expenditure. This report takes us to another area of analysis under the sports heading that is useful and fruitful. The recognition of the economic contribution of sport and recreation, both within the community and beyond, in terms of export potential, is something we cannot overlook.

To the extent that my comments have been allowed under this legislation, I am pleased to have been able to put them on the record. This is useful legislation, in large part because it rationalises even further, and brings together, the services that the Sports Commission, the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and the Australian Institute of Sport provide to the Australian community. I commend the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Sports Commission Bill 1988 is designed to streamline the implementation of Government policy on sport in Australia by bringing under the control of the new Australian Sports Commission activities which were previously the responsibility of its predecessor of the same name, the Australian Institute of Sport and the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism. The Australian Democrats support this Bill. It is most interesting to note that we appear to have tripartisan agreement on a number of issues with regard to this legislation. Perhaps sport is the great conciliator.

SPEECH.PARA: However, in commending the Bill to the Senate I want to draw attention to a number of issues which are of concern to the Australian Democrats and which we believe should receive the attention of the Australian Sports Commission. The first of these issues is the distinction between what are generally referred to as elite sports and community sport. It is widely accepted that Australians are extremely interested in sport and that Australian performers who can achieve top level performance in national and international competition receive an extremely large amount of attention. To some extent, we are inclined to define our standing in the world community by our successes and failures in the arenas of international competition. Indeed, one major catalyst for the creation of the Commission and the Australian Institute of Sport was a perceived decline in Australia's sporting reputation as measured by our Olympic gold medal counts and defeats in international sporting events.

It is the opinion of the Democrats that far too much attention is being paid to elite sports compared with that paid to participatory sport. In that respect, it is pleasing to see that one of the functions of the new Commission is to develop and implement programs that promote equality of access to and participation in sport by all Australians. The Australian Democrats advocate that the Australian Sports Commission be encouraged by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) to place a very heavy emphasis on the development of community sports.

Whilst it is true that the achievements of top class performers can inspire others in the community to emulate their performance and dedication, too much attention to elite sport can have some very destructive effects. In the first place, the impression can be given that only the world class performers have any value or deserve any recognition. This impression may deter people, particularly young Australians, from participating in sport. I believe that this phenomenon is already evident in some high schools, where small numbers of students, under intensive coaching, are achieving even higher standards of performance. But increasing numbers are dropping out of participation in sport. I believe that this is because those who drop out are given the impression that inability to achieve high levels of performance is synonymous with failure. The Aussie Sports program is certainly doing a great job to rectify this situation.

Secondly, the emphasis on top performance, competition and winning has deteriorated into an attitude which sees winning at any cost to be desirable. That issue has already been debated here. This can result, in some sports, in increasing violence. I believe that broad concern about violence in our community, which has often been expressed in this place and, indeed, has been expressed today during this debate, must recognise that the promotion, tolerance and sometimes even glorification of violence in sport inevitably promotes the impression that violence is appropriate in other spheres of human activity. Some body contact sports are approaching the stage where actions which are tolerated during the course of the game would, if they were to occur on the street, result in assault charges leading to convictions and even to lengthy prison sentences.

Senator Crowley raised the matter of the National Committee on Violence. In its first report there is a whole section on violence in sport. In fact, that report states the issues that Professor Duncan Chappell believes should be discussed while the Committee is receiving its evidence. I also draw to the Senate's attention the case of a well known football team being shown Rambo movies before going out to play a game. The Australian Democrats believe that the new Commission should tackle this matter of violence in sport and also tackle the overemphasis on winning at all costs, which can breed violence.

Another result of an undesirable emphasis on winning at all costs is the use of drugs in sport to enhance performance. Certainly, this is another issue which has received plenty of attention in this place and during this debate. I believe it will inevitably be a major concern of the new Commission. The costs of drug usage are enormous. They include the likely damage to the health of participants, the undermining of the concepts of fair competition, the cost of monitoring and detection, and the extraordinary frustration of athletes who do not resort to drug taking and who, after enormous dedication and training, find themselves defeated by inferior or less dedicated athletes who have taken drugs. The Australian Democrats certainly believe that the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, which is inquiring into the use by Australian sports men and women of performance enhancing drugs, should be commended on the way in which it is conducting its inquiry. It is unfortunate that it has been criticised unduly and too early in the course of its inquiry.

The last undesirable outcome of the win at all costs mentality is the totally unbalanced commitment to excessive training which can result when national prestige is made dependent on the performance of athletes and sports contestants. In recent years we have seen examples of absolutely extraordinary performances by teenage gymnasts and swimmers in international competition. While filled with admiration for their almost incredible levels of performance, many Australians must wonder whether the lives of these young performers may not have been rendered miserable through the extremes of the demands placed upon them. Certainly, it is possible that under such conditions young people can become victims rather than happy proponents of sport. The Australian Democrats believe that the Australian Sports Commission should accept responsibility for monitoring the degrees of pressure and the training regimens which are proposed for young contestants. Certainly, we do not want our young people to be pressured into obsessive levels of involvement and training which can make their lives a misery.

I would like now to express grave disquiet on behalf of the Australian Democrats at the prospect of the Bruce Stadium, which was constructed some years ago for the use of the Australian Institute of Sport, at this stage being turned over to the Canberra Raiders and lost to concerns such as Little Athletics and the more general Canberra community use. It seems to be a classic case of precisely the direction in which we should not be moving-that is, of handing over to commercial sport a facility which is intended for participation sport. For this and other reasons the Democrats believe that the trend to ever greater emphasis on elite sport, and media coverage of it, needs to be reversed in favour of energetic promotion of community sport, because of the health, recreational and social advantages of community sport. For example, we should not assess our prowess as a nation on the issue of whether a lone Australian is the holder of a world record for running, but rather on the percentage of Australians of all ages who run regularly and enjoy a high level of physical fitness. Distance runner Sebastian Coe summed it up when he said, `I'd rather see 50,000 people taking part in a fun run than one person running a four-minute mile'.

It is on community sport or sport at the level of participation that the emphasis of the Australian Sports Commission should fall. It is widely accepted that we are an unhealthy community with low levels of physical fitness. There have been a number of reports which have suggested that levels of fitness for younger Australians, particularly teenagers, have been falling rather than improving over the years. Assessments are that a high proportion of the maladies which afflict us are related to our lifestyles and that failure to engage in exercise and physical recreation is a major factor resulting in ill health. Over the past 15 years health care costs in Australia have trebled. Consequently, enormous benefits will accrue to our society from increased participation in community sport and increased levels of fitness. It should be borne in mind that the types of sport which promote health and fitness generally do not require enormously expensive facilities such as are commonly required for elite sport.

One of the encouraging and exciting developments over recent years has been the increase in participation in many types of sport by groups who were not formerly very active. I refer in particular to women, people with disabilities and senior citizens. It is not very long ago, as Senator Crowley said, that women were effectively debarred or energetically discouraged from participating in very many forms of sport. Discouragement and subtle forms of discrimination still exist, but a great deal of progress is being made in making participation available to women. As a result, women's levels of performance are improving very rapidly in many areas. These improvements are occurring at a much more rapid rate than that which applies to male performances, and it is apparent that women athletes will achieve parity in many fields within a very few years. The old myth that women are inferior to men in terms of strength and endurance is now becoming `an old myth'. More recent evidence suggests that women may indeed be innately superior to men in these areas and that in fields such as long distance running and the marathon women's performances are set to surpass those of male athletes. Ken Dyer, in his book Challenging the Men: Women in Sport, states:
In the Olympics . . . most women's sports were introduced well after they were introduced for men . . .

. . . anomalies are quite glaring. For example, there is no women's cycling in the Olympics or any other games despite its being a very popular women's sport in which world championships have been organized since 1958. Worldwide, field hockey is as popular among women as it is among men. It has been a men's Olympic sport since 1908 but was not on the women's programme until Moscow 1980. There is no example of what is primarily a women's sport, such as netball, being on any major games programme.
He goes on to state:
In aerobic events in which they compete, women have attained virtual equality with men. This assertion is based on the following facts . . .
I would like to quote just a few of them:

Women have completed a majority of the ten fastest swims across the English Channel and their dominance has been particularly marked in the last three years. They also hold all the records for swimming the Catalina Channel of California. These events involve eight or nine hours' swimming.
Women have held the fastest times for the fifty mile swim-
that is, Greta Anderson-
and the fifty mile run (Natalie Cullimore) in the 1970s.
Marathon swimmer Diana Nyad became the first person to swim from the Bahamas to Florida on 20 August 1979. She swam the eighty-nine mile distance in 27 hours 38 minutes.

TALK.START.PARA: —You might be winning the women's votes, but you are losing the men's!
—I thought the honourable senator might find these facts interesting. The book continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Women are now consistently achieving times in the marathon . . . of under 2 hours 40 minutes. With such times they can confidently expect a placing in the top 5 per cent or so of male finishers in even the strongest events.
Women hold the fastest times for all roller skating events of 25,000 metres and over.
And finally:
Women are now swimming 800 metres, their longest Olympic distance, in times not achieved by men until the early 1970s.

These developments are beginning to affect in very positive ways women's perceptions of themselves and will promote progress towards equal participating in all aspects of society. Further, the changes are making the enjoyment of active participation in sport in many areas-as participants, officials and administrators-available to more and more women. The Australian Democrats trust that the Commission will energetically pursue the goal of promoting participation in sport by women. Earlier, the pattern in Australia was for people to engage energetically in sport during childhood and early adulthood, but thereafter for active involvement to decline rapidly and for the vast majority to become spectators rather than participants. More recently, the values of participation in physical activity in adulthood and on into old age have been increasingly recognised. The `Life. Be In It' campaign made a contribution here. It is therefore very encouraging to note that participating in appropriate sport and physical activity by senior citizens is also very much on the increase. As a result many will experience vastly improved health and quality of life.

The Australian Sports Commission has played a restricted role in the development of veterans' sport, which unfortunately has been restricted by staff ceilings and availability of program funds. Nevertheless, a great deal remains to be done. Currently only about 35 per cent of adult men and 27 per cent of adult women, according to a 1986 Health Commission report, take any exercise. According to the National Heart Foundation, only about 10 per cent take regular exercise as defined by the Foundation. People with disabilities have been unnecessarily deprived of the opportunity to participate in sport, but enormous efforts have been made by disabled people and those with their interests at heart to turn this situation around, and with great success. The Australian Sports Commission has played a leadership role in this area in the last few years. I wish to quote from the February-March edition of Aussie Sports News 1989 and draw the Senate's attention to an article headed `Aussie Sports and integration of disabled students'. The article reads:

In 1987 Malkara Special School, ACT, for children with intellectual disability and St Peter & Paul's School developed an integrated Aussie Sports program. Since that time the program has developed and expanded with great benefits to all children physically, socially and emotionally. The community were also involved, with coaching being provided by a number of sporting associations.
Aussie Sports with its emphasis on enjoyment, development of skills and participation in a variety of modified sports is ideally suited for integration.

I hope that there will be further participation by people with disabilities, both adults and children, in the sports area. Certainly a lot still remains to be done, but it is in areas such as these, by taking the initiative and setting the pace, that community participation in sport can develop.

I am concerned that under this legislation the Minister is responsible for all appointments and that control is very much from the top down, as Senator Crowley mentioned. Millions of Australians are involved in sport and they have voluntarily combined into thousands of organisations in order to promote and regulate the activities of their sports. The Democrats would prefer to see more provision for direct input by these grassroots practitioners into the management of the Australian Sports Federation. They, after all, are the people who understand the needs of sport in this country and they are interested most in amateur and community sports of the types the Democrats believe the Commission should foster.

In closing, I wish to place on record that the Australian Democrats recommend that the Australian Sports Commission give its major emphasis to community and participation sports; that it continue and develop its excellent initiatives in the fields of children's sport, women's participation, veterans' sport, and sport for the disabled; that provision be made for strong input into the Commission's management and planning functions by the grassroots Australian sporting community and by its representative organisations; and that the Bruce Stadium be retained for the use of the Australian Sports Foundation for athletics, little athletics and for general Canberra community use and not be handed over to commercial interests. The Australian Democrats wish the new Australian Sports Commission well and commend this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Australian Sports Commission Bill 1988, I shall be brief and restrict my remarks to one essential area, namely, the use of banned substances in sport for the purpose of enhancing performance. Since I am the deputy chairman of a committee that is inquiring into that matter, I do not wish to impinge on any deliberations of that committee, but wish to make some general comments which I believe are essential for the Government to consider not only in terms of elite sports, but right through the range of juvenile sport and levels of sport below those of elite standards. These are matters which, in my view, have to be addressed not only by officials and athletes, but by society as a whole, and presumably with the Government giving some lead in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: There are enormous pressures, as my colleague Senator Puplick said, on athletes in Australia at all levels to compete well. There is enormous social pressure, pressure through the media, family pressure, pressure from sponsors, coaches and from those who organise the meets. It is not unkind to say that we in Australian society are not very good at expressing empathy or sympathy for losers. We love winners, but at best failed athletes returning to the shores of Australia, having competed in world championships or in the Olympic Games, will get nothing but perhaps a nod of the head and polite applause. They will receive no recognition for their endeavours, attempts, contributions, or for trying, or for the sacrifices that go with their participation in sport.

Perhaps it is the inferiority complex that affects most of us that leads us to enjoy basking in the reflected glory of success. We feel uncomfortable when we stand alongside somebody who at an international level did not win gold, silver or bronze. Society in its own way puts great pressure on athletes to win. The athlete knows how much it means to everybody else for an athlete to succeed. That is demonstrated by the way in which we conduct ourselves when we watch, for instance, the Olympic Games and the way in which we conduct ourselves on the return of our athletes. We have motorcades for the gold medal winners, but those who perhaps may have broken an Australian record and performed at a greater level than they have ever before achieved but who do not win gold are allowed quietly to go off to their friends and relations for little more than sympathy. It happens after every Olympics. It happens at government level and at the level of ordinary Australians, and that is the attitude that is taken.

The media do not help. They write headlines about a kid who is competing, who has never been within 10 seconds of a world record, but who is thought to have a chance. In that way the media create a hype, an atmosphere, that these young people can succeed. But even if they do their very best, it will not put them in reach of a world record, yet the media write in those terms. The reputations of the coaches and officials ride on the performance of the athletes, at least to their minds and those of their peers and colleagues. We have seen coaches bathe in the reflected glory of a successful athlete whom they take credit for delivering almost from birth to the winning post. That, in itself, puts enormous pressure on athletes. Anyone who has attended a sporting competition for juveniles, for example, little athletics, would have seen the vigour and energy demonstrated by parents on the sideline. Poor old Billy dare not fail, if he is not to get six of the best when he gets home for not being the best. From day one extraordinary pressure is put on our athletes.

We need to consider the enormous rewards and gains to be made by athletes who succeed. The financial rewards for the organisers of meets, sponsors and the media are great. Winning athletes are of advantage to them, so enormous pressure is put upon the athletes, who are given great incentives to succeed. Knowing that the difference between gold and failure, glory and loss, a million dollars and nothing, is perhaps a second or part of a second, who would not be tempted to take under supervision in moderate, controlled doses an anabolic steriod for short periods, like everybody else with whom the athletes line up? They would hardly be human if they were not tempted.

Senator Puplick referred to Darren Clarke who, if my memory serves me correctly, came fourth in the 400-metre final at the Seoul Olympics. My guess is that Darren Clarke is probably the fastest drug free 400-metre runner in the world. But he did not come home with gold. He did not come home with enormous endorsements. He was not driven in the back of a motor car down the main street of his home town, being cheered and clapped and met by the Lord Mayor. He did not receive that sort of reward as an acknowledgment for his being clean, for his resisting the temptation to take drugs, despite his knowing when he gets into the blocks that there is a prospect that everybody who beats him is cheating. Is there not a temptation for him to do what is the norm? The answer is that of course that temptation is there. I am not saying that everybody against whom he has competed used a performance enhancing drug. Darren Clarke, like everybody else, would know that many people who finish ahead of him in his chosen sport are highly likely to have used a performance enhancing drug.
I was disturbed when I read the letter of the President of the Australian Olympic Federation, Mr Gosper. The letter was referred to in a different way by Senator Puplick. Mr Gosper said:
Let's not lose sight of the fact that the real solution to the problem of performance-enhancing drug-taking rests with the athletes who countenance the drug-taking.

That is a stupid, naive and poorly judged comment that does nothing for Mr Gosper's reputation or that of the Australian Olympic Federation. With those words, he seeks to sheet home all the blame to athletes who countenance drug taking. Surely it rests with coaches, officials, families, governments-which involve themselves in sport these days-and society generally.

Senator Puplick read out a paragraph of Mr Gosper's letter in respect of the six weeks notice of impending drug tests given by the Australian Olympic Federation. I do not suggest, nor have I heard anybody else suggest, as Mr Gosper says, that it implies official corruption. I do not believe it does. But whenever an athlete is told that he has six weeks before he will be tested, we can be certain that unless he is an absolute idiot the results of such testing will be negative. The athlete would certainly have got himself off the `gear', as it is called. We all have a responsibility to understand the enormous pressure to which the athletes are subjected.

We need to understand that if Australia were able to introduce a regime of regular and random testing for illegal substances-the daily work of chemists around the world would seem to indicate that it is not possible-there would be the prospect that a whole generation of Australian athletes would be disqualified or eliminated from world competition. The problem could be overcome only if we could satisfy ourselves that there was an effective method of detecting these substances and if the system introduced in Australia were introduced by every other nation that competes in international sporting competitions.

An enormous amount of money and energy is being used to ensure that the testing procedures will fail. It has been discovered that the drug probenecid has been used primarily to mask anabolic steroids. It has the effect of holding in the liver about 99 per cent of the anabolic steroid after what is outside it is flushed out through using a diuretic. It has been suggested that the drug has been in use since 1981, but only in recent times has it been detected. That makes me wonder what masking substances are presently being used to hide the use of banned substances. At the end of the day, although the integrity of the testing that takes place at competitions such as the Seoul Olympics might not be open to question, the effectiveness of such testing can be questioned. These days, all sorts of methods are used to cheat the testing procedure. It is becoming more common, for instance, to use urine substitution. A male athlete, for example, has somebody else's urine inserted through his penis. Of course, the urine is clean and the test says that the athlete's urine is clean. All sorts of other methods are used to ensure that the testing does not give a positive result.

Society, officials such as Mr Gosper, the Government, and other bodies that are funded with taxpayers' money ought to ask themselves about the underlying philosophic reason for banning certain substances. I think Senator Crowley touched upon that subject. We have to remember that the only drugs which are presently banned are the ones which can be detected. That is logical, because if one could not test the drug, how would one ever know whether it was being used? If one did not know it was being used, what would be the point of banning it? The only exception to that situation is blood doping and there are now suggestions that that can perhaps be detected. As Senator Puplick mentioned earlier, the only two substances which have a qualitative definition are alcohol and caffeine.

If we are to address the whole problem of drugs in sport, we ought to ask ourselves the question: why are we opposed to the use of performance-enhancing drugs in sport? Is it because we are concerned about the health of the athletes; is it because we wish to ensure that each athlete competes on an even playing field; or is it because we have a primeval instinct that man should compete `in the raw' without additional help--

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly don't agree with that.
—The Greeks did.

—Yes, with modest exceptions. Is it simply that we want to see the extent, or the extremity, of man's and woman's ability in the field of sport? If we are concerned about athletes' health, what would be our attitude if it were possible to manufacture a drug which enhanced performance but was of no risk to health? Would we say that that was reasonable? If, for instance-and this is a bad example-it were possible to manufacture an anabolic steroid that had no short, medium, or long term effect, but provided muscle mass and the other qualities which enhance performance, would we ban that product? If so, why would we do so? Clearly, this would have nothing to do with our concern and anxiety for the health of athletes. Is it that we believe in what has been described by others as an even playing field? Is it that we want to make sure every athlete competes under the same circumstances and is given the same opportunities, so that when all athletes line up at the starting blocks they are actually running the same distance?

SPEECH.PARA: Some people would say that we ought to ensure there is an even playing field. Frankly, we do not presently have an even playing field. One hears of African swimmers practising in hotel spas. Would anyone seriously put to me that athletes from deprived countries, such as the Sudan or Yemen-perhaps Ethiopia would be a bad example-are on an even playing field with the athletes of East Germany, or West Germany, or the United States? Of course they are not in terms of diet, training conditions, sports medicine or equipment. They do not have the same capacity to train without needing to seek employment or to travel around the world and compete in international events. Surely, nobody is seriously suggesting there is an even playing field at present. But nobody is complaining. Nobody is suggesting that every athlete ought to have the same chance in his training. It is claimed that athletes only have the same chance when they have finished their training and are in the blocks for the final. I believe that those who put that view are hypocritical unless they are prepared to ensure that there is an even playing field.

My final proposition is this: Is it a fact that we are concerned to ensure that present-day human beings compete without any form of artificial assistance? If that were the case, one would have to question the difference between an anabolic steroid and a vitamin B12 injection, or any other form of nutrition, food supplement or dietary process which would not constitute the normal daily regime of an athlete. I do not believe that a line can now be drawn to separate natural raw ability and artificial assistance.

Those are the questions which I believe have to be properly addressed. I do not believe they have been. It is not good enough for us simply to say that a certain thing is wrong, because society itself has not made up its mind why it is wrong. I do not believe that these questions have been addressed by the Government; I do not believe that they have been addressed by senior sporting officials who should have been thinking about these issues two generations ago; nor do I believe they have been considered by the community at large. Until one considers these matters, one faces great difficulty in addressing the fundamental and underlying problems.

The sad fact is that, in the medium term, there is very little prospect of ensuring that athletes will compete purely on natural ability. Let me give another example of what one might describe as an artificial aid. It has been suggested that the West Germans insert gas through the rectum of their swimmers in order to give them better flotation or buoyancy. Does that process constitute an external aid? Is the athlete in that case swimming on his own ability? Is that a perfectly acceptable situation?

I recall that in the last Olympics at Seoul the Australians designed and developed new swimming gear, which apparently was purported by our fair-minded competitors to give us an advantage. Senator Richardson will correct me if I am wrong, but I believe the swimming gear was banned because it could not be demonstrated that it would not give us an unfair advantage. Therefore, I assume that, if every single swimmer used our swimwear in the future it would be all right. So one is left pondering what is fair and what is unfair; what is cheating and what is not cheating.

I conclude by saying that, in my view, we are a long way from solving these problems. We will not do ourselves any favours by imagining that the problem rests simply with athletes. The drugs being used are not simply anabolic steroids. They also include diuretics, beta blocks, narcotics and stimulants. We are talking about a whole range of products which have different effects, ranging from helping pistol shooters to helping marathon runners, high jumpers or basketball players. Until we come to grips with these fundamental issues, the problems shall not be solved. I hope that those who are a part of the Australian Sports Commission will address those questions which are, in my view, of a philosophic nature and look past getting us from fourth to first. Sadly, Australians are ambitious to bathe in the reflected glory of success, which is the very reason the Australian Institute of Sport was developed in the first place. It started in 1977. If my memory serves me correctly, it was because we were not satisfied with our performance in the Olympics in 1976. I remember one of our athletes-he was a swimmer; I shall not name him-who came back having competed and come third. He smashed his previous record.

TALK.START.PARA: —And was treated disgracefully.

—Yes. He was a world record holder, he smashed his previous record, but only scored third on that occasion. When he got off the aeroplane he was asked why he had failed. We wonder why athletes are tempted to take a performance enhancing substance of some sort when they are treated like that by Australian officials, Australian coaches and Australian society. As I say, that is why we have the Institute. It was not good enough for Australia to perform the way it did in 1976, so it decided to use taxpayers' money, with their full support and endorsement, I believe, as is still the case, to establish an institute of that nature to enhance our performance. Let us hope that we get past that stage-it is an intrinsic part of being involved in elite sports these days-address some of these other questions, and ensure that Australia plays its part and has proper and fairer sport internationally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In summing up the second reading debate on the Australian Sports Commission Bill I will not take up a great deal of time or attempt to answer all the points raised, not all of which are entirely relevant to the Bill. However, lest there be any misconceptions in Senator Puplick's or anyone else's mind, the decision taken to locate cycling in Adelaide had naught to do with promises for any election, but everything to do with topography and climate. The reality was that the national body of cycling wanted Adelaide, campaigned for Adelaide and, in the end, got Adelaide. That is why this facility is in Adelaide. There is no other reason.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of elite sport versus more general participation, if one looks at the record one will see that the Australian Sports Commission has achieved a good balance with the funds available to it. It is certainly its intention, and mine as Minister, to ensure that that balance is continued. As all honourable senators will be aware, I am in the process of preparing a submission on the future of Australian sport which will involve even more taxpayers' money but will also involve considerable sums from the private sector. Again, in that submission I am ensuring that the balance between elite sport and participation will continue. There has never been any thought in my mind to try to concentrate all effort on elite sport. The health of Australia will be dependent upon participation in sports generally and we have to attempt to raise that participation level. I would have thought that the Aussie Sports program already has provided a tremendous boost for the future by encouraging many children to participate in a whole variety of sports that previously they would not have dreamt of. I think we are succeeding and certainly trying in that regard.

In terms of sports medicine and its relevance to community health generally, part of that submission will certainly be including an expanded sports medicine component. It is not just a matter of looking at how to cure a pulled hamstring faster than is done at the moment, but rather how to relate research into the health of athletes to preventive medicine generally. I regard that as particularly important and hope to be successful in securing more funds for a study of it.

That, of course, leads to the discussion at the moment on drugs and how the Australian Sports Commission ought to react to drugs in sport. I have been careful over the last few months to say very little about the issue because it is before the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. I have been at pains not to attempt to pre-empt the Committee's findings. So to some extent I will limit my remarks on the question, although honourable senators may be assured that I will have plenty to say about it once the Committee has reported. Nonetheless, it seems clear now that the Olympic movement worldwide will strengthen and tighten its rules regarding drug testing. There is no question that between now and the Olympics in Barcelona the Olympic movement will exert its influence worldwide. I detect on its part a determination to make sure that the scandals which marred an otherwise very successful Olympic Games in Seoul are not repeated. The revelations of Ben Johnson's coach in Canada-from memory, his name is Francis-during the past 10 days are quite remarkable. They show a systematic use of performance enhancing drugs over a very long period, not just by Ben Johnson but by a number of other very prominent Canadian athletes. One can only speculate as to how widespread that usage has been. Certainly there are grave suspicions that it has spread to a number of countries.

We are asked by Senator Crichton-Browne-in my view rightly-to consider our aim. Is it to have a level playing field or are we concerned about health? I said once before in the Senate that there is nothing wrong with being concerned about the level playing field. We are after all not at the Olympics trying to determine who is the cleverest chemist or the cleverest doctor; we are trying to determine who is the best athlete. I worry that if we simply go down the path of saying, `Drugs are okay; we will let you inject yourself with these drugs', at the end of the day we will find out who is the cleverest chemist. I think I would rather discover that in a laboratory than on the track.

Having said that, it is also true, obviously, of steroids in particular, that there are very serious medical health consequences for athletes who have been taking them. The Australian Institute of Sport has an enviable record in making sure that its athletes are kept away from such substances. But certainly any submission that I put up to the Cabinet in regard to the future of Australian sport will focus upon the need for random testing. In Australia there must be a greatly increased program of random testing. The efforts of the past have not been adequate. They have certainly been adequate by world standards, but they will not be adequate by the standards that the world will set in the next four years. I want Australia to be in front of those standards and not behind them.

As to level playing fields and Senator Crichton-Browne's remarks about what is essentially the developed world as against the Third World, clearly it is not going to be possible to make everyone exactly equal. To use another analogy, I certainly do not intend to put forward a program under which we snatch children from their homes at the age of five and throw them into some sports prison where we indoctrinate them and train them so that by the time they are 13 years old they win gold medals and by the time they are 18 years of age they have breakdowns. That ought not to be the aim of any program in this country; nonetheless, there are countries which do that, there are countries which have taken our attitude, and there are the Third World countries. Mind you, the Third World countries have not been all that unsuccessful. The records of the Kenyans and the Ethiopians in comparatively recent times in the Olympics have been spectacular. They have done very well indeed, particularly in track and field events. I do not see why that trend cannot continue. However, obviously they are not going to have the same advantages even as athletes in Australia with the facilities that are available to them. While we cannot make the playing field exactly level, it ought not to be the case that we pick simply the cleverest chemist. I hope we never get to that stage. I will resist the temptation to comment further on Bruce Stadium. I think we have done that to death around this place by now, and I am more than satisfied with what the Government has done.

I turn to the real purpose of the Bill for a minute, so that someone at some point says something relevant to the actual Bill. Already it is obvious from the actions of the Australian Institute of Sport and the Australian Sports Commission, which have been running as a combined entity, that that has worked well, and produced economies, despite the fact that it has been difficult to pass this Bill through the Senate due to the pressure of business. Previously we have always had the possibility of one focus going towards elite sport, leaving the more participatory nature of the role of the Sports Commission somewhat in the shade. I think that has been removed by this combination. I really believe that this amalgamation will make sure that, in the future, we will not have the concern that Senator Jenkins has mentioned. I give Senator Jenkins and the Senate an undertaking that, as Minister, I will make sure that that balance is maintained and improved.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
