TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberal and National parties do not oppose the Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill 1988. However, in the committee stage several amendments will be moved and we will be seeking to oppose particular clauses of the Bill that will enable the Government virtually to ban real estate purchase in urban areas of Australia. At the outset, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate condemns the Government for its failed economic policies which have resulted in:
(a) Australia's increasing dependence on foreign investment;
(b) a continuing balance of payments crisis and associated foreign debt problems;
(c) high domestic interest rates adversely affecting all Australians; and
(d) record levels of taxation which are heavily biased against the ability of Australians to save''.

This amendment draws attention to the Government's failure in its economic policies. Of course, that lays Australia open to any kind of predatory investment that may emanate from overseas. We do not oppose the second reading of the Bill. The amendment spells out very clearly the crisis this country has reached under the economic policies of the Hawke-Keating Government. I will return to that theme a little later.

At present I just want to observe that, because of the constant need to borrow or to sell assets and receive the proceeds from the sales of those assets, $1,500m is required every month just to keep the country going. That is an indication of the depth of our difficulty. Of course, this is expressed most clearly by our total debt, which has now accumulated to more than $125,000m. As I have said, that figure is growing to the tune of $1,500m a month. The crisis that we face in this country is of enormous proportions. Of course, the danger and the tragedy is that there appears to be no end to it because the Government simply does not have the policies to address it. As a result, debt levels in this country are growing out of all proportion.

Let me turn, firstly, to that part of the Bill that seeks to regulate the purchase by foreigners of urban real estate in this country. We have to cast our minds back to September 1987, when the Government, through the Treasurer, Mr Keating, made a statement claiming that it was about to introduce legislation to give effect to the control of urban real estate. It was a knee-jerk reaction to a perception that foreigners were buying up real estate in this country. Of course, we should just remember that in September 1987 the Premier of New South Wales was Mr Barrie Unsworth and he was fighting for his political life in the last few months of his tragic regime. In fact, he was being helped out extensively by Mr Keating, who perceived that there was a need to somehow generate some kind of image in New South Wales that housing prices were all the fault of foreigners and not the fault of either the State Government or the Federal Government. It was a knee-jerk reaction to a politically motivated need to shore up the fortunes of the Premier of New South Wales at that time.

Six months later Mr Unsworth was out of government, out of the premiership and disappeared without a trace onto the back benches of the New South Wales State Parliament. That was the central reason for the Treasurer moving in the way that he did in September 1987 to implement this virtual ban on the purchase by foreigners of urban real estate in this country. He did it without any kind of analysis as to the proportion of urban real estate in this country owned by foreigners; he had absolutely no idea. In fact, he produced no evidence whatsoever of the degree of involvement of foreigners in land purchases in this country. It was simply a political knee-jerk reaction. One can typify that only as unbounded hypocrisy showing the arrogance of the man and also, I believe, his lack of intellectual honesty in bringing this matter forward. I will return to that point about honesty a little later.

Just to be certain that we know what we are talking about, I mentioned earlier that no hard evidence was produced by the Treasurer to indicate that foreign investment had pushed up house prices. I wish to quote from a report of a press conference held on 27 September 1987, when the Treasurer announced this new measure. The report in the Australian Financial Review of 30 September 1987 states:
The weakness of the Government's position was the lack of hard evidence.

At his press conference yesterday, Mr Keating could provide no facts and figures to back his decision. Nor could officials produce them later. The Treasurer admitted the evidence the Government did have, that foreign money was distorting the urban residential markets was `inconclusive'.
The report in the Australian Financial Review goes on to state:
He conceded that the Government relied heavily on `anecdotal' evidence.

Obviously that press conference clearly made the point that the Government had no real reason for introducing this measure in the first place. I guess that shows because, nearly 18 months on since the matter was first raised, the legislation is now just being discussed in the Senate.
Let me go on to deal with a few other points. A journalist at the press conference which I just mentioned asked the Treasurer a question on the relevance of the measure. He asked:
Do you have any figures Mr Keating to show just what level of buying has been done by foreigners in residential real estate and what it's done to prices for the overall view?
The Treasurer's answer was no. A further question was asked:
What was the Government's assessment about the possibility of future capital inflow in these sort of residential areas . . .
The Treasurer's answer was:
Well we had not made such an assessment . . .

Obviously what we have here is a total denial of any responsibility on the part of the Government to justify its actions. Quite clearly, this measure is based on political imperatives and, as I said, basically was designed to ensure that the then Premier of New South Wales had some chance of winning a New South Wales State election which, of course, he subsequently lost.

One other strand in the thinking to try to save Mr Unsworth at the time was that urban real estate and residential house prices in Sydney were going through the roof and that prices were being driven up by the pressure of money coming in through foreign investment.

I answer that claim by quoting a statement by Mr Robert Bevan, the President of the Real Estate Institute of New South Wales. He was absolutely astounded by the action that the Government took. Mr Bevan said:

It is a decision taken for purely political reasons to support the fallacious argument that foreign investors in the $1m plus residential market are making it hard for first-home buyers in the $80,000 to $90,000 market. If there were any way the REI could be convinced that stopping foreigners from buying into the upper end residential market would stop the price spiral in the mid to lower end residential market we would applaud the Government's move.

Of course, that is the point. People who were investing from overseas-if there were a great number-from all the evidence available and from the Treasurer's own admission, which is anecdotal, appeared to be investing in expensive real estate. The fact was that there was very little movement due to the pressure of money from that source on lower to middle level property prices. That is the key point. Most people do not live in million dollar homes. They live in the cheaper ones around the median level of under $100,000, even in Sydney.

The conclusion is clear. The Government was totally politically motivated in setting down this measure. We will be opposing in the committee stage those clauses in the Bill which seek to implement controls over residential real estate. That is consistent with the Liberal and National parties' position. We have been exposing this issue since this policy was first announced in September 1987. We will also be moving some amendments in the committee stage which seek to alleviate the most onerous conditions imposed on trustees by this legislation. We will also be seeking clarification from the Government of its intentions with regard to the establishment of regulations under the legislation which will have the effect of controlling further the activities of people in the foreign investment area.

We should turn now to the need for foreign investment in this country. I do not think anybody in this Parliament would deny that this country requires, needs and demands more investment by foreigners who bring their technology, ideas and capital in order to stimulate job opportunities in Australia. We should welcome that on that basis. But the truth is that foreign investment is not progressing all that well in those areas. What we are seeing is mostly, if I may so characterise it, hot money. The reason why it is of the hot money variety is that many Australian businessmen and entrepreneurs tend to invest overseas rather than within this country.

Why do they do that? The reason they are taking their productive investments to countries such as Thailand, the Philippines, Korea, the United States of America and to other places is that, because of the returns they deem that they can obtain from their capital investments will be better placed in those countries. If the economy of this country were being run properly, we would find there would be no incentive for those businessmen to invest overseas. They would obviously prefer to invest in their home country if they could get a return equal to or better than the returns they get from overseas. They would then tend to place their money in this country. But, because of the Hawke-Keating Government's mismanagement, we see that there are not the returns available for that kind of investment in this country. Therefore they tend to invest offshore.

This has a twofold effect. The first is that the amount of money that would otherwise be available for development of our industries is reduced because it finds its way into other investments. Secondly, not only to replace that money but, indeed, to find other money to meet our bills every month, we have to bring in money from the overseas marketplace. That money is in the order of a couple of billion dollars a month. It is the sort of hot money which finds its way washing around the world, taking advantage of high interest rates and the currency fluctuations in order to earn short term profit. What a way to run a country! In order to finance our consumption-that is, what we spend every day in order to keep Australians employed and for them to buy goods in the supermarket-we are relying on attracting money from overseas on a short term basis which is highly dependent on the maintenance of a fluctuating exchange rate and/or a high interest rate. Of course, everybody in this country knows that the Hawke-Keating Government has deliberately brought interest rates to the highest level in history so as to make sure that we can attract that money from overseas. If we did not have those high interest rates, the dollar would collapse. As a result, we would be in an extraordinarily difficult position.

This is a conscious policy of the Government and it does not deny it. No-one denies it. While we have such a heavy problem with our overseas balance of payments position, interest rates by definition will remain high. This is a real tragedy for this nation. We face a situation where the Government has led us into a deeper morass of higher interest rates and a growing debt which does not seem to be falling at all but rather to be growing.

We have listened to the Government's assertions about the way it is running the economy. It says, `We are all on track. All you have to do is trust us'. Just how arrogant are these spokesmen of the Hawke-Keating Government? Where is their concern for the individual Australians who have to compete in the marketplace for money for their housing, for their businesses and to buy their cars at the kinds of interest rate levels that we see in the country? What is needed on the part of this Government is leadership. What this Government fails to offer the Australian people is a leadership style that allows people to believe that the Government's direction is the right one.

We hear the rhetoric of free enterprise being espoused by the Government, but we know that it does not believe it; its heart is not in it; it shows no commitment. We see higher and higher taxes in this country. The Hawke Government is the highest taxing government in Australia's history. Yet still we run further and further into debt; government debt grows higher than ever. We see more and more regulations by the Government in the control of the economy. We see a total lack of action in the area known as micro-economic reform.

Where, for instance, are the Government's efforts in tackling the waterfront mess-the huge mess that has been made over many years and that it vowed it would tackle but has failed to do so? We know that the waterfront mess is one of the chief economic difficulties for our exporters and importers and adds significantly to the costs of manufacture and to the cost to the Australian consumer of goods and services. No action is taken because the Government is faced with having to shape up to the trade union movement, its political master.

The Government has failed to take action to privatise organisations such as Qantas Airways. We saw the Government's piddling effort to try to shore up Telecom Australia and other agencies in the telecommunications industry owned by the Government and to ensure that they were put in a monopoly position ahead of any very moderate deregulation that the Government might have contemplated. There has been a total failure to recognise that one of Australia's great opportunities in the future is to develop the telecommunications industry in this part of the world and to become a dominant leader and competitor in that industry. There has been a total failure to recognise the job opportunities for future Australians in that area. While the Government maintains its present stance of taking no action to deregulate the industry, we will see the maintenance of this kind of stultifying approach to industrial development.

True leadership by this Government would have positive results. It would recognise, for instance, the qualities of the Australian people; it would give encouragement at the proper levels for people to improve their skills; it would provide incentive for them to work harder and also improve themselves; and it would galvanise Australians into striving to improve their education and family circumstances generally. This Government should be saluting individual workers.

On the contrary, the Government, through its accord with the trade union movement, sends all the wrong messages to individual workers and persons striving to improve their circumstances in this country. There is no incentive for effort. All we are doing through the accord is rewarding people on the same level and not endeavouring to reward excellence. We are not rewarding people who are contributing to a greater extent than others. The system does not encourage people to try harder. That is the resounding failure of the accord and why we have led ourselves into a false dawn of hope about the state of the economy since this Government came to power.

May I turn to a speech made by Sir Arvi Parbo in Adelaide a week or two ago which highlighted, I think, the very difficult circumstances in which individual Australians find themselves. He spoke about our basic need being for better performance and went on to say:

This includes working harder, but it means more than that. It means improving our skills, removing artificial obstacles to the efficient functioning of the economy and, above all, developing a community attitude which supports and applauds achievement. It means encouraging, not discouraging, the natural desire of individuals to improve themselves.

I believe that that is a most succinct expression of the problem that this country faces and how we can best draw ourselves out of the mire that the Government has brought us to. We need to have individuals seeking to improve themselves. The Government's leadership in that is critical. We need to transform Australia into a performance oriented society, and that requires a major change in our current mentality. Obviously the Government, rather than seeking to lead us out of that mentality, reinforces it through its current economic policies. I quote again from Sir Arvi Parbo's speech:

Superior performance is not achieved by governments, the industry, the unions or any other part of the machinery; it is achieved by individuals. The advantages we have as a country do not entitle us to anything; on the contrary, they represent an obligation to make full and wise use of these advantages.

That is the critical issue that the Government fails to grasp. It needs to show leadership to individuals and to take them out of the mire which has been created by the Government's policies. By contrast, key policies will address those problems if they are the kinds of policies that have been adopted by the Liberal and National parties. In the area of industrial relations, we stand for a deregulation of the labour market so as to allow individual enterprises to make arrangements with their employees so that all parties benefit and so that individual workers' earnings can be improved by productivity improvement on the part of the whole firm.

People should be rewarded for their efforts, for their striving for excellence. That is the policy that this country needs at this time. That policy is supported by the Confederation of Australian Industry, the National Farmers Federation, the Business Council of Australia and many other organisations. We are even seeing in some parts of the trade union movement a glimmer of hope that this will be the kind of policy adopted. Charlie Fitzgibbon, one famous example, is quoted quite often. It is that reward for effort through enterprise arrangements that is the critical key to the development of our future economic policy and turning this country around so that we can start to repay the huge Labor Party debt that will be inherited by the next Howard government-and it sounds as though that will not be too long. That change must occur--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha, ha!
—I believe that the Government is going in September.
—You are not going to win with Howard there.

—Well, my boy, we have the policies. This Government's policies are on display. Everybody has seen how they have failed. The Government will leave a legacy-not in credit but in debit-of $140 billion or more. That will be the Government's legacy. We will have to pick it up and correct it. Our outlook for the future is positive. Obviously the Government does not have any intention of changing its mode. That has already been stated by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).

SPEECH.PARA: The kind of leadership the Australian work force requires must provide incentives by ensuring that the tax system is fair and must reward effort. We should remember the words of Sir Arvi Parbo which I have just quoted. Our superior performance has to be achieved by individuals. This Government needs to recognise that it is only by individual incentive that we will achieve superior performance. Of course, we know full well that it will not do so because it is locked into its narrow thinking, as it was when it first announced this proposition for the control of real estate in September 1987. It was motivated then by political considerations. Whatever the Government might be going to do with regard to taxation cuts in July of this year, it will again be motivated by political considerations and not by considerations which are of the most fundamental importance to the Australian people. Critical issues need correction in this country, but it looks as though we will have to wait until the election for that to occur. The pressure which Australian families are suffering under this Government will drive the people to vote for change in the months ahead.

We have seen new taxes under this Government: the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax, the entertainment tax, the foreign tax credits system, the lump sum superannuation tax, the assets test on pensions, the new and higher company tax rates, the petrol excise which has gone up from 6c a litre to 22c a litre, the wine tax, the intermediate and new oil tax, the gold tax and the graduate tax. There are plenty more. They are the kinds of things this Government is doing to suppress the incentive of the Australian people.

I return to my basic theme: foreign investment has turned into a dirty word. This Government knows that it has to have foreign investment in whatever form it comes to us from sources overseas just so that we can pay the bills every month. Now it seeks to constrict the amount of investment in particular areas because it has not been able to solve the basic problems of the economy. We will be opposing certain clauses of this Bill and moving several amendments at the committee stage. I urge all honourable senators to support the Opposition's second reading amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not at all sure what Qantas Airways Ltd and Telecom Australia have to do with the Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill 1988, unless Senator Messner is planning on selling Qantas to Japan Air Lines and Telecom to Nippon Telephone and Telegraph. His enthusiasm for foreign ownership indicates that maybe he will. I certainly have no idea what waterfront industrial relations practices have to do with this legislation either, although Senator Messner seems to think there is some connection, however tenuous. What we are debating is the question of foreign takeovers and, specifically, the foreign takeover of Australia which is, of course, increasing rather than decreasing.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill before us makes a number of amendments, in accordance with announcements made over a period of years-in 1985, again in April 1987 and September 1987-that in some areas make it more difficult for foreign investors to purchase Australian assets and resources and in some areas make it a lot simpler; so it will be harder in some areas and easier in others. In any event, the Bill goes only a small part of the way towards assuaging the concerns that many Australians have about the amount of foreign ownership of companies and of land in Australia.

To its very great shame and to the detriment of future generations of Australians, I suggest that this Government is continuing to liberalise the foreign investment guidelines instead of tightening them, as many Australians would like to see happen. Unfortunately, as we have just heard in those parts of Senator Messner's speech which actually touched on the topic this evening, it would appear that there is a considerable amount of bipartisan agreement in this area. The starting point might be different but the end point is the same, that is, encourage as much foreign investment in Australia as possible and never mind the consequences that will inevitably result from selling off the farm and, for that matter, any other bit of Australia that anybody wants to buy.

This Bill continues the trend that we have seen developing over decades in this country, encouraged particularly under Menzies, then Fraser and now the Hawke Labor Government. The legislation seeks to amend the principal Act to exempt from Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) scrutiny companies and businesses where the total assets involved are less than $5m for urban businesses and less than $3m for rural land. If the Opposition is to be believed, under its regime the Foreign Investment Review Board would not have any scrutiny role at all because there would be no Foreign Investment Review Board to look at any purchases under any circumstances.

The Bill seeks to amend, as I said, the principal Act to allow the Foreign Investment Review Board to scrutinise only acquisitions by foreign investors in Australian urban real estate. It makes no inroads in respect of the current rash of foreign ownership of Australian rural land or of Australian industries. In spite of the restrictions that have been in operation since they were announced in 1987, the latest FIRB report shows that real estate, rather than manufacturing in the services area, is still the major target for overseas investors, and why not? To them it is a give-away. Australian prices are considerably lower than those in Japan and in many other countries. For those overseas investors, an investment in Australian real estate, whether urban or rural, is petty cash in comparison with what they would have to expend for something similar in their own countries. So we have seen a burgeoning amount of foreign investment in these areas.

In 1987-88, $9.7 billion was invested in real estate, compared with $5.2 billion in manufacturing. This was up considerably from the 1986-87 values of $5.2 billion invested in real estate and $3.9 billion in the manufacturing sector. So more and more Australian real estate continues to be sold to foreign investors, primarily because the Foreign Investment Review Board is approving, willy-nilly, investment proposals for real estate which is commercial or undeveloped and only putting restrictions on foreign residents who buy or wish to buy developed real estate. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) himself admitted in his second reading speech, while the Bill provides for the notification and examination of foreign purchases of all forms of urban real estate, both commercial and residential, the relatively liberal approach to approvals in cases other than developed residential real estate is to be maintained. If that is not a signal to anybody overseas with any spare cash to come wandering into this country and spend it as if there was no tomorrow, I do not know what is. It is an assurance to foreign investors that the `relatively liberal approach to approvals in cases other than developed residential real estate is to be maintained'. `Come and get it!' is essentially what the Treasurer is saying to residents of other countries who want to buy up Australian property.

The Australian Democrats' position on this matter is well known and clear. We will certainly support the Government's amendments to this legislation which aim to prevent foreign investors from buying Australian residential real estate without FIRB approval. We will support this measure because it is long overdue and very necessary. We will support it on the grounds that, although it does not go far enough, it goes some way towards stopping the tragedy that is occurring in this country as we aim to sell off as much as possible to offset our other problems. However, we will be moving amendments in respect of other areas of the legislation. We will be moving to delete the $5m threshold for purchases by foreign persons of urban businesses and the $3m threshold for rural land. We believe that the FIRB ought to scrutinise all foreign investment proposals, not just those above the two amounts in those two areas.

We will also be moving to establish a public register of foreign corporations which own or control major Australian properties and other assets. If we get the support of the Government or the Opposition in this place, that register will be available for public inspection. I think it is outrageous-and my concern is shared by many ordinary Australians-that the public has no idea of who owns what in this country or to what extent and most of us very much doubt whether even the Government has much idea. The people of Australia simply do not know how much of their country is in foreign hands; how much of Australia has been sold, leased, loaned, mortgaged or simply given away. I think we are entitled to know those details. A register of foreign ownership will begin to give us the answers. The government of the day, whether it is the current Government or some future government with a Liberal leader, may still be able to sell off the farm, since I presume that the major political parties will happily collude on this issue for years to come. But, at least Australians will be aware-and they should be-of how much is sold and who is buying it.

Concern about the level of foreign ownership is not something on which the Australian Democrats have some sort of monopoly. Concern has also been expressed by the National Party in Queensland and by the Australian Labor Party in Queensland. The Queensland Labor Party has called for a tax on foreigners who own land in Queensland but live overseas. The National Party Government in Queensland introduced the Foreign Ownership of Land Register Bill (Queensland) on 19 October 1988 although, as far as I am aware, that legislation is still not operational. In addition, the Liberal Premier of Tasmania announced in July last year that he, too, would be moving to establish a register of foreign land ownership in Tasmania. I would like the South Australian Government to take a leaf out of the books of these two States since, as those of us who are South Australian residents are aware, the State Government sold off on a lease-back arrangement the Torrens Island power station to foreign investors whose identity is still being concealed by the South Australian Government, despite pressure from within and outside the State Parliament to get some idea of who now owns the major producer and supplier of electricity in South Australia.

The simple fact of the matter is that Australians cannot determine what sort of foreign ownership problem exists until a register of foreign investments is established. Only then will we know which Australian assets are controlled by foreign interests and which States, regions and industries have a foreign ownership problem. On this basis, further action can then be taken when necessary to restrict and reduce that foreign ownership.

As I said earlier, the foreign investment history in Australia is one of increasing dependency on that foreign investment. The Menzies Government, the Fraser Government and the Hawke Government have all unquestionably welcomed foreign investment, claiming it to be of automatic benefit to the country-that is, when they are not claiming it has to be done in order to offset some other difficulty that exists here. In the past they have placed minimal restrictions on foreign investment and have made no attempt to compile the sort of public register that we will be moving for. The Hawke Government-contrary, I would have thought, to Labor Party philosophy-has progressively dismantled restrictions on foreign investment since Labor won office in 1983. The current Treasurer has reduced the staff of the Foreign Investment Review Board from 40 to 20 and, as I indicated earlier, the value of foreign investment has more than doubled in the past few years.

The Hawke Government maintains that it has been forced to increase the level of foreign investment into Australia because Australia needs foreign currency to meet the massive interest bill on our foreign borrowings. This is something about which Senator Messner had a little to say. It certainly is, or should be, a concern of every Australian that we have a massive interest bill on foreign borrowings. But instead of trying to offset this by encouraging foreigners to buy up what is left of this country, we should be looking at a much longer term solution to that problem. As we all know, foreign investment leads to payments of rents, profits and dividends to the overseas owners. So it is only a partial solution to the problem, even if we assume that it is an acceptable solution, which the Democrats do not. To meet those payments of rent, profits and dividends we have to export more, we have to borrow more in foreign currencies or we have to sell more Australian assets overseas. None of those things is either desirable, certainly in the case of selling overseas, or likely-in the case of increasing exports-because our manufacturing sector is so neanderthal, so unimaginative, that it simply is not moving into increased export markets or import replacement areas.

Alternatively, we have to take other action to reduce our growing foreign debt. That means recognising what or who is causing that foreign debt and taking action to impede that rather than encouraging it as the current Government, following on from the previous Fraser Government, has done. In June 1977 Australia's total gross external debt was $7.8 billion. By June 1983 it had increased to $35.5 billion. It is now over $120 billion, most of which is owed by the private sector. Those private sector borrowings have been encouraged by previous governments' and this Government's allowance of tax concessions, primarily through the negative gearing system, which has been taken up with considerable enthusiasm by Australian companies to the point where some major companies in this country pay no tax at all.

Alan Bond commented quite cheerfully to the Australian Financial Review last year that, while he will be paying a little less than a cent in the dollar tax in this financial year, in the next financial year he expects to pay no tax at all-this despite profits in the range of $400m annually. He does this, as other companies do, by borrowing often from overseas and then writing off the interest against the Australian tax commitment. Pensioners are often paying out to the Government 50c in every dollar they earn over a certain amount while some of the wealthiest companies in this country are paying no tax. When that happens, of course, the Australian Taxation Office loses out on revenue. In turn, it slugs the benighted pay as you earn (PAYE) wage earner and struggling small businesses to make up the revenue shortfall. I must say that I think it was extraordinary, given the increasing number of companies that are currently paying less than 10c in the dollar when the nominal tax rate is 49c for companies, that this Government last year, with the support of the Opposition, should have seen fit to cut company tax by 20 per cent and then a few months later say that the economy was not in the sort of condition that would allow PAYE wage and salary earners to get the sort of commensurate tax relief that they so desperately need. The Government ought to be looking at the cause of the problem of the burgeoning foreign debt and not simply looking at increased foreign investment to offset that rocketing foreign indebtedness that is actively encouraged in this country. In the short term this Government's policies will convert our foreign debt problem into a foreign ownership problem. In the long term the earnings on the foreign investment will need to be serviced, as well as the interest payments on our foreign debt.

Of particular concern to many Australians is the impact that these policies are having on their lifestyle and standard of living, particularly as related to ordinary Australian families. Senator Messner argued that there was no empirical evidence to show that house and land prices were being affected in any way at all detrimentally by foreign investment in these areas. Yet we read reports in newspapers of just such attempts being made to purchase Australian real estate at highly inflated prices that will impact on everything else in the market. A Japanese client, according to the Melbourne Herald in November last year, offered the owner of a Toorak apartment in Melbourne $10m, after an earlier offer of $1m had been turned down. It is inevitable, when foreigners are able to offer an inflated price for property, that that will ripple down.

It is not only, as some people would like to have it, Toorak luxury apartments or harbourside homes in Sydney that attract foreign investors. They are looking in the ordinary housing market to buying up blocks of units for highly inflated prices and putting some homes outside the reach of ordinary Australian families. They are doing it, as I said earlier, because housing prices are comparatively cheap in this country to most residents of Japan, Hong Kong or Singapore. It is ironic that there has been this shift in ownership in Australia. Eight or so years ago the Australian National University ran a seminar entitled `Who Runs Australia?'. At that stage people were complaining loudly about the fact that millions of hectares of pastoral land in northern Australia were being bought up by Saudi Arabians and West Germans. It seems that it takes a concerted attempt by the Japanese before people start to get concerned about what is happening.

Urban land and house prices are not the only areas of concern. Rural real estate is and has been for decades a target for overseas buyers. The impact on our farming sector is evident. More and more people are being forced off the land or placed in a particularly impecunious condition because of rocketing prices and valuations in that area. A few weeks ago the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, attacked my colleague Senator Macklin when Senator Macklin raised the question of payments to children whose families live in isolated areas but who have been means tested out of benefits. Senator Walsh said, `Well, anybody who is on a property valued at $600,000 and can't make a go of it should get off that property'. The fact is that frequently there are not buyers for that property. The valuation is up only because some investor from outside this country has paid a highly inflated price for a neighbouring property but is not necessarily prepared to buy the next door property, even if those concerned are prepared to sell.

It is ridiculous that Australian rural real estate purchases under $3m will be exempt from Foreign Investment Review Board surveillance, that is, unless the Democrats' amendment is successful. I certainly hope that my National Party colleagues in this place will consider quite seriously the impact of this legislation and the Government's proposals on their constituents. The President of the National Farmers Federation, John Allwright, has written to the Treasurer, to the Australian Democrats and, I would hope, to National, Liberal and Labor Party senators in this place expressing concern about just this matter. He wrote:

The National Farmers' Federation considers that the foreign takeovers legislation should require foreign investment in land (and possibly selected other assets) to be notified to the FIRB. In addition, steps may need to be taken to strengthen the FIRB's powers to ensure that a requirement to notify is effective and enforceable.

The requirements to notify land purchases would substantially alleviate fears in many rural industries, especially the Queensland cattle industry, that the rate of foreign purchase is excessive and out of control. In some areas, the concern over foreign ownership is reaching a highly emotional level.
That was certainly exhibited on a 60 Minutes program the other night. Mr Allwright went on:
. . . urge the Government's consideration of changes to the foreign takeovers legislation to require notification of foreign land purchases to the FIRB or other competent authority.

Tourism is another area in which foreign investment is burgeoning, again particularly in Queensland. It is not surprising, therefore, that people are very concerned about the fact that between 1986 and 1987 the level of investment in Australia's tourism increased from $440m to $1,800m-all of which was assisted by the fact that the FIRB rules on tourist developments such as hotels and motels amount to little more than open slather on foreign investment in that area. The issue was recently pinpointed by Dr Adrian Bull, a lecturer in tourism at the Queensland Agricultural College, who noted:
Foreign investment in tourism should be stringently controlled so that the financial benefit does not simply flow back to the visitor's own country.

What is happening is that golf courses, tourist resorts and so on are being purchased for access use by Japanese tourists. They are purchased by Japanese, they are for use by Japanese, and the money turns round and goes back to the Japanese and is of little benefit to the Australian people as a whole. Dr Bull pointed out that soon Australia will be in a similar position to Spain. That country receives as little as $31 for every $100 spent by tourists on a holiday in Spain. Yet, he points out, it could have been as high as $85 out of every $100 had the facilities been Spanish-owned instead of owned by other western European countries, the source of the tourists spending their holidays in Spain.

Even when some restrictions exist, however, there is no guarantee that very much will be done, due primarily to the fact, as I said earlier, that the FIRB has been downgraded. Its staff, as I said a moment ago, has been virtually halved and a ceiling has been imposed on its staff members. Since its establishment in 1976, the FIRB has managed only one prosecution under the Foreign Takeovers Act, and even that was unsuccessful. I am not being critical of the FIRB and its staff. They act in an advisory capacity only and if the Government-and that means the Treasurer-does not want to act, there is not a great deal that the FIRB can do about it.

On 28 July 1986 the Hawke Government decided that it ought to do something about the situation, however minimal its actions were to be. It decided that foreign purchases of real estate for development, both residential and commercial, would be approved-unless judged contrary to the national interest. I ask you! I would have thought that any Australian government would have been much more concerned about seeing that approval was given to a development by a foreign national only if it could be shown that that development was in the national interest, rather than the negative of its being contrary to the national interest. Given that there has been only one prosecution under the Foreign Takeovers Act, I expect that it will be highly unlikely that any proposal will ever be judged contrary to the national interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill amends the Foreign Takeovers Act to give legislative effect to changes to foreign investment policy announced by the Government in 1985 and 1987. The Opposition, as Senator Messner has said, does not oppose the Bill, although we will move several amendments at the committee stage. To the motion for the second reading, we have already moved the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate condemns the Government for its failed economic policies which have resulted in:
(a) Australia's increasing dependence on foreign investment;
(b) a continuing balance of payments crisis and associated foreign debt problems;
(c) high domestic interest rates adversely affecting all Australians; and
(d) record levels of taxation which are heavily biased against the ability of Australians to save''.
I will come back to the amendment a little later.

The main purposes of the Bill are to prevent foreigners from buying Australian urban real estate without approval; to strengthen the penalty and enforcement provisions of the Foreign Takeovers Act; to exempt from the provisions of the Act the acquisition by foreign persons of mineral exploration rights; to increase to $5m and, in the case of rural businesses, $3m the value below which proposals by foreigners to buy Australian businesses are exempt from examination; to increase from $3m to $20m the threshold above which foreigner to foreigner takeovers are subject to the Act; and to amend the Act to provide a changed definition of foreign person that takes account of trusts. By far the most important of these proposals is the first, that is, to bring the acquisition of urban real estate within the scope of the Foreign Takeovers Act.

Several things should be said at the outset about this Bill. Firstly, the Bill is a classic example of this Government's total disregard for the Parliament and for the proprieties of legislative practice. The Bill has not been lying around for a long time; it was introduced into the House of Representatives in November last year. It gives legislative effect to changes to foreign investment policy announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 29 October 1985, 30 April 1987 and 29 September 1987. In other words, the Bill should have been brought to the Parliament more than three years ago, as soon as the first of the policy announcements were made.

Even the latest of the policy announcements, the one in September 1987, came out more than one year before the Bill was first introduced. That September 1987 decision was an economically stupid and cynically opportunistic decision. As we all know, the decision was taken by the Australian Labor Party in the forlorn hope of saving poor old Barrie Unsworth in New South Wales. That would have to be the classic example of mateship, the Right helping the Right, regardless of the impact it would have on all other Australians. It did not succeed. Barrie Unsworth went the way of all such Premiers and all such discarded governments. Nevertheless, that was the reason for that key decision which is now the main element of this Bill.

The reason for the taking of the decision was a disgraceful one, particularly in view of the enormous delay in bringing the matter to Parliament for the necessary legislative validation. No clearer indication could we have of the contempt with which the Hawke Government holds the Parliament and, therefore, the Australian people. Legislation by press release, which is what the actions of the Government over the past three years in this respect virtually amount to, is undemocratic. It is a denial of basic parliamentary procedures. It is the action of an arrogant and out of touch Executive and it is something to which the Senate, through its Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, has drawn attention. All of us in the Senate, on both sides of the chamber, have drawn attention to the problem for years now, yet the situation has not improved. It gets worse day by day.

Not only is the Bill being brought to the Parliament three years late: it is also a very silly Bill, at least in respect of its main provision which deals with the acquisition by foreigners of urban real estate. The provision is very badly flawed. It is based on thoroughly bad economics. Over the past six years we have had many examples of just how little grasp of basic economic concepts Mr Keating really has. By and large, he has managed to cover up those deficiencies with a mixture of hype, public relations good luck and a bullying of both the media and the business sector. But those tactics can only get someone through for so long, and they no longer work for this Treasurer. No longer do the media hold the Treasurer in respect. They have seen through him. They have at last recognised that, whilst the Treasurer won a journalistic award for economic management earlier in his stewardship, he won it at a time when even blind Freddy could have done the same. When put more to the test, though, the Treasurer failed lamentably to manage the economy effectively. No wonder that only a year after he won his best Treasurer award, he was judged by the same judges as the world's second worst Treasurer.

The decision to clamp down on foreign purchases or urban real estate was said by the Treasurer to have been taken because such purchases were pushing up the prices of houses in Australia and therefore making it more difficult as well as more costly for people to buy homes. In other words, the Treasurer alleged that foreign purchasers of homes in places like Sydney, the Gold Coast and elsewhere increased their prices and also acted to reduce the stock of housing. The Treasurer produced no evidence whatsoever to support his claim with respect to the cost of housing. The assertion is hotly disputed and denied by experts in the real estate industry. Leading figures in the real estate industry have made many statements refuting the Treasurer's claims in this regard. I will mention just two of them. Mr Neil Collins, the Managing Director of Richardson and Wrench, one of the largest real estate firms in Australia, said:

. . . overseas investors have been buying only a very small percentage of the market and while there have been some spectacular purchases these investors were not major players in the market. I think it will make very little difference to the market.
The President of the Real Estate Institute of New South Wales, Mr Robert Bevan, said:

It is a decision taken for purely political reasons to support the fallacious argument that foreign investors in the $1m plus residential market are making it hard for first-home buyers in the $80,000 to $90,000 market. If there were any way the REI could be convinced that stopping foreigners from buying into the upper end residential market would stop the price spiral in the mid to lower end residential market we would applaud the Government's move.
As I said, the fact is that the Treasurer has produced no evidence whatsoever to support the assertion that the foreign buying of urban houses has pushed up prices.

The Treasurer's argument that foreign purchasers reduce the stock of available housing is quite the opposite of the truth. The Treasurer appears to assume that foreigners can add to the stock of housing only if they build new houses. That argument ignores the fact that funds are freed up for Australians when they sell to foreigners. Some of those funds will be used by Australians to build new houses; the remainder will either be consumed or saved and, therefore, invested by others who may also build new houses. In other words, the Treasurer's economic argument is totally wrong. Indeed, in the longer term, his ban on foreign investment in urban real estate will reduce the stock of housing, not increase it. That, in turn, will lead to higher prices and higher rents.

The Treasurer made these wild statements in his second reading speech on 9 November 1988. He was also associated with other statements at that time. Although the new policy has been in force since September 1987, the action taken then did not push down the price of houses. On the contrary, the price rose massively in the year after the decision was taken. If we were honest about it, we would all know that the real causes of high home prices do not lie with foreign buyers; they lie entirely with the Government and its wretched failed economic policies. The economic mismanagement of the Hawke-Keating Government and the blind arrogance and intransigence of the Treasurer have led to huge increases in the costs of construction of new homes and in the cost of home loans.

That is why Senator Messner, on behalf of the Opposition, has moved a second reading amendment condemning the Government for its failed economic policies. Those policies have caused hardship for every Australian. But, above all, they have crippled young married couples seeking to buy, or to retain possession of, their first home. The burden on young single income families with children is totally overwhelming.

When this Government came to office in 1983, monthly repayments on an average home were of the order of $385. Today, that figure has nearly doubled. How can any young couple afford such a staggering increase? That is not the end of the story, by any means. In addition to huge loan repayment increases, there have been equally staggering tax increases. Some people would argue that the actual monthly repayment on a loan does not necessarily increase with an increase in interest rates, because the banks, or the lending institutions, simply extend the time of the loan for repayment or take other measures to ease that immediate burden. That is what is happening in many instances. However, that does not, in any way, rebut the argument that the cost burden on families repaying loans on home mortgages increases as a result of interest rate increases. Of course, the demand for housing, the cost of building new houses and other factors also push up the price of housing, thereby increasing the size of the loan which is required.

In addition to the huge loan repayment increases, there have been equally staggering tax increases. The average income earner today would need a tax cut of $251 a month simply to be in the same after tax position as he was in 1983 when this Government came to office. It is no wonder the electorate is crying with financial pain; no wonder it is crying for a change of government. The average income earners in this country, and particularly the average family with young children, are facing financial stringencies which are unprecedented in the lifetimes of most of us.

There are many popular misconceptions about the role and nature of foreign investment in Australia. The debate about foreign investment which is taking place in this country today worries me in several important respects. That debate is increasingly ringing with xenophobic and jingoistic views which we must be very careful not to foster. We heard some of these misconceptions, par excellence, from Senator Haines, before the suspension of the sitting for dinner. No doubt we will hear more from other Australian Democrat speakers this evening. Foreign investment in Australia supplements our own domestic savings. It adds to our resources and, therefore, it enables us to grow at a faster rate than would otherwise be the case.

Australia has relied throughout its history, and particularly in the post-Second World War era, on the inflow of foreign capital to provide us with additional resources. There is no doubt that we will continue to do so in the foreseeable future. There is nothing wrong with that in principle. I was very concerned to hear Senator Haines express, in her remarks before dinner, the view that we had to have a register of foreign assets and land holdings in Australia. She said that until we got such a register we would not know the extent of foreign ownership by industry and by region and, therefore, we would not know the extent of what she described as the problem and what we need to do about it. Inherent in her whole approach is an argument that, somehow or other, foreign investment is bad for us. If I am misinterpreting Senator Haines, I hope that Senator Powell will say something to set me right. It appeared to me that that was the whole thrust of Senator Haines's remarks. I believe that that is a totally negative, destructive and economically wrong approach and method of looking at the whole question of foreign investment. It demonstrates to me a complete lack of understanding of the subject-a misunderstanding which is of concern to any of us, but it is of even more concern coming from the economic spokesman or representative of a party in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —She is said to be the economic spokesman.
—That is a very good point. Senator Haines is said to be the economic spokesman of the Democrats, but we have found, from many examples, that that is actually hard to believe.

SPEECH.PARA: However, there are important aspects of our current foreign investment situation which, I believe, are matters of legitimate concern. The first is the sheer size of the inflow.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not have a register.

—Senator Powell says we do not have a register, but she does not distinguish at all between debt, on the one hand, and equity on the other. The honourable senator wants a register for the assets which are owned in Australia. Therefore, on the one hand she is talking about equity, but on the other hand she is complaining about the cost to the economy of the money borrowed from overseas. She is all over the place on the subject. I wish she would get her facts and her concepts right.

SPEECH.PARA: The sheer size of the inflow is, of course, a function of the huge deficit in our balance of payments on current account. That totally unacceptable deficit is very much the fault of the policies of this Government. It is salutary to note in this connection that the deficit would be very much larger if there had not been the extraordinary and largely unexpected buoyancy of commodity prices on international markets over the past year or so. Indeed, this buoyancy has resulted in Australia's terms of trade now being more favourable than they have been for at least two decades.

Is it not strange that we do not hear much from the Government about this major improvement in the terms of trade? Why do we not hear about it? It is because this Government put all the blame for our economic difficulties in 1985 and 1986 on a fall in the terms of trade that we suffered at that time-a fall, I would point out, that was not as large as the fall experienced in the late 1970s under the Fraser Government, which caused problems but which was ridden out very successfully by the responsible economic policies of the Fraser Government. There was a significant fall in our terms of trade in 1985-86. The Government placed all the blame for our economic problems at that time on that. That was largely a fallacy. Our problems were not simply induced by the terms of trade. However, if logic were to play any part in the Treasurer's armoury, he should be saying now that the big improvement in our terms of trade has led to an easing of our economic problems. Why is he not saying that? He is not saying it because our problems are increasing despite the terms of trade improvement.

The concern about the size of the current inflow is related to the large debt component within the total inflow. Debt has to be repaid in the end, and in the interim interest has to be paid year by year on the capital outstanding. The interest burden on our foreign debt is now a matter of very great concern. Interest payments alone-we should forget about repayments of any of the capital-amount to something like one-fifth of all our earnings in the form of exports of goods and services. That is a huge burden at any time and it takes a great chunk out of the benefits that we derive from our export performance-a performance which, despite the increase to record levels in our terms of trade, is volumeless in terms of increase. The increase in our exports is coming from price increases, not from volume. That in itself is a major problem, but it is a somewhat separate issue. When export prices weaken-and it is a matter of when, not if-the interest bill will pose very grave problems for our economy. That is not an argument against foreign investment per se; indeed, to put up the shutters against foreign investment would be catastrophic to our standard of living. It would make the 1930s look like chicken feed. We need to pursue policies which will over time reduce the degree of our dependence on foreign investment for the maintenance of our living standards. We need a broadly based policy approach in many areas at both the macro- and the micro-economic level.

The Government's failure to adopt appropriate fiscal and wages policies has cost Australia very dearly. The present direction of policy in both these areas must be reversed as a matter of the greatest urgency. On the wages front the Australian Council of Trade Unions deal of a $20 tax cut and a $30 wage increase per week is, I believe, a recipe for unmitigated disaster. It represents an increase in average real wages of more than 10 per cent. It is not even linked to guarantee productivity increases, yet low productivity gains have been the underlying reason for our internationally uncompetitive economic performance for decades now, and the reason why we are slipping rapidly through the international ranks in terms of our per capita standard of living. It is nothing short of economic criminality for the Government to contemplate supporting an increase of this magnitude at this time. Indeed, I believe that there are more cogent reasons for arguing against any tax cut or wage increase at this time.

I make two points in passing on the so-called wage tax cut trade-off. The first is that it is no trade-off. The two are additive; one is not a substitute for the other. The second point I make is that a tax cut of the size proposed would go nowhere near returning to taxpayers the taxes that have been ripped off them through bracket creep in the last six years. There would need to be a cut of something like $58 per week, not $20, to achieve that. On the micro-economic front, the Government continues to fiddle while Australia burns. The industrial relations situation continues to deteriorate and the waterfront and the shipping industries continue to suffer from gross overmanning, restrictive work practices and other impediments to improved efficiency. The Government has failed singularly to take the necessary steps either to privatise its business undertakings or to make them more competitive and efficient. The list is endless. These are the tasks that we must undertake if we are going to restore Australia's fortunes and our living standards. The Bill before the Senate does none of these. In my view it displays a negative and restrictive mentality.

As I said earlier, I urge all honourable senators to exercise our maximum responsibility as politicians-and I make the same comment for others in the community-to ensure that we do not get into the area of xenophobic, jingoistic mud-slinging about foreign investment in this country, because if we do we will get ourselves into some very sticky waters indeed. The concern that is being voiced in the community today about foreign investment is a great echo in my memory of the debates and the concerns that were expressed against American investment in the 1950s and 1960s. We were concerned at that time that American investment was going to gobble us up. We went through some very difficult periods in those days before we got a rational view and a rational debate on the whole question of foreign investment.

Despite the fact that the assertions are wrong, I fear that there is an attack coming on Japanese investment in Australia. That is what it is about. If we go down the path of saying that there is something bad about the current level of investment in Australia because it is Japanese-and that is the connotation that many people will place on it-we will do ourselves a very grave disservice. Japan is our largest trading partner. Our fortunes are inextricably linked with the fortunes of Japan and it is of the greatest importance that in our approach, which needs to be responsible, autonomous and in our self-interest, we must take very careful account of the need to cooperate and work with Japan and not to give the Japanese or other people in this world any opportunity to say to us that we are being racist in our approach to foreign investment. If we do not watch that very carefully we will have a problem.

Whilst I am not suggesting that this Bill is necessarily of that nature, there are very heavy overtones of it. The argument in the community has been that the main purchasers of urban real estate have come from Japan. That is not entirely correct, but that is the public perception. Therefore, one can argue that, because the main provision in this Bill is directed at imposing a major clamp on foreign investment in urban real estate, it is directed against Japanese investment in this country. I caution the Senate very strongly indeed about going down that road.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks will be directed in large measure to supporting amendments which will be moved in the committee stage by Senator Haines, who is leading for the Australian Democrats in this debate on the Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill 1988. I will begin my contribution by commenting on the final remarks of Senator Short. His caution that any debate about questions of foreign investment and foreign ownership on this country should not be seen in any way to have any racist or other overtones is to be endorsed. This country has a history of waves of investment coming from those economies that are strong in the overall world picture. Initially, British investment came very much with our original British heritage, and Senator Short referred specifically to the period of strong investment from the United States of America. Following that there were the oil sheikhs. A problem was beginning to emerge with that and there was some concern, but the oil prices then went down and that problem disappeared. At the moment there is concern, and I reiterate that that concern has been about before as those waves of investment, and particularly ownership, came upon this economy. The fact that it now focuses to a very large extent, although not exclusively, on Japanese investment is a reflection of the strength of the Japanese economy on the world scene. It is a reflection of the currency difference between our two countries and of the availability of sources of investment in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats will be moving a number of amendments, among them an amendment to set up a register-which again Senator Short has referred to-and an amendment to remove the $3m limit which currently is required before purchases of rural real estate can be made. In a sense, those two amendments are complementary. I want to address the question of whether the setting up of a register is a useful thing to do. I reiterate that this has been a policy of the Australian Democrats since the early 1980s. We had a national conference in 1982 and we included that in our policy as rural people were concerned that large tracts of land had been in the past and were continuing to be purchased by overseas interests-not at that time specifically Japanese interests. This is not a new thing for the Australian Democrats; it is a longstanding policy. We have chosen to move an amendment to this Bill to try to implement that longstanding policy.

In recent times it has often been suggested that, if we could set up such a register, a great deal of the heat would go out of this debate. A great deal of the suspicion, and even the concern, that this might be seen as some kind of racist exercise would also go out of the debate because people would be operating from the point of view of real information and not just from the point of view of public perception. I heard Senator Short use that phrase at least twice. Our problem is partly one of public perception. We are dependent upon adhockery to find out the nature of investment, where it is, and the level of that investment. That is really our concern. The Democrats are not saying that foreign investment and foreign ownership per se are bad. We are saying that the nature and the level of that investment or ownership may be bad and that we need a register to show exactly what is happening so that we and other concerned people and decision-makers in our community can make decisions about that.

We are not saying this on our own. We do not stand condemned, as Senator Short would have us, as people who really do not understand what is going on in the economic world. The National Party Government in Queensland has put up legislation, although, as Senator Haines said, we understand that that legislation is not yet operative. That Party's colleagues in the Australian Labor Party in Queensland also have such a recommendation in their policy, and so has the Tasmanian Liberal Party.

It seems to me that we are seeing a great degree of multipartisan support, except here in the Federal Parliament. My National Party colleagues are not in the chamber tonight, nor are they entering into this debate. I looked down a speakers list of some 10 or 12 people and did not see a single National Party senator on it. I suspect that there is a reason for that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Stone is.
—My list does not have Senator Stone on it. If Senator Stone had been intending to speak tonight it might have been fascinating to hear what he had to say.
—Perhaps he is away tonight.

—It might be convenient for him to be away tonight and not to have to persuade one of his colleagues to stand in his place. I suspect that members of the National Party are having grave problems with the fact that they have not been able to carry the day and convince the coalition of the necessity of our amendments to set up a register, which their colleagues in Queensland are going to do, to remove the limits so that we will really know what is happening with rural land and so that people will not be able to buy little parcels of land, under $3m at a time, and build up their investment without accounting to the Australian community. National Party senators have a few problems with that, similar to the problems that they are having within the coalition on the upcoming legislation on wheat marketing, where once again it appears as though the coalition will walk away from its rural constituency, which I think by now will have come to realise that it has had the wool pulled over its eyes for some years.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, there seems to be some multipartisan support around the country, although not in this Parliament, for the establishment of a register and for a closer supervision of what is going on. I can go no further for a pretty comprehensive run-down of other areas of support for the rural industry outside the political scene than an article in last Wednesday's Melbourne Age which demonstrates the attitudes of various groups that I consider would normally be looking to the National Party and to the coalition for some support in this place. These groups include: the United Graziers Association, the Cattle Council, the Victorian Farmers Federation and the Cattlemen's Union. I wish to put on the record what some of these groups are saying, which is very much what the Democrats are saying. I think the concern of these organisations relates to what is clearly developing in this area of foreign investment and ownership-that is, the development of vertical integration, particularly in the beef industry. We know it is happening in the beef industry. It has become quite obvious because of the high levels of investment and the very obvious nature of that investment. It is not an investment that is easy to disguise.

Earlier this month the Cattlemen's Union called for a total freeze on all Japanese investment in the beef industry until the impact on Australia's long term interests had been assessed. We have talked in this debate about selling off the farm. The message in this article in the Age by David Porter is this:
. . . cattlemen do not intend to sit around the camp fire while foreign investors rustle the family herd from under their feet.
Clearly, they are not prepared to do so. The article continues:
The union's executive director, Mr Shaun Coffey says: `I think the community generally is expressing two fears. Firstly, that the industry could be overrun and we could lose control.
I ask the honourable senators to notice the qualification `could'. The article continues:
Secondly, that the Australian Government is not scrutinising closely enough what is going on.
That is the very point that the Australian Democrats have been making these past eight years. The article goes on to state that there is a perception that:

. . . the Government's review process needs to be more open, that more information needs to be made public on the level of foreign interests and where foreign investment is directed. Such openness, he says, would allay the unnecessary `suspicion and alarm'-
that same suspicion and alarm that Senator Short was warning against-
that has spread through the cattle industry.

That suspicion and alarm have spread through a number of other industries, in particular the tourist industry, which has been mentioned already in this debate. Again, this suspicion and alarm is based on a lack of information. All that the Democrats are saying in our relevant amendment to establish a register is, `Let us get rid of that uncertainty and that ignorance about what is happening and then let us have the debate'.

The Cattlemen's Union has called for a moratorium. It says that it believes it is warranted until foreign investment guidelines are tightened. That is perhaps one of the toughest stands. The United Graziers Association has pointed out, as did Senator Short, that Japan generally has been a good trading partner. It, however, favours a return or the 51 per cent Australian equity criteria for abattoirs and feedlot purchases with one-third local equity rules applying at the farm level. It believes that property purchases of $1m or more should be assessed by the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB), as should abattoirs for purchases in excess of $5m.

Again, that is the sort of thing that the Australian Democrats are saying clearly. Even the United Graziers Association, which is very concerned to stress the good relationship with the Japanese, is worried that $3m as the benchmark for rural purchase is too high. As I said, there is no control or review over any purchases that are smaller than that. It is clearly a simple matter to break up the purchases into smaller parcels. The Cattle Council of Australia is similarly concerned. It is concerned particularly that the fears of the meat industry should not be interpreted as populist, anti-Japanese sentiment resulting from the lingering wartime resentment. We should realise that these organisations, the industry itself and anyone else in the community who is concerned run the risk of being labelled racist. I again stress that for the Democrats, as for the rational people in this debate, including the Cattle Council, it is important that it is seen as a debate about what has been a wave process throughout our history. It is one which from time to time in the past has caused concern. It is doing so equally now.

Michael Prendergast, the Cattle Council's Acting Director, pointed to the emotionalism in the debate. He also said that he could understand it being there and that it does not help. He said that the Cattle Council, like the United Graziers Association, wants to see an FIRB with more teeth and believes that an industry impact statement should accompany each proposal. The Council is so concerned to keep Australian interests at a very high level that it is interested in supporting foreign investments in the form of joint ventures. The Victorian Farmers Federation pastoral group's spokesman, Mr Kevin Shiell, said this:
Many of the concerns about foreign ownership in the meat industry have arisen because nobody really knows how much there is.
There is a need for a register so that we do know.

The Foreign Investment Review Board is strongly supported in all of those comments. Groups are urging that it be stronger and that its requirements be stricter. At the moment that is the real part of the problem. There is no mechanism for the FIRB to deal with anyone who, as I said, accumulates small blocks of land below the $3m cut-off for rural land, $5m in business takeovers or $10m in new businesses. In addition-this has been mentioned by Senator Haines-Budget cuts have forced the FIRB to shed staff. As Senator Haines also mentioned, the constituency should realise that in this debate the Federal Opposition wants to remove it altogether. I am not sure which is worse-the sort of attrition process which it is undergoing at the hands of the Government or the absolute abolition which it would undergo at the hands of the alternative Government. Certainly none of those organisations from whom I have quoted can take much comfort out of either process.

It is certainly a concern in the meat industry because of vertical integration-the purchase of land, the purchase of feedlots, the purchase of abattoirs. Although the liberalisation of the Japanese domestic meat market holds great promise for new opportunities and large profits, if we can meet the demand, there is that question of what happens. Money is certainly coming in but it is not buying Australian goods. It is buying the Australian means of production of goods. This type of vertical integration can lead-Senator Haines has given examples of the tourist industry in Spain-to Australia being placed back into the colonial stage that we were in earlier in our history when profits and products were expatriated. That cannot be seen to be in our best economic interests unless it is well handled, unless we have the fullest information and unless we are looking for the best interests of this country and not being blinded by the volumes of moneys that are coming in and not worrying about where it is going or what it is doing.

We hear a lot from both sides of this chamber-from the conservative Government and the conservative Opposition-about levelling the playing field. We need to realise that Australian producers are still denied access to Japan's lucrative domestic meat retail sector. So we are not operating on a level playing field. This morning in the Australian the Cattlemen's Union came out with a much more detailed statement. It is worth putting that on the record. It has given the matter more thought even in the last week and has called for guidelines for the scrutiny of foreign investment in the future. A register, such as we are proposing in our amendments, would go a long way towards that. It wants the statutory meat authorities to determine first of all whether an industry benefit analysis is needed. If, then, it believes that it is needed, an economic impact study should be commissioned by the FIRB. That will be difficult if members of the Cattlemen's Union and its rural compatriots vote in a coalition government at the next election because there will not be an FIRB. The Cattlemen's Union says that such a study should consider:
The ability of the investor to reduce Australian income by transfer pricing . . .

I remind the Senate that the Democrats have long stood up in this chamber against the process of transfer pricing and very little has happened. The Cattlemen's Union says the study should also consider the ability of the investor to reduce Australian income:
. . . by collusive bidding or tax avoidance.

It should also consider the threat of monopoly power developing. This is a major concern in vertical integration. When we are dealing with a trading partner whose own market is not totally open to us, as the Japanese retail meat sector is not, it is a problem. The third point the Cattlemen's Union makes is the potential for Australian interests to be excluded. We cannot determine that unless we have a register so that we know the exact level and nature of the investment. It is very encouraging to see that the Cattlemen's Union went on to say:
The union felt the study should also include aspects such as the introduction of new technology, job creation and export market access.

This kind of in depth review before major investment takes place certainly has the support of the Australian Democrats. But again, Mr Coffey concluded by assuring those who were interested in this issue that the Cattlemen's Union is not, per se, opposed to foreign investment in the beef industry. All it is really saying is that it must be in the best interests of the Australian beef industry and, therefore, of the Australian nation as a whole.
