It seems to me that the amendments which we will move, particularly the ones that will remove the $3m limit on the FIRB's review of the purchase of rural properties and set up a register, deserve support, if only to take some of the heat and emotionalism out of the debate. When the next wave takes place this country will be in a position to know what is happening, will be in control and will not go to short term solutions, as we so often do, but will be able to look at long term solutions. The Australian Democrats believe that this Government-this Opposition seems happy with it-is really replacing the foreign debt problem with a foreign ownership problem. It will pass on to future generations the need to deal with situations where significant industries in this country are expatriating their profits overseas. The only benefit we could possibly get out of it might be some minimal employment which could probably be generated by other means and by more balanced investment.

I urge honourable senators, particularly those who are concerned about the rural industry and rural communities generally, to support the Democrats' amendments. I place it on the record that the Democrats will support the Opposition's second reading amendment. I am sure that each of the complaints which the Opposition has in that amendment about the Government's economic policy is a complaint for quite a different reason from our point of view than it is from the point of view of the coalition parties. Nevertheless, we have those complaints and we will support the amendment. Paragraph (c) of the Opposition's amendment talks about high domestic interest rates adversely affecting all Australians and paragraph (d) talks about the ability of Australians to save. I draw the Opposition's attention to the private member's Bills which are designed to address the problems of home owners in this country. The Bills which Senator Haines introduced last week deal with issues which the Opposition's Treasury spokesperson, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), seems to be attempting to grapple with. I urge my Opposition colleagues to support not only our amendments to this legislation but also those Bills which will address some of the economic concerns which are expressed in its second reading amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill 1988 is a very important piece of legislation. I have just re-read the second reading speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). One comment on page 4 is of particular interest to me and to tonight's debate. At page 4 the Minister actually laid down the challenge by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill will provide the Opposition with an opportunity to clarify its position on these issues.

Already two Opposition speakers have spoken to the Bill tonight but so far, unfortunately, the challenge has not been taken up. According to the speakers list, Senator Parer will speak very soon, followed by Senator Lewis and Senator Archer. I remind each of those honourable senators of that challenge. Where does the Opposition stand in terms of foreign takeovers of Australian resources, be they minerals, mines, houses, shops or whatever? Where do the Liberal and National parties stand as political parties? I remind honourable senators opposite that there is more to being in opposition or being a representative in parliament than continually knocking or continually using every piece of legislation or every debate in this chamber for union bashing, which is what we have heard from two of the previous Opposition speakers. They have used the debate on the Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill to attack the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) claim for a wages-taxes trade-off. I dare say that other Opposition speakers will follow that through. Not only did that not add anything to this very important debate but it proved, yet again, that honourable senators opposite honestly do not know what they are talking about, whatever the subject matter, whether it be foreign takeovers, wages or taxes.

The challenge is in front of the Opposition. I invite it to put up a coherent, rational alternative that the people of Australia can understand, one that can stand comparison with what the Government is doing. I note that some previous speakers, particularly Senator Short, said that the $50 ACTU wages-taxes claim was something which the country could not stand. Sections in the Government also believe that. Healthy debate on that is taking place not only within the Government but within the community. It is taking place in a controlled, rational and reasonable fashion as distinct from the confrontationist tactics that we witnessed under the previous Government led by Mr Fraser and Mr Howard.

The Opposition has not scored any points in recent times by union bashing. Why does it not learn from its mistakes? How many elections in a row has it lost at State and Federal levels? We heard some talk about the New South Wales election, but honourable senators opposite failed to mention the Western Australian election, the Victorian election and the last Federal election. Let us get things in proportion and not deal with only one election. Of course, the important one for each and every one of us here is the next election, whenever it will be held. That election ought to be fought on policy issues. One of those crucial policy issues ought to be taxation. Why does the Opposition not bring out its policy and tell us what it is about? Why does it not bring out one policy?

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you tell us what your tax cuts will be?

—I ask Senator Baume not to get into this debate. He should hold it for a moment. He gave us a big help in the last Federal election campaign. He will be of use to us at a later stage, in the same way that Joh, the former Premier of Queensland, was of use to us in the last election. I ask Senator Baume to stay quiet for a little while. He will get his opportunity later. We will circulate his press releases.

SPEECH.PARA: In closing his comments, Senator Short made a very important announcement, which I agree with, concerning Japanese investment. One of the things happening in the Australian community is that the fear of Japanese investment in Australia has been beaten up into a torrent. Lots of people are becoming extremely scared about the impact that Japanese investment will have on Australia, both in the short term and in the long term. If people have a fear it ought not to be about Japanese investment. It should perhaps be about foreign investment or whatever controls a government exercises over foreign investment. It should not be turned into a racist debate. Unfortunately, if it is I am afraid the finger will again have to be pointed at those sitting on the Opposition benches. It was Opposition members who polarised our community last year on the migration debate. If there are any costs to Australia from this anti-Japanese sentiment that is around at the moment in Australia-small though it may be-the finger will be pointed directly at those on the Opposition benches. There is an obligation on us as members of parliament and representatives of the people to--

TALK.START.PARA: —To tell the truth.
—To tell the truth, to control this debate on the way through, and to explain clearly and succinctly to people what we mean about foreign investment in Australia.
—And what did Senator Short say?
—I agreed with Senator Short.
—You just accused us of being racist. You can't have it both ways.

—I accused the Opposition parties of being racist. I agreed with Senator Short's specific comments tonight on Japanese investment. Senator Baume should not twist the words. I commended Senator Short for saying what he did, even though it might get him into problems with his own Party. I agreed with his commendable statement tonight. I did not intend to speak for this long and I will wind up shortly.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently I was involved in a foreign takeover of a small fish processing plant in Geraldton in the mid-west of Western Australia by a Japanese company. The company which was taken over by the Japanese company was owned by British interests. I must make the point very clearly that, despite my accent, I did not become involved and do things merely because there was some British involvement in the takeover. I did so because there was great fear among the fishing community and local residents not only within Geraldton but right along the west coast of Western Australia. I am sure that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, became aware of that as well. There was a genuine fear by those people of the impact on their industry if Japanese interests were able to gain a major influence-not a controlling influence-over that very important industry to Western Australia and Australia as a whole.

Unfortunately, that fear was beaten up in the heat of the Western Australian State election held early last month. The fear was beaten up, unfortunately, and played on by people who had an interest in making political capital out of it. Thankfully, the matter was resolved amicably. What could have turned out to be a big hate campaign did not happen because the industry itself took a very sensible and rational approach to the problem. Industry representatives sat down and researched what possible impacts the Japanese takeover could have on their industry. They put their research on paper and brought it here directly to the Treasurer, Paul Keating. They met with him for a considerable period and put their arguments to him.

The Treasurer listened to those arguments. He heard them out. He was not forced into making a decision prior to the Western Australian election merely for the sake of political expediency, which some people tried to get us to do. He did not make a decision in the heat of an election campaign. He certainly heard the people in the week prior to the election but he would not and did not make a decision until afterwards. When he did make a decision, the decision was favourable to the industry because it rejected the foreign takeover of a British-owned company operating within Geraldton in Western Australia.

As I said, this is a very important Bill that we are debating tonight. I had not intended to speak for as long as I have. However, I was somewhat baited into doing so-perhaps that is a comment I could have made in my recent remarks about the fishing industry. The people of Australia need to understand a lot more about this important matter. There is an obligation, not only on the Government, but also on the Opposition parties, including the Australian Democrats, to explain to the people of Australia as clearly, calmly and succinctly as possible how the foreign money that is coming into Australia is impacting on us.

Nobody, including honourable senators opposite, would say that we do not need foreign investment in Australia. Even honourable senators opposite would agree that there have to be some measures of control over foreign investment. In this legislation we are relaxing those controls in certain areas and tightening them in other areas. That is an indication of the flexibility this Government is showing in dealing with the economic problems that beset Australia as a developed nation approaching the twenty-first century.

The Bill is commendable. We will look with interest at the amendments that will be put forward by the Australian Democrats. Hopefully, the level of debate will improve. As I said, the challenge is before Senator Parer. He is now presented with an opportunity to clarify his position and his Party's position on this most important issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill 1988. I commend Senator McKiernan for getting to his feet. According to the list of speakers, he is the only person from the other side of the chamber who will participate in the debate on what he considers to be a most important Bill. I can only presume, in view of the absence of his colleagues, that he is the only honourable senator opposite who believes that it is an important Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill has two purposes. The first is to relax some restrictions on foreign investment; the second is to tighten up other restrictions. The Bill seeks to tighten restrictions on the purchase of urban real estate by foreigners. Senator McKiernan went to great lengths, tongue in cheek, to say that he agreed with Senator Short that this issue should not be politicised. Naturally, I agree with Senator Short. But, as honourable senators will find as I debate this matter, this Bill is political. It was introduced not on the basis of fact but on the basis of the perception by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that the Government ought to do something, without any reference at all to the facts.

Let us be direct: this Bill is about preventing or cutting off the level of Japanese investment in urban real estate. Newspaper and other reports have claimed that the Japanese somehow, by buying at the top end of the market, have affected the purchase price of the average house. Nothing could be further from the truth. This is yet another Government tactic, another Government technique, to draw attention away from the real cause of the rise in the price of housing in Australia. That rise has been brought about by this Government, not by foreign investment in urban real estate.
As indicated by my colleague Senator Messner, the coalition will support these changes but it will move certain amendments that I will discuss later. In his second reading speech the Treasurer said:

. . . we have always needed a substantial flow of foreign investment to help expand our economy . . . This is particularly important now, given the crucial requirement that we internationalise the Australian economy and expand our export sector.

What the Minister should have added-this is particularly important-is that the diabolical state of the economy has been brought about by this Government, an economy described by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in quite comical terms, as a tragedy but not a mess. Can honourable senators imagine anything more ludicrous than that comment? When the Australian dollar went down, the Prime Minister got to his feet and said, `I did not say anything to bring the dollar down. Of course I did not'. To be fair to him, he said that aspects of the economy-fairly critical aspects such as the inflation rate and the balance of payments-were a tragedy, but not a mess.

Australia needs foreign investment because it is the only immediate solution to our key economic problem of external debt. The alternative-I hope that the economists in the Australian Democrats listen to this-because of the situation we find ourselves in, is a major economic recession or depression. That is the position we have reached. Until we can reduce or eliminate our current account deficit, which fuels this debt, that deficit must be financed by net capital inflow, either by increased overseas borrowing or, better still, by direct investment.

But the Government, having recognised the need for foreign investment and having moved to liberalise some of the guidelines in one part of this Bill, seeks to ban all foreign purchases of urban real estate. Under the legislation, all proposed acquisitions of urban real estate of foreign interests will now require approval by the Foreign Investment Review Board, regardless of size or value. Approval will not be granted for the foreign purchase of developed residential properties, except in a few limited cases. They are: Australian citizens living abroad, intending migrants who have received approval from the immigration authorities to take up permanent residence in Australia and foreign companies buying houses for executives resident in this country.

The Treasurer said in his second reading speech that at first sight we might find this incongruous. I would call it highly contradictory and typical of the breathtaking hypocrisy of which this Government is so capable. Needless to say, the coalition opposes these clauses, for the reasons I spoke about earlier. We are not advocating open slather. We believe that previous guidelines which all- owed foreigners to buy a property or properties not exceeding a cumulative value of $600,000 were adequate and preferable to this political, knee-jerk reaction.

What is the economic rationale for the new urban real estate guidelines which the Treasurer first announced in September 1987? I point out that we are now into March 1989. One might well ask. The official line is that the Government is concerned that the purchase of Australian houses by foreigners who have no intention of taking up residence here has contributed to driving up the price of Australian real estate and that this ban will dampen price pressures on the local housing market. How noble of the Government! What a pity there is not a shred of hard economic evidence to support this theory-not one single shred. When these measures were first announced in September 1987, the Treasurer could not provide any facts or figures to back up that decision. He conceded that the Government had relied heavily on anecdotal evidence. Nor could the real estate industry provide any support for it. It is worth repeating some of the quotes from real estate executives which the honourable member for Wentworth, Dr Hewson, cited in his speech during the second reading debate in the other place. Dr Hewson quoted Mr Neil Collins, Managing Director of Richardson and Wrench, one of the largest real estate firms in this country, who said:
Overseas investors have been buying only a very small percentage of the market and while there have been some spectacular purchases-
of course, these are the ones that get reported-
these investors were not major players in the market.
Bearing in mind that the major housing price increases have occurred in Sydney, it is worth noting the comment by Mr Robert Bevan, President of the Real Estate Institute of New South Wales, who said:

It is a decision taken for purely political reasons to support the fallacious argument that foreign investors in the $1m residential market are making it hard for first home buyers in the $80,000 to $90,000 market. If there were any way the Real Estate Institute could be convinced that stopping foreigners from buying into the upper end residential market would stop the price spiral in the mid to lower end residential market, we would applaud the Government's move.

Mr Keating fancies himself as an economic rationalist, but the ban on the purchase of urban real estate from a point of view of factual evidence is with the fairies. In fact, since the ban has been in place, since September 1987, housing prices have continued to boom. The ban has not had one iota of effect, especially in Sydney. In the year to December 1988, the value of medium priced homes increased by 70 per cent in Sydney, 36 per cent in Melbourne, and 32 per cent in Brisbane. That was after this ban came into effect in 1987. It has nothing to do with foreign investment in urban real estate; it is something else, and hence the amendments moved to this Bill by my colleague Senator Messner. The real motivation for this change has nothing to do with economics but everything to do with politics. This is the very thing that Senator McKiernan spoke about. He said that we should not make this matter a political issue. But that is exactly what this Bill does. That is what it is all about.

This Bill is part of the Government's ongoing search for scapegoats-people whom it can blame for the mess it has brought upon the Australian economy because, as honourable senators know, it is not the fault of the Government! The world's greatest Treasurer has told us it is not and we must believe him! Everyone knows, or seems to know-except the Government-that the economy is off the rails and the Government is paralysed into inaction. As each new set of bad economic data is released, the Government's excuses become more creative. The Australian Statistician, Mr Ian Castles, was blamed for the bad December consumer price index which pushed Australia's inflation rate to about 7.7 per cent. According to the Treasurer, Mr Castles was not measuring the housing costs properly. Mr Ron Knowles wrote about what he called the Government's `scapegoat crisis' in Monday's edition of the Australian Financial Review. It is worth quoting from his column. He said:

We have to be grateful to Mr Keating as the only minister who appears to be giving any thought to the scapegoat crisis. It was his fertile mind that identified the real cause of current problems . . .
And guess what it was-the people of Australia. That was the Treasurer's excuse. Mr Knowles continued:
According to the Keating doctrine, Australia would be an easy place to run if it weren't for the people who live there.

It seems that they want to live in pleasant houses, with space for the children to play and a Hills hoist on which to dry the washing. Some of them might even want to have a home as grand as the four-storey mansion near Sydney Harbour that they are paying Mr Keating and his family not to live in.
These people pushing up the cost of housing and the rate of inflation are ideal scapegoats.
That is, ordinary, average Australians. Mr Knowles continued:
Not only do they have no sense of patriotism as they indulge their appetites for revolving clothes lines, they are not willing to save.

It is their fault again-they will not save! No-one reminds the Treasurer that the reason some people will not save is that they cannot because of the tax rip-offs by this Government-the highest taxing government in this country's history-and so on. The article further stated:
According to . . . Senator Button, the ordinary people have no saving grace. They are not putting their money in the banks to enable Australian industry to develop and invest.

Why would they? There is a bias against putting one's money in the bank. By the time one's tax is paid-and the average person who earns more than $19,500 pays 40 per cent tax-and the inflation rate of 7.7 per cent is taken into account, one is in fact losing money. Much to my surprise, Senator Walsh has developed some sort of a taste for scapegoat hunting too. He blamed the ostentatious consumption of the nouveau rich as one of the causes for Australia's low household savings ratio. I think Senator Walsh should have blamed Labor's nouveau poor for not saving their money, judging from the angry response to this assertion. As one person said in a letter to the newspapers, `Save-I would love to. But my first thoughts are to ponder a way for my family to exist, before giving a thought to saving'. Or, `Where does Senator Button get off saying we aren't saving enough? How can we? With rising interest rates, plus phone, power and groceries, et cetera, how does he expect the ordinary person to save?'. Then there was this advice to the Treasurer from another person: `I'm off to spend my money before I lose any more to Mr Keating. I will start saving again when and if you get your act together'.

And now to the housing crisis, which is the background to this Bill. It will stop foreigners buying into urban real estate. That is the cause of the problems, even though I have shown quite clearly that since 1987 when this ban was first introduced, although the Bill is now just before us, housing prices have grown enormously. Housing affordability continues to fall in Australia. The December figures reveal the fifth successive quarterly decline in housing affordability since September 1987-since that date. The great dream for many a young person has turned into a nightmare. I know, because I have children of my own at that age who are affected by this very problem right now. I feel sorry for them because the struggle to overcome the situation is very difficult. The problem is not that the value of housing as a multiplier of average weekly earnings has changed too much in the past 20 or 30 years, but that interest rates have changed. Interest rates for the average home are rising to about 16 per cent and the inflation rate is about 7 per cent, whereas 20 or 30 years ago it was basically nil. More importantly, the tax rate takes away and saps the savings of individual Australians. I shall come to that matter shortly because it is important. The fact that people cannot afford to buy a home has, in the Government's view, nothing to do with the galloping inflation rate, just as it has nothing to do with the Government's monetary policy, which has delivered to Australia the highest interest rates in the industrialised world. The Government also believes that it has nothing to do with the weakness of the Australian dollar against the major currencies. No, it is foreign buyers who are the big bad bogies, regardless of the fact that there has been no evidence to support that claim.

I now wish to address briefly Senator Messner's amendment. As I have mentioned a number of times, one of the major problems in Australia is the current account deficit, or the balance of payments deficit, whatever one likes to call it. I refer to the deficit between imports and exports-in other words, between what we buy and what we sell. As mentioned by Senator Short, the Government claimed the year before last that we were in an economic crisis because there was a collapse in our terms of trade; it was not as great as had occurred some years earlier. Then last year-and this was not forecast-the terms of trade turned around quite dramatically.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good economic management.

—More by good luck than by good management. The bad economic management lay in what the Government did about it. In August last year the Government decided that it ought to rearrange its affairs and gear itself up for an election-everybody knows the lag effect of economic changes. The Government decided to crank up the interest rate-because the world's greatest Treasurer said that inflation would be down at around 4.5 per cent by the middle of the year-and get the dollar up so as to reduce the price of imports and help to bring down inflation. That theory, like all great theories, did not work. We ended up with an enormous interest rate. Today, the ordinary businessman who goes to borrow money has to pay around 18 per cent. This is a key aspect.

SPEECH.PARA: If an Australian is competing with international buyers who are investing in this country, one needs to make a comparison. An Australian borrows money at the bank rate at 18 per cent, whereas a borrower in Japan goes to the bank and gets money at 4.5 or 5 per cent. That person is already miles ahead. The balance of payments deficit is the major cause of our problems and it is increasing our total debt at the rate of $1.5 billion a month. At the end of December our gross foreign debt was over $125 billion. The net debt, which is the figure about which the Government tends to speak more often, now exceeds $95 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much of that is private sector debt?

—I am glad that the Minister interjects on that point, as that argument is often thrown about. If my memory is correct, the figure is about 54 per cent private sector, 46 per cent government. Private debt is that high because our domestic interest rate is so damned high, thus forcing people offshore to borrow, even though they have to take an exchange risk. Everyone is aware that, if we are to improve our balance of payments, we must, if we can, increase our exports. There is a common feeling around the place at the moment that we are probably exporting as much as we can. I would hope to see more, thus reducing our imports and hence increasing our import replacement factor.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently the Prime Minister toured South East Asia-good luck to him-in an effort to get people overseas to purchase more from Australia and perhaps to get themselves involved in the Australian economy. One place he visited was the Republic of Korea. In his parliamentary statement the Prime Minister said:
My visit to the Republic of Korea took place some three months after President's Roh's visit to Australia, thus consolidating a relationship that, in economic terms, is now among our most important.

That is very true. What the Prime Minister, Robert Hawke, did not say-and I say this categorically because of what Senator McKiernan said about this Government not believing in confrontation-was that he was in Korea to mend bridges.

In 1978 I attended an international coal conference when Prime Minister Hawke was then President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). The Republic of Korea then imported about 48 per cent of its raw materials from Australia. It wanted to increase its imports, but the only thing that stopped the Koreans was their concern about the unreliability of supply because of industrial disputation or strikes. Their representative asked the then President of the ACTU to give them some assurance, some glimmer of hope, so that they could go back and recommend the purchase of more raw materials from Australia. That person was subjected to the greatest insults and diatribe I have heard in my life-much to the disgust of everyone who attended that meeting. It was not just Koreans who were present, but buyers from all over the world. The then ACTU President told them that he did not care if they did not buy one tonne of anything from Australia because he did not like their way of government, or the way in which the industrial affairs operated in that country. His view was that, if the Koreans got their act in order, he would be prepared to speak to them. I hope that on his recent visit he repaired some bridges. What happened after the earlier meeting was that the figure of coal exports to Korea fell from 48 per cent to 38 per cent. When I was in Korea recently I asked some of those people whether the earlier incident had any effect on them, and they said that it had had an effect. They said, `Why do you think we now buy only 38 per cent and not 48 per cent? Why do you think we diversified to other places, including Canada?'.

The Opposition will not oppose the Bill. We shall be pursuing some amendments during the committee stage. I reiterate the problem we have, or perceive that we have, for which a Bill is introduced to prevent foreign interests from buying urban real estate, is caused not by the purchase by foreigners of real estate but by the state of the economy and the level to which this country has been allowed to drop. That has not happened because of the people of Australia. The people do a wonderful job if they are given the chance. The inflation rate is 7.7 per cent, twice the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development average, with the inflation rate in Japan running at about one per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —You aren't going to tell us about the Fraser comparison, are you?

—I would be happy to do so. The balance of payments deficit is currently running at $125 billion and is increasing at the rate of $1.5 billion a month. I understand some of the thinking of the Australian Democrats, and I understand the feeling of nationalism that we all have, but we must remember that we have little option. We need foreign investment, and on that subject we and the Government are bipartisan. We also need to be able to save more and invest more. As Senator Messner pointed out in his amendment, this country has record levels of taxation. This is the highest taxing government this country has ever seen. This affects the ability of individuals to save and do their own investment. That has gone. We have high domestic interest rates which affect the competitiveness of our own products if we are considering import replacement. We have increasing dependence on foreign investment because of the Government-inflicted state of the economy, and of course we have a continuing balance of payments crisis.

SPEECH.PARA: We need more serious application to the problems of this country. People on the other side say that we should wait until the Government's structural improvements start to bite. I am not sure of the exact word they use; I think it is `structural'. For goodness sake, they are into their seventh year in government! I do not see any structural changes. All I know is that after the last Budget the Treasurer of this country said that the Government had introduced all the reforms that needed to be introduced. Less than six months ago he said that there were no more reforms for the Government to introduce.

We must look at our micro-economic policy and at structural changes. We must look at improving our productivity. Unless we improve our productivity, from a manufacturing point of view, we will develop into a Third World country, if we have not already done so. Japan, Korea, Taiwan and Thailand have made advances-not that I am decrying this-but we still have not changed our three major industries of mining, primary industry, and tourism. With our natural raw materials we must be able to achieve a value-added factor. It will not happen under the accord. Even the Government is starting to realise that the accord has been a failure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on!

—It has been a failure and it will continue to be such, because its bottom line is a deal not to improve the productivity of Australia or the lot of the ordinary individual Australian, but to enhance the power of the ACTU. That is what it is all about.
—Oh!
—Senator Cook smiles.
—No, I just disdain that comment. It is ridiculous.

—At the moment an effort is being made to reduce the number of trade unions. The trade-off there is that a handful of very powerful groups, the Swedish model, will increase the trade union membership from about 50 to 70 or 80 per cent, whatever can be achieved. I do not blame the union movement for doing that; that is the power game. But it is not right for this country. We must get back to the enterprise level if we are to become more productive, so that people who work in a particular organisation feel that they are in the same boat-not the east is east and west is west approach. They must be able to negotiate work conditions suitable to both sides. This was done recently in Queensland, my State, and it was opposed by the Trades and Labour Council because it saw that as a reduction in its power. Its members are human. I suppose no-one likes to see his power being reduced, but as people in the Parliament it is important that we ask not what is best in a particular power struggle but what is best for the country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Such debates on the economy show how remarkably little difference there is between the Government and the Opposition. If one listens carefully, one finds that honourable senators on the Opposition side, particularly, flail in the air to attempt to discover differences between themselves and the Government and attempt in hollow ways to criticise the Government. Earlier tonight Senator Short found it remarkable that the Government is now belatedly legislating for changes that were introduced as long ago as 1985 under administrative arrangements. Several speakers later, Senator Parer criticised the Government for coming forward with the legislation, saying that it is politicising the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Another thing that I find rather depressing is that the analysis of the economic situation we heard tonight from both sides falls a long way short of reality. It is easy to take small pieces of the economy and with those small pieces attempt to show that there is or is not a relationship between two factors. Both Senator Short and Senator Parer quoted the Real Estate Institute. I will return to the fallacy in their arguments later; at this point, I just remark that it is unlikely that the Real Estate Institute would criticise a system which pushed up house prices when the profits of its members are directly related to the value of real estate. As the value of real estate increases, real estate agencies increase their profits because they work on a percentage of turnover. Therefore, it is clearly in their interests to maintain a system which returns them the largest profit.
In three brief paragraphs of the second reading speech, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) outlined what the legislation is all about. He said:
I should emphasise that this general strengthening of the Act does not-
I stress that-
herald a new tough line on foreign investment: the Bill brings the Act more closely into line with foreign investment policy.
He went on to define the Government's foreign investment policy. He said:

The Government remains committed to a generally relaxed approach to foreign investment in all except a few sensitive sectors. Foreign investment is welcome in Australia and policy is administered on a non-discriminatory basis.

The one thing on which I would personally agree with him is that if one has a policy with respect to foreign dealings it should certainly be on a non-discriminatory basis. In every other respect I find myself in total disagreement with what the Minister said.

I emphasise again that the Opposition would have no quarrel with those arguments. It certainly supports a generally relaxed approach, perhaps a more relaxed approach, to foreign investment and it welcomes it in Australia. But the Opposition is largely aligned with those who are able to dabble in that sort of large money market, so Opposition members and their mates are the ones who, more than average Australians, benefit from that sort of arrangement. Senator Short specifically said that he accepts that foreign investment is a good thing. He also criticised Senator Haines, who spoke before him, for suggesting, as the Australian Democrats have done, that there should be a register of foreign ownership. I cannot quote his words directly but he indicated that he hoped that Senator Haines was not suggesting that foreign investment was not a good thing. Nonetheless, he indicated quite clearly that he would prefer not to have a register of foreign ownership. Clearly Senator Short was saying that he would prefer this country to go on in total ignorance of the state of foreign investment and ownership in Australia. Whether one agrees or does not agree with foreign investment and foreign ownership, surely when foreign investment in a country and the relative shift of capital between countries are as large as they are today it would be desirable at least to have the basic statistics, to know where the country is going. Senator Short would prefer simply to go on in blissful ignorance.

The best figures I have seen indicate that foreign investment in Australia is now running at between $2 billion and $5 billion a quarter. I saw those figures just in the last few days. They suggest a foreign investment rate of between $8 billion and $20 billion a year. Before I came into the chamber tonight I did a few calculations which suggest that between 20 and 50 years from now Australia will be totally foreign owned if we go on at that rate. Frankly, I am very concerned at that rate of foreign investment. It is something we need to be concerned about; it is something we need to get a handle on. We at least need the basic data. However, the Government does not provide that basic data. As far as I am aware, Queensland is the only State which has legislated, in any way, to get a register of foreign ownership of real estate. That legislation, I believe, was proclaimed only today. No other State keeps a register of foreign ownership. We should be very worried about the size of foreign ownership and we need a register of that ownership.

Let us look at the arguments in the Treasurer's second reading speech. Senator Short and Senator Parer, as I indicated earlier, quoted the Real Estate Institute and argued that the purchase of real estate had little to do with the increase in the price of real estate in Australia. Senator Parer recently said that real estate prices had continued to climb even though there had been less purchasing of urban real estate in recent years after the administrative procedures were put in place. Of course, other factors operate in this area other than foreign purchases of real estate.

However, the Government has not restricted the purchase of land for development. We have recently seen very large purchases of near-urban land for development. Given the attitude which this Government and the Opposition have to a free rein of the market, it does not take a great deal of grey matter to see that if the price of near-urban land is substantially increased by foreign purchases for development purposes, the price of other land will be pushed up. That is, indeed, a factor in the increase in the price of urban land in Australia.

If one followed the chain through, one would also realise, as we have learned earlier tonight, that some 60 per cent of Australia's foreign borrowings are private in nature. The interest payments on those foreign borrowings are written off against the earnings of individuals in Australia. That factor, therefore, increases the tax on other Australians and relatively decreases their ability to purchase real estate. So, as a result of that chain of events, the cost of acquiring housing in Australia has increased. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) seemed to argue that it is desirable to tie in our economy to that of other countries. The Minister said:
Under a policy change which I announced on 28 July 1986, foreign purchases of real estate for development-both residential and commercial-are approved unless judged contrary to the national interest.
He also comments that the Treasurer will:
. . . prohibit proposed foreign acquisitions or urban land that are judged contrary to the national interest . . .

This refers to the previous conditions to which this Bill applies. To the extent that we lock our economy into that of other countries, we make ourselves dependent upon supply and demand which occurs elsewhere. A net inflow of large amounts of capital, which there is at the present time, will push up land prices. Equally, if people who have invested take their capital out of the economy, prices will fall.

We are therefore on a treadmill and ordinary Australians in a larger market are dependent upon the operations of usually very large operators in foreign markets. As we also know, a large amount of that money in international markets is speculative capital which simply sloshes around from one place to another, wherever it can make a profit, very often in foreign currency transactions. It seems to me to be quite obscene that this Government has made the purchase of homes by ordinary Australians dependent upon that system. Indeed, this is what the Opposition would do if it were in government. I do not believe that we should be deliberately attempting to make our own internal markets as volatile as that by making them ultimately dependent on those much larger markets. The Treasurer, in his second reading speech, when speaking of the purposes of this Bill, said:
The first is the natural desire of the Australian community that local people should have the dominant influence in our economy.
Yet this Bill aims to hand over to foreign forces a substantial control and influence over our economy, particularly over the value of Australian land.

The Government also, according to the Treasurer, welcomes productive investment, and yet I find nothing in this piece of legislation which ensures that the investment coming in will be productive and not merely speculative in nature. The Treasurer also spoke of the benefits to Australia. He said:
Distinct from most forms of foreign investment, we see these purchases as providing-
he is talking about real estate-
little or no real benefit to Australia. . .

Elsewhere he also talks about `benefit to Australia' as though there is a clear benefit to Australia and no need to justify or to prove that benefit. It is as if it is sufficient merely to assert that foreign investment in Australia produces a benefit.

I would equally well assert that there will be no investment in anything unless the person who makes the investment expects and gets, in most cases, a larger return than the investment which is made. We have seen massive investments in recent decades by developed countries in Third World countries. As we know, most Third World countries have investment at such a level that there is a net flow of capital for those Third World countries back into the countries which have made the investment. There is, therefore, a net flow of capital from the poor to the rich. Senator Parer, a few moments ago, talked about Australia becoming a Third World country. I believe we are going very rapidly down that road.

We are not operating in a level playing field-we never have and we never will. The richer players in the field can always get the advantage; the rich will always get richer at the expense of the poor. All the Government has done and, as I have stated many times, all the Opposition would do if it were in government, is simply extend that system.

One test of the economy is said to be the measure of benefits. As I have argued many times in this place, I am not too sure that this is a true test. I think a large number of costs are included as benefits. Let us take for the moment the proposition that gross national product or gross domestic product is a real indicator of the wealth of the country. If a gross national product is growing at a certain percentage rate and the profit which foreign investors are taking out is larger than that rate, it follows, as a simple matter of mathematics, that the country will become poorer. If the wealth of the country is growing at 2 per cent and the profit in real terms which the foreign investor is taking out is 3 per cent, clearly the country must be becoming worse off. That is precisely what is happening.

On page 2 of the Minister's second reading speech we find the Minister justifying this legislation and the Act it seeks to amend in terms of our small population. He states that, because we have a small population relative to the size of our existing economic infrastructure, we need an inflow of foreign capital. We have a small population, certainly, but we are a relatively rich country. The investment which we need to make surely relates to the needs of the people of Australia, not to foreigners or anybody else. If the people of Australia, that small population, has certain needs, then clearly in a rich country we can find sufficient investment for those needs. To seek to exploit our resources at a faster rate than needed by our own population is to exercise greed; there is no other word for it.

Neither this Government nor this Opposition has accepted a sane economic program. They have accepted the traditional growth model which seeks merely to turn resources into waste, and that is what growth is ultimately about. We seek to push through as much resource as we possibly can, so we tear down forests and dig up resources and send them overseas, pollute our environment, and call that development. That is a lovely euphemistic term which appears repeatedly through the Minister's second reading speech.

We are a small population; we are a rich population. We have enough capital in this country for our own development provided we are modest in our demands. By seeking to exploit our resources at a faster rate than dictated by our real needs, it seems to me that we have led ourselves into a problem of enormous foreign debt which could shortly lead Australia to being totally foreign owned.

This type of development is not really the function of ordinary Australians. The majority of Australians do not participate in this process at all. As most honourable senators would know, a large amount of Australia is owned by a very small number of people, both Australians and foreigners. The figures run something like this: half a per cent of the population owns some 10 per cent of the country, 5 per cent of the population owns something like 50 per cent of the country, 10 per cent of the population owns about 60 per cent of the country, and the remaining 90 per cent of the population owns 40 per cent of the country. Those who participate in the sorts of transactions with which we are dealing in this legislation are not ordinary Australians.

As Senator Cook indicated earlier by way of interjection, our foreign indebtedness is caused substantially by private borrowings. Well over half of the foreign debt is due to private borrowings. Private borrowings have very often been mounted so that individuals can buy assets which are already owned. We have seen breweries which have been in this country for well over a century bought with foreign borrowings by people in Australia. Interest payments must be made on those foreign borrowings and the interest payments are claimed against the tax which those people pay. So not only do Australians have to pay a higher price for their products than they have paid before to repay the debt; they have to pay a higher price again to pay the interest, and a higher price again because they have to pay more tax to cover the tax avoided though the foreign borrowings. We are selling off this country so that individuals can borrow that money to buy this country's assets.

Ordinary Australians are losing all along the way. We are losing our country and we are paying others to take it away. One can find numerous examples of this. An example which has been discussed in the newspapers just recently relates to woodchipping, the infrastructure costs of which far exceed the benefits which flow back. We are losing our resources; we are paying foreign countries to take those resources away from us. It becomes particularly serious when, to cover the debts of people such as the Bonds and the Elliotts, we are selling this country to foreign interests. I am very concerned about it. My estimate suggests that the rate of foreign ownership in this country is not inconsiderable and that, if we continue to go down this road, within 20 to 50 years we could finish up in a situation where Australia is totally foreign-owned. The Australian Democrats certainly would like to see the establishment of a register of foreign ownership so that at least we get the basic data. We would like to see the whole of Australian real estate totally in Australian hands by the year 2000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I congratulate you on your appointment. This is the first time I have addressed the Senate while you have been in the chair. The Senate is considering the Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill 1988, to which my colleague Senator Messner has moved the following amendment to the motion for the second reading:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate condemns the Government for its failed economic policies which have resulted in:
(a) Australia's increasing dependence on foreign investment;
(b) a continuing balance of payments crisis and associated foreign debt problems;
(c) high domestic interest rates adversely affecting all Australians; and
(d) record levels of taxation which are heavily biased against the ability of Australians to save''.

How very true those words are. I hope that the Australian Democrats will support that amendment. After all, what has the Hawke Government done during the past six years? After all its talk, what has it done? It has mortgaged our future and it is now left with only one policy: the policy to sell off the farm, to sell off the land and assets of Australia to foreigners in order to meet the massive trade imbalance which has grown so enormously during its six years in government. When I asked a senator in this chamber yesterday what he thought about our current economic policy, he said, `Well, we are galloping down the Argentinean road'.

We are being led by a gambler. This Government has gambled away many of the benefits of the Fraser wage pause of 1982. I know the disappointments of the Fraser years and I regret the disappointments of those years, but let me assure the Parliament that the Fraser wage pause of 1982 was of enormous benefit to this country. This Government has gambled away those benefits. It has gambled away our recovery from Australia's worst drought ever, which was experienced at the end of the term of the Fraser Government. This Government has gambled away the benefits of improved commodity prices, which have been at record levels since 1986. This Government has gambled on being able to con the Australian people by talkfests, by conferences and by clever manipulation of the media while it has done nothing other than go on increasing expenditure and taxes, thereby destroying the enterprise and initiative of Australians who want to be successful. This Government has gambled on being able to con the Australian people that the 1.2 million jobs created since the 1982-83 recession were the result of good economic management. The truth is that, apart from the extra jobs created by the demand arising from increases in immigration, most of the job increases can be directly attributed to the Fraser wage pause, to recovery from the 1982 drought, and to improved commodity prices.

That propensity to gamble is very much part of both Mr Hawke's and Mr Keating's characters. Last year, in response to mounting pressures from traditional supporters, Mr Keating brought down a gambler's Budget. That gamble has not come off. Australia now faces economic disaster and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) blithely describes it as `a tragedy not a mess'. This Government has lost control and has abandoned us to the fate of the Argentineans and maybe even to the fate of the Venezuelans. As I said, and as Senator Coulter from the Australian Democrats said before me, the only policy that this Government has left is to sell off the assets of this country. If the Democrats firmly believe what Senator Coulter was saying, I hope that they will support the amendment moved by the Liberal and National parties.

Ministers in this Government are now so paralysed with fear of the consequences of Keating's last Budget that they cannot do anything or decide anything. As I have said, they have simply lost control and abandoned us to our fate. Yet there is much that they could be doing. They could be taking action to stabilise our foreign debt; to reverse the high interest rates for many categories of loans; to reduce the inflation rate; and to encourage savings. They could be taking action to provide incentives to encourage affordable home ownership; to reduce the current account deficit; and to reduce the record levels of public sector outlays and the record levels of taxation revenue. They could be taking action to reduce the levels of unemployment, particularly amongst the youth of this country. I might mention to the Senate that, under this Government, average monthly unemployment has risen to 627,000, compared with 403,000 when it took office, with the average youth monthly unemployment rate under Mr Hawke rising to 130,000, or 23 per cent, which is a national disgrace. Even some simple, practical steps by this Government would demonstrate to the people that it was still alive and not totally inept. For example, this Government could announce that it intends to build the third runway at Mascot. At least that would be an indication that it is prepared to try to do something to sort out the crisis that is existing at Mascot, our major international airport.

This Government could take some action to sort out the union movement-a movement with which it has had such close association in the past. It must be able to get through to the union movement that some things need to be changed. For example, it could at least persuade the union movement to recognise that a youth wage would increase employment opportunities and assist in developing a viable youth traineeship system. This Government could increase the number of places available at universities and other tertiary institutions. It could introduce some of the micro-economic reforms that it has been so voluble about. In particular, it could reform the waterfront, which the Economic Planning Advisory Council estimates would save this country $850m per annum. It could reform our coastal shipping and trans-Tasman shipping, with an estimated annual saving of $200m. A billion dollars could be saved every year if this Government were to take these steps. If it were to indicate that it would take these steps, at least that would be a start. It could reform the transportation of bulk coal and wheat, with an estimated saving of $700m per annum. This Government could say to the States that the States must take steps to reform these areas where there is a desperate need for micro-economic reform and where the States are not facing up to their obligations in this regard.

As Senator Messner says in his amendment, this country faces an increasing dependence on foreign investment. This country faces a continuing balance of payments crisis and associated foreign debt problems. This country faces high domestic interest rates, which are adversely affecting all Australians, and record levels of taxation which are heavily biased against the ability of Australians to save. Commodity prices, although high at the moment, have little chance of increasing any more, so the Government cannot look to that area to solve our balance of payments problem. Tourism is booming currently and bringing in substantial income but, as I mentioned, the tourist gateway at Mascot is a disgrace.

There seems to be no chance of seeing the economic turnaround on which the Hawke Government has gambled for four or five years. I cannot see it happening under this Government. As I have said, this Government has mortgaged Australia to the hilt. It does not seem to have the courage to take the urgent action desperately needed to rectify these problems. Until it does, we will continue to attack this Government for its indecisiveness and will expose it for its empty rhetoric until at last the people of Australia give us the opportunity to take these steps.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the Australian Democrats to make a brief contribution to the debate on the Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill 1988. I would like to have referred to the second reading speech of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) in this place on 25 November last year, but I think it must have been one of the shortest second reading speeches ever delivered. Instead, I wish to refer to the second reading speech by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the other place. He said in his speech:

SPEECH.PARA: In its foreign investment policy the government attempts to maintain a balance between two important interests.
The first is the natural desire of the Australian community that local people should have the dominant influence in our economy.

The Australian Democrats agree with the Treasurer that it is a natural desire of the Australian community that this should be so. Because of this, over the last year or so there has been a flurry of activity in the press with ordinary people expressing their concern at foreign takeovers. I put it to the Senate that one of the reasons for that concern is that we do not have a register of the foreign ownership in this country; therefore, people feel concerned because they are working in the dark. Earlier Senator McKiernan brought up the crayfishing industry in Western Australia. In 1988 the Western Australian Superannuation Board sold its holdings of one of the 12 processing licences for crayfishing to Chunagon Pty Ltd, a Japanese firm. There was an outcry and the then Minister for Fisheries, Mr Grill, was reported to have said that one Japanese licence was not going to damage the industry and might in fact enhance it. That was reported in the West Australian of 20 July 1988. However, in the same article we find this:
The Rock Lobster and Prawning Association has also called for a freeze on licence transfers until policy guidelines are clarified.
Association president Max Ball said the industry was concerned that Chunagon was a major Japanese end-user.
Those fears were justified, because earlier this year-on 22 January 1989-we read in the Sunday Times:
A giant Japanese fishing company is trying to take over the multi-million dollar WA crayfishing market, it was claimed yesterday.
More than 250 angry crayfishermen met in Geraldton this week to call on the Federal Government to block the sale of three fishing licences to the Chunagon company.
Details of the sale are now before the Foreign Investment Review Board. The final say rests with the Treasurer, Mr Keating.

As Senator McKiernan said earlier, the Treasurer blocked that sale. If that sale had been approved, it would have placed 25 per cent of Western Australia's processing licences for crayfishing in Japanese hands. That is why ordinary workers are concerned that their livelihoods are going to foreign ownership. Again in Western Australia we had the case of Sanwa Vines. This is a Japanese firm which has bought up a vast acreage-I suppose I should say hectareage these days-of land in the Swan Valley at Ellenbrook. The land, the condominiums and town houses to be built are already on sale in Japan, and the prices are very high.
Perth hotels are coming on the market just like cards being dealt for a round of rummy. We read in the West Australian newspaper on 8 November last year:
Four of Perth's six top hotels are owned by Asian businesses and they are set to buy part of a fifth.

The hotels already owned are the Hyatt Regency, the Parmelia Hilton, the Burswood International and the Orchard Hotel. The fifth hotel involved in negotiations is the Sheraton. There is a very interesting tie-up there among those hotels because the Parmelia Hilton is owned by the same people who own the Sanwa Vines holiday development.
We then have the case of Japanese investors buying a farm in Western Australia. The West Australian newspaper in September last year said:
A report in this week's Countryman says the sale comes at a time when tempers are running hot in the Eastern States with a backlash against continuing Japanese investment.

The backlash is there not, I hope, because of any feeling that a certain nation should not move into this country, although as Senator Powell said we must have regard to the sensitivities, especially as far as the Japanese are concerned. But the Democrats believe that the concern is there because it is our land that is being sold and we do not know how much of it is being sold.

There was a very offensive advertisement which appeared in a Chinese newspaper. The advertisement appeared with the slogan `Australia up for grabs'. It had a picture of a smiling Asian man holding a handful of earth with a sprouting bush. In the advertisement people were asked to buy and make money down under. The message in the advertisement was:
``If you want to own a piece of Australia, here is a golden opportunity to buy land in an area where prices and values are rising rapidly.
``Either way it makes an excellent investment proposition as land for home unit development in fast developing Perth . . .
The advertisement appeared twice in June in the English-language Post, which is published in Hong Kong and distributed throughout South-East Asia.
I was very pleased to read in the Sunday Times in Perth on 21 August last year that the State Minister for Housing, Mrs Beggs, said:
The advertisement wording could lead West Australians to pay higher prices for land.
She said: ``I would think that sort of advertising overseas is not in the best interests of the domestic market.

There is awareness that overseas investment in housing and land is pushing up the prices of homes for Australians. We are fortunate in Western Australia that our prices have not risen to the extent that they have risen in the eastern States but they are certainly on the rise. If we were able to have a register so that we could know exactly how much is owned by overseas investors, we could assess that situation more closely and come to logical conclusions. We are working in the dark. There is also concern that the Japanese are moving into the beef market. That is a very genuine concern expressed by rural people and others who are working in that industry. It is an industry which has had enough problems without having the problem of foreign ownership added to it.

If the Government wants to put an end to this sort of press as far as overseas investment is concerned and if it wants to put an end to what I think have been described as xenophobic tendencies, a register so that we know exactly what is owned by foreigners overseas for investment purposes would certainly achieve that result. I hope that we will not have yet another example of the Government and coalition Opposition voting for the second time in less than a week for such information to be denied to Australian citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the other time?

—The other time was when I sought to have tabled documents relating to advice given by the Australian Electoral Commission to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) with regard to the electoral system for the Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: The second important interest listed by the Treasurer-the first, honourable senators will recall, was a natural desire of the Australian community that local people should have the dominant influence in our economy-was the very significant benefit that Australia gains from foreign investment. Without a register, without knowing how much foreign investment we have and without being able to do the sums in detail, how on earth can we possibly assess that situation? It is very difficult to do when working in the dark. Senator Parer asked for the facts; the facts are simply not there. The Treasurer went on in his speech to say:
Under a policy change which I announced on 28 July 1986, foreign purchases of real estate for development-both residential and commercial-are approved unless judged contrary to the national interest.

Who is judging whether the national interest is being served? How can this be judged if we cannot place it in the context of the degree of foreign investment which we have in this country? The Treasurer went on:

Purchases of developed commercial real estate are approved subject to a flexible guideline for 50% Australian equity, with approvals for 100% foreign ownership being granted if Australian equity on reasonable terms and conditions is unavailable.

What a cop-out that is! Indeed, this is a doublespeak. We find doublespeak in the Foreign Investment Review Board report 1987-88 which was tabled the other day in the Senate. We read that, as far as policies are concerned in manufacturing, services, resource processing, non-bank financial institutions, insurance, sharebroking, tourism, rural properties and primary industry:
The Government approves proposals to acquire existing businesses or to establish new businesses over $10 million, unless the proposal is contrary to the national interest.
Again this is a subjective judgment. As far as real estate is concerned, the report says:
Acquisitions . . . are approved unless they are contrary to the national interest . . . providing no more than half of the units in any one development are sold to foreign interests.

But if those are sold again, how are we to know into which hands they are falling? The doublespeak continues as far as mining is concerned. Our mining interests can be sold to foreign investors. The report states:
The Australian Equity and control guideline is applied flexibly.
I refer now specifically to uranium, where the report states:
Foreign interests may explore for uranium and are not required to seek Australian participation in their exploration activities.

That is indeed a very strange kind of policy to have when we have a three-mine policy as far as the Parliament is concerned and a no uranium mine policy as far as the Australian Labor Party policy is concerned.

So the Foreign Investment Review Board itself is indeed a toothless tiger. We do not have a register. We have some rather rubbery figures which are available only through two official sources of information. One is the Foreign Investment Review Board itself and the other is the Australian Bureau of Statistics. As far as the Australian Bureau of Statistics is concerned, most of the figures relate to the first half of this decade and no-one can be sure as to their accuracy. The 1984-85 figures, which I believe are the latest available, record the mining industry as being 44.7 per cent foreign owned and mineral explorations 35 per cent foreign controlled. Thirty-seven per cent of petroleum exploration expenditure was also foreign controlled. According to the 1982-83 figures, which are the most recent available, the manufacturing industry was 33 per cent foreign owned; transport 5.1 per cent foreign owned and 3.4 per cent foreign controlled. And so the figures go on, although they are not up to date. The Australian Bureau of Statistics says that the figures cannot be regarded as having any great degree of accuracy. Again I refer to the Treasurer's second reading speech, in which he said:
I should emphasise that this general strengthening of the Act-
he was talking about the increase in penalties for giving false information-
does not herald a new tough line on foreign investment: . . . The Government remains committed to a generally relaxed approach to foreign investment in all except a few sensitive sectors.
The whole situation is very loose. The Treasurer went on to say:
Acquisitions below these thresholds-
that is, $5m in the case of Australian businesses and $3m in the case of rural businesses-
seldom raise issues that require detailed consideration.
I regard that as an insult to the ordinary Australian public. I would suggest it is a softly, softly foreign takeover approach. The Treasurer said:
It is to be noted that there has been a net reduction in staff in the foreign investment area of Treasury in recent years as a result of liberalisations of the foreign investment guidelines.

That is a confession indeed. I do not believe that liberalisation is acceptable to ordinary Australians on matters as serious as this. It may or may not be acceptable after we have a register of foreign ownership, but at least we would be put in a position where we could make up our minds on a sensible and rational basis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking briefly I wish to reflect on some of the figures and facts that are involved in the Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill. The legislation is quite extraordinary. It reflects the Government's position that it does not mind non-Australians buying any or all of our businesses, factories, shops or undeveloped subdivisions-be they residential or commercial-so long as they do not buy our houses. That is the theory that comes through in the legislation and I have no idea why. What we have to remember and assume is that the position is totally racial. The legislation refers specifically to Japan. Table 4.4 at page 20 of the 1987-88 report of the Foreign Investment Review Board shows that in 1983-84 the United States of America held $19.9 billion worth of property. By 1986-87, the amount was $40.5 billion, or more than double. In 1983-84 the United Kingdom held $20.4 billion worth of property. By 1986-87 the figure was 37.1 billion, or almost double. In 1983-84 the figure for Japan was 10.8 billion, which by 1986-87 was 21.3 billion-less than double.

SPEECH.PARA: The figures also show that Japan, which is the obvious target of the legislation, held $10.8 billion worth of property in 1983-84 and that in 1984-85 the figure had risen to $16.2 billion-a rise of 60 per cent in one year. Between 1984-85 and 1985-86 it rose 25 per cent and in the year 1986-87-the year in which this legislation was put together-it rose by the massive sum of 5 per cent! The whole thing blew up in our faces. To take it further, the figures showed that in 1983-84 Japan had 12 1/2 per cent of the total value of overseas ownership and exactly the same amount-that is, 12 1/2 per cent-in 1986-87. So the Government went through a great charade to try to prove figures which are not provable. Anybody who, fortuitously, kept copies of newspapers at the time would find that on 13 November 1987 the Australian carried the headline `Home ownership move inflames racism claims'. I thought that the Government was accusing the Opposition of racism last year, but I am talking about the year before. The racist claims against the Government were made in 1987, the year before. The newspaper article stated:
Japanese investors are annoyed by a perceived anti-Japan bias in Australia's new foreign home ownership rules and apparent racism.

Who is talking racism? Here the Government is floating this ridiculous legislation and attacking the Japanese when, 12 months earlier, people were saying, `Oh, yes, that Liberal mob was racist'. The Government produced legislation to demonstrate its racism. The Government was against the Japanese. Why was it not against the United States of America or the United Kingdom, both of which have twice as much ownership in Australia as Japan does? Japan was blamed for house prices. There were all sorts of articles in the newspaper about the way in which Japanese buyers were driving up prices. Who has any evidence of that? I have had a good look-and I know a little about housing-and there is no evidence to show that the Japanese influence drove up prices. This rule came into effect on 29 September 1987. Prices have risen miles more since that date than before it. That is the date that the clappers were put on the Japanese. From that date prices have risen very considerably. As I have said, even now the Japanese still own only half of what the United States and the United Kingdom have in Australia.

The whole point is that the crazy, spotty economy which is being created by the Government is causing the trouble. The fiddled dollar is the problem and the Government knows it. Overseas speculators-from whatever country they come-like Australia. There are no revolutions in Australia; the inflation rate is good, 7 or 8 per cent; and interest rates are high. Speculators can get interest rates of 15 to 18 per cent. Australia is absolutely made for speculators. It is not made for ordinary Australians though. We must remember that Japan is our major trading partner. In 1988 we increased our trade surplus with Japan by a further $900m. The Age newspaper of 4 March states:
Australia's surplus from trade with Japan grew by a strong $900 million to $4.56 billion last year as Australia's biggest customer bought more of everything from abalone to zinc ore.

We are talking about the country that is our biggest trading partner and buys everything it can from Australia. It suits it to do so and it certainly suits us. Whether the commodity is abalone, zinc or anything else, our trade with Japan must be fostered. The Government must make up its mind.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 22 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In how many airports in the world is the Air Traffic Control Autonomous Radar Digital System (ATCARDS), similar to that at Melbourne Airport, installed.
(2) Have any other airports experienced errors with ATCARDS following its installation similar to those at Melbourne Airport.
(3) What is the normal period within which a new system of this type would be expected to settle down.
(4) Was the previous radar tracking method used as a backup from the time ATCARDS was installed. If not, why not.
(5) How many air traffic controllers at Melbourne Airport have been suspended since ATCARDS was installed.
(6) How many air traffic controllers at Melbourne Airport were suspended in the comparable period in each of the last 3 years.
(7) Have any air traffic controllers at Melbourne Airport resigned from their positions following the installation of ATCARDS.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A number of overseas administrations use the ATCARDS radar display. ATCARDS is an Australian acronym for the AIRCAT series manufactured by Thomson-CSF (France). While the actual figures would have to be verified with other administrations it is understood that there are approximately 2,800 AIRCAT radar displays installed at one hundred and thirty airports in forty countries at this time compared with thirty radar displays at three airports (Adelaide, Melbourne and Perth) in Australia.

(2) All new radar display systems, regardless of manufacture, require an amount of fine tuning to optimise their operation for the local conditions and for the characteristics of the radar heads used. No two installations in the world are exactly the same so that the ``errors'' experienced in Australia are not the same as elsewhere even if the same basic radar display system is installed.

(3) The settling in period for any radar display systems can vary considerably in length, depending on the complexity, the type of radar heads being used and the methods of running up and testing. There is no recognised ``normal period''.

(4) The field sensor (antenna) equipment serving the old system now serves the new ATCARDS system. The display equipment associated with the old Centre was dismantled and removed shortly after the new equipment was commissioned to provide urgently needed critical spares for the Sydney and Brisbane systems.

(5) and (6) Ratings suspensions are initiated by supervisory staff when they desire to enquire into an aspect of a controller's work output. In itself a suspension is not a punitive action but merely allows an examination to proceed in a mutually constructive atmosphere. Because this is so, no records are kept of rating suspensions.
(7) There have been six resignations of Air Traffic Controllers from Melbourne Airport since 1 May 1988, two of which were from the ATCARDS area.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 22 November 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Prime Minister expand on his answer to my Question on Notice No. 539 (see Senate Hansard, 17 October 1988, page 1508) by providing the following details:
(1) How much of the $1.25 million spent on travel and accommodation in the 1987-88 financial year was spent on overseas travel?

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 1 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: In view of the decision of the Defence Science and Technology Organization to let a $2 million contract to Schlumberger Instrumentation Australia Pty Ltd to develop and market a new high performance, low-cost visual air traffic control simulator called AUSTOWER which is to be supplied to the RAAF School of Air Traffic Control at East Sale in Victoria, and in the light of the establishment of the National Air Traffic Control training centre in Launceston, Tasmania, will the Minister confirm whether the Government intends to supply that centre with the AUSTOWER simulator; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Civil Aviation Authority does not plan to supply an AUSTOWER simulator to the National Air Traffic Control training centre at the Tasmanian State Institute of Technology (TSIT) in Launceston, Tasmania, at this time.
The CAA is currently installing an Air Traffic Control simulator at TSIT to assist in the training of students in radar and procedural control and flight advisory services.

The training needs of the Authority are subject to continuous review and in assessing the need to supplement training capabilities the Authority will examine the options offered by potential contractors in accordance with normal commercial practice.
